questions.text:
A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation is found to have high blood pressure recording and a urine protein of 3+. Concomitant presence of which of the following symptoms would make you suspect imminent eclampsia?


	Headache
	Blurred vision
	Persistent pedal oedema
	Epigastric pain
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 1, 2, 4

Explanation: Headache, blurred vision, persistent pedal edema, and epigastric pain are warning signs of imminent eclampsia.

The warning signs of imminent eclampsia include:

  • Blood pressure ≥160/110 on two different occasions while the patient is on bed rest
  • Proteinuria of <5 g/24 hours
  • Oliguria or anuria
  • Epigastric pain (4)
  • Headache (1) and visual symptoms (2)
  • Pulmonary edema or cyanosis
  • Sudden and generalized or persistent pedal edema (3)
  • End organ damage
  • Disturbed sleep

Visual symptoms such as blurred vision, diplopia, scotomata, and amaurosis fugax are telltale signs that the patient is entering an eclamptic state from pre-eclampsia.

Treatment:

  • Prevention of seizures with MgSO4
  • BP control with anti-hypertensives
  • If <34 weeks, corticosteroids for lung maturation
  • Termination of pregnancy is the definitive treatment

questions.text: Which one of the following is not used to treat PCOD?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Tamoxifen

Explanation: Tamoxifen is not used commonly for the treatment of PCOD. Tamoxifen is a selective estrogen receptor modulator (SERM) primarily used for the treatment of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer.

Drugs used to treat Infertility in PCOS

  • Letrozole (preferred over clomiphene citrate):
    • Aromatase inhibitors
    • No antiestrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix, thus yielding a better pregnancy rate.
    • Induces Mono Follicular stimulation, thus avoiding multiple pregnancies.
    • No hyperstimulation syndrome.
    • Side effect - drowsiness.
  • Clomiphene citrate: (Option A)
    • Unlike letrozole, it has anti-estrogenic action on the endometrium and cervix, thereby decreasing the fertility rate.
    • It can cause hyperstimulation Syndrome in <1% of patients.
    • It induces ovulation in 80% of the cases, and 40-45% conceive.
    • Co-administration of dexamethasone leads to better outcomes.
    • In resistant cases, Tamoxifen 80-160 mg daily for 5 days is tried.
  • Metformin: (Option B)
    • It is used as an insulin sensitiser.
    • Reduces the insulin levels, delays glucose absorption and production of glucose in the liver
    • It also improves the peripheral utilisation of the glucose. Reduces the free and total testosterone and increases SHBG.
    • Contraindicated in hepatic and renal disease
  • Oral Contraceptive Pills (OCP): (Option D)
    • Fourth-generation combined pills containing ethinyl estradiol and drospirenone are preferred.
    • Oral combined pills with Cyproterone acetate (DOC)
    • Oral combined pills with spironolactone
    • Used to treat menstrual abnormalities, reducing acne and hirsutism.
  • Nowadays, instead of Metformin, some gynaecologists prefer using N-acetyl cysteine with micronutrients. This reduces the homocysteine level and improves fertility outcomes.
  • Ketoconazole 800mg daily reduces testosterone secretion.
  • If medical management fails, then surgical management can be undertaken.

questions.text: A doctor tells a 31-year-old woman, who is 20 weeks pregnant, that her baby has a developmental defect. She has come to you for a second opinion. The following USG finding is seen. Identify the defect.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Anencephaly

Explanation: The given ultrasound image shows an open defect in the calvaria and skin, with exposed brain tissue, consistent with anencephaly.

Anencephaly:

  • Absence of the cranium and telencephalon above the level of the skull base and orbits.
  • Progresses from acrania (absence of cranium with disorganized brain tissue) to exencephaly (herniation of brain tissue), with anencephaly being the final stage.
  • It results from incomplete closure of the neural tube and can be detected as early as 10–11 weeks of gestation via ultrasound or maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) screening.
  • Sonographic findings include:
    • Abnormal cranial contour in the first trimester.
    • Absence of ossified cranium.
    • Characteristic signs:
      • Shower cap sign (disorganized brain tissue protruding).
      • Frog eye sign (prominent orbits with absent calvaria).
  • Anencephaly is uniformly lethal, and perinatal palliative care consultation is recommended if the pregnancy is continued.
  • Folic acid supplementation at a dose of 4 mg daily before conception can reduce the risk of neural tube defects and is recommended in subsequent pregnancies.

Omphalocele (Option B) is a congenital anterior abdominal wall defect where abdominal organs protrude through the umbilical ring, encased in a thin sac. This defect does not involve cranial structures and is unrelated to the findings of absent cranial vault and brain tissue.

Cystic hygroma (Option C) is a congenital lymphatic malformation often found in the posterior neck. It appears as a multiloculated cystic mass on ultrasound and does not involve neural tissue or cranial defects, distinguishing it from the described condition.

Encephalocele (Option D) is a neural tube defect characterized by herniation of brain tissue and/or meninges through a skull defect. Unlike anencephaly, encephalocele presents with a localized defect in the skull, not the complete absence of the cranium and brain tissue.

questions.text: What is triage for?

choices.text: To assess the impact of a disaster
To classify the priority of treatment

questions.solution:
Correct answer C) To classify the priority of treatment

Explanation:

  • Triage is the process of classifying patients based on the severity of their condition and the priority of treatment required.
  • It is commonly used in emergencies or mass casualty incidents with limited resources.
  • Triage helps in efficiently allocating resources by prioritising patients based on the urgency of their condition.

 

To prepare for a disaster (Option A) is incorrect because the purpose of triage is not to prepare for a disaster but rather to assess and prioritise patients during a disaster or emergency situation.

To assess the impact of a disaster (Option B) is incorrect because while triage is a part of disaster response, its main objective is not to assess the overall impact of a disaster but to categorise patients based on the severity of their injuries or illnesses.

To rehabilitate following a disaster (Option D) triage is not involved in the rehabilitation process after a disaster. Triage focuses on initial assessment and prioritisation of patients during the acute phase of a disaster.

questions.text: If the contractility of the heart is decreased, which of the following is seen?

choices.text: Shift of the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Shift of the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right

Explanation:

  • Reduced contractility shifts the end-systolic volume and pressure curves to the right on the pressure-volume loop, indicating that the heart is ejecting less blood per contraction.

Myocardial Contractility

  • Definition:
    • The intrinsic ability of the myocardium to contract and generate force, independent of preload (end-diastolic volume) and afterload (resistance against which the heart pumps).
    • Changes in contractility shift the Frank-Starling curve (relationship between stroke volume and end-diastolic volume).
  • Impact on Frank-Starling Curve:
    • Increased Contractility (Positive Inotropic Effects):
      • Shifts the curve upward and to the left.
      • Results in a greater stroke volume at any given preload.
    • Decreased Contractility (Negative Inotropic Effects):
      • Shifts the curve downward and to the right.

The Bowditch Effect

  • Alternative Names: Treppe phenomenon, staircase phenomenon, frequency-dependent activation
  • Definition:
    • An increase in heart rate enhances the force of contraction of myocardial cells with each heartbeat, independent of other influences.
  • Mechanism:
    • Related to calcium ion handling and mishandling in cardiac cells.
    • Involves proteins crucial for excitation-contraction coupling, such as sarcoplasmic endoplasmic reticulum calcium-ATPase (SERCA).

Aspect

Details

Positive Bowditch Effect

Seen in healthy hearts, related to SER Ca load alterations.

Negative Bowditch Effect

Pathological, due to diminished SERCA protein expression, hallmark of heart failure.

Clinical Significance

Shift from increasing heart rate to beta-blockers for improved cardiac function in heart failure.

Incorrect Options:

Decreased end-diastolic volume and pressure (Option A): Incorrect. Reduced contractility typically impairs the heart’s ability to fill properly during diastole, leading to an increase in end-diastolic volume and pressure as the heart struggles to adequately fill.

Increased stroke volume (Option C): Incorrect. Reduced contractility results in decreased stroke volume since the heart is less efficient at pumping blood, impairing its ability to eject blood effectively.

Enhanced response to sympathetic stimulation (Option D): Incorrect. A decrease in contractility usually indicates a weakened response to sympathetic stimulation, as the heart is unable to contract as forcefully as required.

questions.text:
Nonclinical question: Match the following:


	
		
			
			1. Hirschsprung’s disease
			
			
			A. MRCP
			
		
		
			
			2. Posterior urethral valve
			
			
			B. CT scan
			
		
		
			
			3. Choledochal cyst
			
			
			C. Rectal biopsy
			
		
		
			
			4. Intussusception
			
			
			D. Micturating cystourethrogram
questions.solution:
Correct answer C) 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B

Explanation:

Condition

Investigation

Explanation

Hirschsprung’s disease

Rectal biopsy (C)

Gold standard test to confirm absence of ganglion cells in the colonic submucosa, leading to functional obstruction.

Posterior urethral valve

Micturating cystourethrogram (MCUG) (D)

Identifies posterior urethral obstruction due to congenital valves in male infants, causing urinary retention and hydronephrosis.

Choledochal cyst

MRCP (Magnetic Resonance Cholangiopancreatography) (A)

Best non-invasive imaging modality to visualize biliary tree anomalies, including cystic dilatation of the common bile duct.

Intussusception

CT scan (B) (Ultrasound is first-line for children)

CT scan shows the "target sign" in adults, while USG is preferred for children, showing characteristic concentric rings.

questions.text: An individual is in an environment of a temperature of 47ºC. What is the mechanism of heat loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sweating

Explanation:

  • When an individual is in a hot environment with a temperature of 47°C, the primary heat loss mechanism is sweating. Sweating is the process by which the body releases moisture (sweat) onto the skin's surface. As the sweat evaporates, it absorbs heat from the body, thus helping to cool it down. Sweating is an effective cooling mechanism in hot environments to dissipate heat and maintain body temperature within a normal range.

Mechanisms of Heat Loss

  • Radiation:
    • Heat loss via infrared rays emitted from the body to the environment.
    • Accounts for 60% of heat loss under normal conditions.
    • Significant in cooler environments or when at rest. (Option A ruled out)
  • Evaporation:
    • Heat loss through vaporization of water from the skin and respiratory tract (sensible sweating and insensible losses).
    • Accounts for 20-22% of heat loss at rest; can increase to 80% during intense activity.
    • Crucial in high temperatures or during physical exertion.
  • Conduction:
    • Heat transfer from body to cooler adjacent objects (solid or liquid) via molecular contact.
    • Contributes 2-15% of total heat loss, depending on surface contact.
    • More significant when in contact with cooler surfaces (e.g., sitting on cold floor, swimming in cool water). (Option B ruled out)
  • Convection:
    • Heat loss through air or water movement around the body.
    • Accounts for 15% of heat loss.
    • More effective with increased wind or air movement. (Option C ruled out)

questions.text:
A mother notices a swelling in the abdomen of her 3-year-old child while bathing him. He had a history of hematuria two weeks back, which resolved spontaneously. On examination, a right–sided reniform ballotable mass was found. What investigations will you do?

1. CECT

2. PET-CT

3. 24 hour urinary VMA

4. FNAC
questions.solution:
Correct answer) C 1, 2 and 3

Explanation:

Investigations for a Ballotable Abdominal Mass in a Child (Suspected Wilms Tumor)

Investigation

Role in Diagnosis

Justification

CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT Scan)

First-line imaging for renal tumors

Determines tumor size, extent, local invasion, and vascular involvement (e.g., renal vein or IVC thrombus).

PET-CT (Positron Emission Tomography-CT)

Staging and metastasis detection

Helps assess lymph node involvement, lung, liver, and bone metastases. Also differentiates Wilms tumor vs. neuroblastoma.

24-hour urinary VMA (Vanillylmandelic Acid)

Differentiates Wilms tumor from Neuroblastoma

Neuroblastoma (adrenal origin) → elevated VMA levels; Wilms tumor does not produce catecholamines.

FNAC (Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology)

Not recommended

Contraindicated in Wilms tumor due to risk of tumor spillage, which can lead to peritoneal dissemination. Core biopsy may be done in unclear cases.

Hence (Option C) 1, 2 and 3 is the right answer

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature observed in osteoporosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Normal calcium and normal ALP

Explanation:

  • Osteoporosis occurs due to excessive bone resorption compared to bone formation resulting in reduced bone density.

 

Osteoporosis:

  • Disorder with low bone mass and structural defects, increasing fracture risk.
  • Cancellous regions: More porous; cortices: Thinner.
  • Loss of bone strength is mainly due to decreased bone mass and structural connectivity in trabecular bone.
  • Plain radiographs: Not sufficient for diagnosis, though signs like trabecular loss and vertebral compression fractures can suggest osteopenia.

Bones affected in osteoporosis:

  • Vertebrae (Spine) (Most common)
  • Hip (Proximal Femur)
  • Wrist (Distal Radius) (First fracture)
  • Ribs
  • Pelvis
  • Humerus (Upper Arm)
  • Tibia and Fibula (Lower Leg)

DEXA (Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry):

  • T-score: Standard deviations below the young adult mean.
  • Z-score: Standard deviations below the age-matched mean.
  • WHO T-score interpretation:
    • Osteoporosis: Below -2.5
    • Osteopenia: Between -1.0 and -2.5
    • Normal bone mass: Above -1.0

Additional DEXA Tools:

  • Vertebral Fracture Assessment (VFA): Assesses for vertebral fractures using a low-resolution lateral spine image.
  • Trabecular Bone Score (TBS): Measures bone microarchitecture based on lumbar spine texture.

Fracture Risk Assessment:

  • Bone density is one risk factor; other tools (FRAX, QFracture) assess fracture risk based on clinical factors and bone density.

 

Normal calcium and increased ALP (Option A)It is observed in Paget’s disease and Rickets or osteomalacia.

Decreased calcium and normal ALP (Option C) This is seen in hypoparathyroidism, renal failure, and vitamin D deficiency.

Increased calcium and increased ALP (Option D) This is seen in primary hyperparathyroidism. In addition to this, they have high PTH levels.

questions.text: What should be the subsequent course of action in the management of a female patient who experienced abdominal pain and increased heart rate three days after cholecystectomy? Her white blood cell count is 11000 cells / mm^3, and an ultrasound examination revealed a 5x5 cm accumulation of fluid in the sub-hepatic space on the right side.
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage

Explanation:

  • The next step in managing a woman who presented with abdominal pain and tachycardia, with a fluid collection in the right sub-hepatic space seen on ultrasound, is USG-guided pigtail catheter drainage as this is a case of bile duct injury following cholecystectomy.
  • Ultrasound-guided pigtail catheter drainage offers several advantages, including improved accuracy in locating the fluid collection and minimizing the risk of complications.

 

Antibiotics and send home (Option A) The presence of a fluid collection and symptoms suggestive of postoperative complications necessitates intervention rather than sending the patient home with antibiotics alone.

Laparoscopy and re-exploration (Option C) are not the first-line management options for a fluid collection in the subhepatic space. Less invasive measures like drainage should be attempted first.

ERCP and T-tube placement (Option D) are indicated in biliary tract-related issues, which may not be the primary cause of the fluid collection in this scenario.

questions.text: What is the duration of short-term memory?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 30-300 seconds

Explanation:

  • Short-term memory (STM), also called working memory, is the brain's temporary storage system used for immediate tasks such as reasoning or learning.
  • It retains information for a brief period, typically lasting 30 to 300 seconds (0.5 to 5 minutes).
  • Beyond this timeframe, information either decays or transfers to long-term memory if rehearsed or encoded.

Short-term memory:

  • Short-term memory retains information for durations ranging from seconds to several hours.
  • The ventral hippocampus, specifically the CA1 region, is responsible for short-term memory.
  • Through rehearsal or repetition, short-term memories can be consolidated into long-term memories.

Long-term memory:

  • Long-term memory retains information for years or even a lifetime.
  • The neocortex serves as the centre for long-term memory storage.

Incorrect Options:

3-6 hours (Option A): This duration is associated with long-term memory consolidation, not short-term memory. Short-term memory is transient and does not last for hours without active rehearsal.

12-18 hours (Option B): This duration pertains to retained information in long-term memory or residual effects of memory retention after learning. Short-term memory operates on a much shorter timescale.

3-4 seconds (Option D): This duration corresponds to sensory memory, particularly echoic (auditory) or iconic (visual) memory, which lasts only a few seconds before decaying. It is not the same as short-term memory.

questions.text:
Arrange the following in sequential order with regards to the steps of collection of samples for pap smear testing:


	Use posterior vaginal wall retractor
	Take the sample
	Make smear on a slide
	Fix the smear
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation: The correct sequential order involved in a Pap smear procedure is 1, 2, 3, 4.

Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from the transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor (1) or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells (2) by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells (3) onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear (4) with a fixative to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

questions.text: Which of the subsequent observations manifest itself later in compartment syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Paralysis

Explanation:

  • Paralysis is a late finding in compartment syndrome, indicating severe and advanced muscle and nerve damage. It is crucial to recognize and treat compartment syndrome promptly to prevent irreversible tissue damage and complications.

 

Compartment syndrome:

  • Compartment syndrome is a condition where increased pressure within a closed muscle compartment compromises the circulation and function of the tissues within that space. The classic symptoms and signs include the "5 Ps": pain, pallor, paresthesia (tingling or numbness), paralysis, and pulselessness.

Clinical Features:

Initial Symptoms of Compartment Syndrome (in chronological order)

  • Pain (Option D): The earliest symptom, worsened by passive extension of fingers - Stretch pain
  • Pallor (Option A): Skin may appear pale due to reduced blood supply.
  • Pulselessness (Option C): Diminished or absent radial pulse.
  • Paresthesia: Numbness or tingling due to nerve compression.
  • Paralysis: Weakness or inability to move fingers, indicating nerve ischemia.

 

Causes include:

  1. Tight bandages and dressings
  2. Animal bites
  3. Burns
  4. Intensive and excessive exercises
  5. Muscle hypertrophy
  6. Neoplasms
  7. Bleeding into a closed compartment (injury to a vessel, congenital or acquired disorder)
  8. Injections in the forearm
  9. Surgery on the forearm

 

Common sites:

  • Most common: Flexor compartment of the forearm.
  • 2nd Most common: Anterior and deep posterior compartments of the legs.
  • Rare sites: Buttocks, shoulder, hand, foot, arm, and lumbar paraspinal muscles.

questions.text: What is the name of the instrument depicted below, which is utilized for the creation of a pneumoperitoneum?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Veress needle

Explanation:

  • The Veress needle is a surgical instrument used to create a pneumoperitoneum, which is the insufflation of carbon dioxide gas into the peritoneal cavity to create a working space during laparoscopic procedures.
  • The Veress needle is inserted through a small incision or through the umbilicus, and its tip is equipped with a spring-loaded mechanism that allows for controlled penetration of the abdominal wall. Once inserted, carbon dioxide gas is introduced through the needle to inflate the peritoneal cavity.

 

Morris' needle (Option B) Not commonly used for pneumoperitoneum; it is mainly used in general surgical procedures for drainage or infiltration.

Yankauer suction tip (Option C) A rigid suction device used primarily in oropharyngeal and surgical suctioning, not for insufflation.

Von Graefe needle (Option D) A specialized needle used in ophthalmic surgery, particularly for cataract procedures, unrelated to laparoscopic surgery

questions.text: The sodium iodide symporter is present in all of the following except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pituitary gland

Explanation:

  • The pituitary gland does not have the presence of the sodium iodide symporter. Unlike the thyroid gland and certain other tissues, the pituitary gland does not actively concentrate iodine, and the expression of NIS is not found in this gland. In summary, while NIS is present in the thyroid gland, placenta, and salivary glands, it is not found in the pituitary gland.

Sodium Iodide Symporter (NIS):

Locations of NIS and Functions

Location

Function

Thyroid Gland (Option A ruled out)

Active iodide transport for thyroid hormone synthesis (T3, T4) in thyroid follicular cells.

Salivary Glands (Option C ruled out)

Possible role in regulating iodide content in saliva (exact function unclear).

Gastric Mucosa

Potential involvement in iodide transport within the stomach.

Placenta (Option B ruled out)

Allows iodide transfer from maternal to fetal circulation, necessary for the development of the fetal thyroid gland.

Mammary Glands

Facilitates iodide transfer during lactation for breastfeeding purposes.

Kidney

Aids in iodide homeostasis, with expression in renal tubular cells.

Other Tissues

Observed in extrathyroidal tissues with unclear or under-researched roles.

questions.text: Calculate the Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) of a patient admitted after a road traffic accident and receiving mechanical ventilation. The patient demonstrates a response by opening their eyes upon verbal command and exhibits spontaneous movement in all four limbs.
questions.solution:
Correct answer D Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6

Explanation:

  • Eyes-3, Verbal-NT, Motor-6 indicates that the patient opens eyes spontaneously, but the verbal response is not testable (NT), and the patient exhibits purposeful motor response. Since the verbal response is not provided, the total GCS score cannot be determined.
  • Eyes-2, Verbal-1, Motor-5 (Option A) suggests that the patient opens their eyes in response to pain, gives an inappropriate verbal response, and exhibits localized motor response.The total GCS score would be 8.
  • Eyes-2, Verbal-NT, Motor-5 (Option B) indicates that the patient opens their eyes in response to pain, but the verbal response is not testable (NT), and the patient exhibits a localized motor response. Since the verbal response is not provided, the total GCS score cannot be determined.
  • Eyes-3, Verbal-1, Motor-6 (Option C) suggests that the patient opens their eyes spontaneously, gives an inappropriate verbal response, and exhibits purposeful motor response. The total GCS score would be 10.

Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS):

Eye Opening (E)

Spontaneous

4

Eyes open without stimulation.

To verbal command

3

Eyes open in response to speech.

To pain

2

Eyes open in response to painful stimuli.

No response

1

No eye opening.

Verbal Response (V)

Oriented

5

Correctly answers questions about self, location, and time.

Confused

4

Speech is coherent but disoriented.

Inappropriate words

3

Random or unrelated words in response.

Incomprehensible sounds

2

Moaning or groaning without forming words.

No response

1

No verbal sounds.

Motor Response (M)

Obeys commands

6

Follows simple motor commands (e.g., "Lift your arm").

Localizes pain

5

Purposefully moves to remove painful stimulus.

Withdraws from pain

4

Flexion response to painful stimuli.

Abnormal flexion (decorticate posturing)

3

Flexion of arms with extension of legs in response to pain.

Abnormal extension (decerebrate posturing)

2

Extension of arms and legs in response to pain.

No response

1

No motor movement.

Calculating the Total GCS Score

  • Formula: GCS = E (Eye opening) + V (Verbal response) + M (Motor response).
  • Range: 3 to 15.

questions.text: What would be the appropriate next step in the management of a 55-year-old female patient who has a 4x3 cm lump in the right upper outer quadrant, with no involvement of axillary lymph nodes, and a BIRADS 4b staging on mammography? The patient underwent breast conservation surgery, and the final histopathology examination (HPE) report indicated high nuclear-grade ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS) with necrosis and a 10mm margin clearance.

choices.text: Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up

questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Adjuvant Radiotherapy

Explanation:

  • After breast conservation surgery for high nuclear-grade DCIS with necrosis and margin clearance, adjuvant radiotherapy is the appropriate choice.
  • DCIS, a non-invasive breast cancer type, involves abnormal cells within breast ducts but not spreading outside.
  • High nuclear grade DCIS with necrosis signifies a more aggressive form.
  • Margin clearance of 10mm confirms absence of cancer cells around the tumor, lowering local recurrence risk.
  • Adjuvant radiotherapy targets any remaining cancer cells in breast tissue, further reducing recurrence risk, notably ipsilateral.

 

Adjuvant Chemotherapy (Option B) Not typically recommended for DCIS, reserved for invasive breast cancer.

Follow up 6 monthly for 2 years and then yearly follow up (Option C) While follow-ups are crucial post-treatment, adjuvant radiotherapy is necessary here to minimize recurrence risk.

Trastuzumab Therapy (Option D)Targeted for HER2-positive invasive breast cancer, not typically indicated for HER2-negative DCIS. Reserved for cases with HER2 overexpression, typically invasive cancers.

questions.text: An old lady slipped and fell at home. She was diagnosed with a Colles fracture and managed with a POP cast. What is the correct sequence of reduction of the given fracture?

choices.text: Traction, POP, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation
Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP
Traction, ulnar deviation, palmar flexion, POP
Palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, traction, POP

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Traction, palmar flexion, ulnar deviation, POP

Explanation:

  • Colles’ fracture is extra-articular.
  • The deformity seen is Dinner fork deformity.

Displacements seen are:

  • Impaction of fragments
  • Dorsal displacement
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Lateral displacement
  • Lateral tilt
  • Supination

Closed manipulation of Colles’ fracture is by:

Traction + Counter traction (by the assistant)

↓

Palmar flexion

↓

Ulnar deviation

↓

POP application

Management of a Colles' fracture:

  • Closed reduction and below elbow POP cast- “Handshake cast”: Palmar flexion,pronation and ulnar deviation (prevent dorsal displacement).

 

Complications

  • Stiffness of fingers - most common
  • Malunion - next common complication
  • Median nerve - most common nerve injured.
    • One of the very common causes of Carpal tunnel syndrome.
  • Extensor pollicis longus - most common tendon injured.

 

Options A, C and D are incorrect

questions.text: Beta hCG is structurally similar to which biochemical moiety?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) LH

Explanation:

  • Beta hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) is structurally similar to LH (luteinizing hormone). Human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is a hormone produced during pregnancy. The placenta primarily secretes it and has various functions, including supporting the development of the corpus luteum and maintaining progesterone production.

Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG)

Physiology of hCG

Production and Source:

  • Produced primarily by syncytiotrophoblasts of the placenta post-implantation.
  • Minor production occurs in the anterior pituitary, liver, and certain tumors (e.g., choriocarcinoma, germ cell tumors).

Structure:

  • Subunits:
    • Alpha (α): Shared with LH, FSH, and TSH.
    • Beta (β): Unique, determines biological specificity, contains glycosylation sites influencing activity.

Functions:

Function

Role

Maintaining Pregnancy

Stimulates corpus luteum to produce progesterone, essential for uterine lining maintenance.

Trophoblast Growth

Enhances cytotrophoblast growth and placental development.

Angiogenesis

Promotes blood vessel formation in uterine endothelium for fetal nutrition and oxygenation.

Immunomodulation

Alters immune responses to promote fetal tolerance at the maternal-fetal interface.

Clinical Significance:

  • Detectable in maternal blood ~10 days post-ovulation; peaks at 8-10 weeks, then declines but remains elevated.
  • Used to confirm pregnancy, monitor its progression, and diagnose ectopic pregnancies or trophoblastic diseases.

Isoforms and Implications:

Isoform

Characteristics/ Functions

Classical hCG

Supports early pregnancy.

Hyperglycosylated hCG

Involved in placental invasion and growth.

Free β Subunit

Elevated levels may indicate malignancies (e.g., trophoblastic tumors).

Sulfated hCG

May influence pregnancy outcomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a part of AMTSL?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Controlled cord traction

Explanation: Controlled cord traction is a component of active management of the third stage of labor (AMTSL).

Steps of AMTSL:

  • Use of uterotonic (oxytocin) after the birth of the baby (5-10 IU IM) at delivery of the anterior shoulder, before delivery of the placenta. (Option A)
  • Delayed cord clamping (≥ 1-3 minutes). (Option D)
    • Wait for 60 seconds.
    • Increases the Hb of the baby by 1g% (preventing neonatal anemia).
    • Contraindicated in:
      • Fetal distress
      • HIV/HbsAg positive mother
      • Rh-negative mother
  • Delivery of the placenta by controlled cord traction (Modified Brandt Andrews method).
  • Intermittent assessment of uterine tone.

Advantages of AMTSL
  • Minimised Blood Loss
  • Shortened Duration

Disadvantages
  • Slightly increased incidence of retained placenta
  • Risk of asphyxia in the second twin if administered prematurely.

Indications

High-risk factors include anaemia, hydroamnios, twins, grand multiparae, and a previous history of postpartum haemorrhage (PPH).

Uterine massage (Option C) is not recommended for preventing postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) in women who have received prophylactic uterotonics such as oxytocin. It is now considered an optional component of AMTSL and is primarily used in managing uterine atony during PPH.

questions.text: The formula for urea clearance is U×V/P, where U is?

choices.text: Urine concentration of urea in mg/100ml
Urine concentration of urea in mg/ml

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Urine concentration of urea in mg/ml

Explanation:

  • Clearance measures the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per minute (mL/min), reflecting renal excretory efficiency. It is essential for evaluating kidney function, including filtration, reabsorption, and secretion processes.

To calculate the clearance rate (Cs) of the substance, use the formula:

  • Clearance Formula: (Cs) = (Us x V) / Ps
    • Us: Urine concentration of the substance
    • V: Urine flow rate
    • Ps: Plasma concentration of the substance

questions.text:
After a fracture in the femoral shaft, your consultant instructs you to apply tibia traction. Which of the following will you ask the nurse to provide?
 

1. Thomas splint

2. K-wire

3. Steinmann pin

4. Denham's pin

5. Bohler's stirrup

6. Bohler Braun splint
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) 3, 5, 6

Explanation:

Steinmann pins can be used for skeletal traction by inserting into the tibia following a shaft of femur fracture where 10% of body weight or 20 kg of weight is used.

  • Bohler’s stirrup is a device that holds the Steinmann pin and is used to maintain traction.
  • Bohler Braun splint has 3 pulleys and is used to immobilise and support lower limb fractures by maintaining traction.

Instrument

Images

Proximal Femur Nail (PFN)

  • The Proximal Femoral Nail (PFN) is used for closed intramedullary fixation of proximal femoral fractures.
  • It features two proximal openings for a femoral neck lag screw and an anti-rotation screw.
  • Indications include peritrochanteric, intertrochanteric, and subtrochanteric fractures.
  • It is contraindicated for medial femoral neck fractures.

Kuntscher Nail

  • Used for internal fixation of femoral fractures.
  • The nail is a hollow tube with a cloverleaf shape for rotational stability.
  • Fixation is based on three-point fixation: at both ends and the isthmus.
  • Each end has an "eye" for the extractor hook during removal.
  • Nail size is determined by measuring from the greater trochanter to the lateral knee joint line and subtracting 2 cm.
  • About 2 cm of the nail is left protruding at the trochanter for removal, usually 2 years post-operation.

Kirschner wire (K wire)

  • Thin, straight steel wire with a diameter of 1 to 3 mm.
  • Uses include:
    • Internal fixation of small bones.
    • Tension band wiring in patella
    • Applying traction (e.g., through the olecranon).
    • Fixing fractures in children.
    • Used in Ilizarov’s fixation system.

Steinmann Pin

  • Stout, straight steel rod with a diameter of 3 to 6 mm.
  • Primarily used for skeletal traction.
  • Common sites for insertion include the upper end of the tibia, the supracondylar region of the femur, and the calcaneum.

Bohler’s Stirrup

  • A device used for holding a Steinmann pin and applying traction.
  • Side screws secure the pin in place.
  • Allows for changing the direction of traction without moving the pin inside the bone.
  • Helps avoid loosening of the pin during traction adjustments.

Thomas Splint:

  • Primarily for the stabilization and immobilization of fractures in the femur or tibia.
  • It consists of a metal frame that supports the limb, preventing movement and reducing the risk of further injury.

Steinmann Pin:

  • It is a large, stainless steel pin used for internal fixation of fractures or to stabilize bones during surgery.
  • Typically inserted percutaneously (through the skin) or during surgery and is used to hold bones in place for proper healing.

Denham's Pin:

  • It is used for joint stabilization, often in the hip joint.
  • It is inserted into the bone and can be used for traction or temporary stabilization while healing.

Bohler-Braun Splint:

  • Splint used for the immobilization of fractures, especially in the thigh and leg.
  • It is a two-piece splint made of metal and is commonly used for fractures of the femur and tibia.

questions.text:
Following a road traffic accident, a patient develops type IIIa compound tibial fracture. Arrange the following external fixators in decreasing order of their stability (highest to lowest)

1. Ilizarov fixator

2. Uniplanar with a single rod

3. Uniplanar with double rod

4. Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) 1 > 4 > 3 > 2

Explanation:

Highest to the lowest order of their stability starts with Ilizarov > Biplanar frame > Uniplanar with double rod > Uniplanar with a single rod.

  • Ilizarov fixator: The Ilizarov fixator is the most stable fixator. It uses a ring-based system with multiple rods and wires that provide a high degree of stability and control over the alignment and position of the bone fragments. The fixator can be adjusted in multiple planes, providing more stability and making it effective for complex fractures like type IIIa compound tibial fractures.
  • Biplanar frame/Ring with a cylindrical rod: This fixator provides stability through its ring configuration, with the added benefit of a cylindrical rod that increases strength. The biplanar design gives good stabilization in two planes, making it more stable than uniplanar designs but less so than the Ilizarov.
  • Uniplanar with double rod: A uniplanar fixator with double rods provides more stability than a single rod because of the additional support, but it only stabilizes in one plane. It's less stable than biplanar or Ilizarov systems due to the reduced number of support structures and limited planes of control.
  • Uniplanar with a single rod: This is the least stable option because it provides minimal support and only in one plane. It’s commonly used for less complex fractures but doesn’t offer the same level of stability needed for more severe fractures like a type IIIa compound tibial fracture.

questions.text: Which of the following options is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Kallman syndrome

Explanation: Kallmann syndrome is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea; it results in primary amenorrhea due to hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

Primary Amenorrhea is diagnosed when a young girl who has not yet menstruated by:

  • 13 years (in the absence of secondary sexual characters)
  • 15 years (regardless of the presence of secondary sexual characters)

Secondary amenorrhea is defined as the absence of menstrual periods for three consecutive months in a woman who previously had regular menstrual cycles, or for six months in a woman who had irregular cycles.

Common causes of secondary amenorrhea:

  • Physiological Causes:
    • Pregnancy
    • Lactation
  • Pathological Causes:
    • Genital Tract:
      • Acquired cervical canal obstruction
      • Asherman syndrome (Option D)
      • Vaginal atresia
      • Vesicovaginal fistula
    • Ovarian Causes:
      • Surgical extirpation, radiotherapy
      • Multiple ovulation induction
      • PCOD
      • Resistant ovarian syndrome (absent FSH receptors)
      • Infections (e.g., mumps, tuberculosis)
      • Masculinizing ovarian tumors
      • Premature ovarian failure/menopause
    • Pituitary Causes:
      • Insufficiency: Simmonds disease, Sheehan syndrome (Option C)
      • Hyperprolactinemia, prolactinomas
      • Empty sella syndrome
      • Drugs (e.g., tranquillizers, OC pills, dopamine blockers, antihypertensives, antidepressants)
    • Hypothalamic Causes:
      • GnRH deficiency, vigorous exercise, stress, obesity
      • Pseudocyesis, brain tumors, anorexia nervosa
    • Suprarenal Causes:
      • Addison disease, adrenogenital syndrome, suprarenal tumors
    • Thyroid Causes:
      • Hypothyroidism, chest wall lesions, Graves' disease

Turner’s mosaic (Option A): Turner syndrome causes primary amenorrhea, while Turner mosaicism can present with either primary or secondary amenorrhea, making Kallmann syndrome the best answer in this case.

questions.text: All of the following ions have decreased concentration on the luminal side of the proximal convoluted tubule except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Chloride

Explanation:

  • In the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT), glucose, amino acids, and bicarbonate are actively reabsorbed, leading to decreased concentrations in the lumen. Chloride, however, is primarily reabsorbed paracellularly with sodium, and its concentration remains relatively high in the lumen as it is not actively reabsorbed.

Proximal Convoluted Tubule:

PCT plays a crucial role in renal function by reabsorbing approximately 65% of filtered sodium, chloride, potassium, bicarbonate, and almost all filtered glucose and amino acids.

  • Isotonic Absorption
  • Passive reabsorption of Calcium (65%)

Sodium Resorption: Occurs through various Carrier Proteins

  1. SGLT (5%): Secondary Active Transporter of Sodium and Glucose
  2. Co-Transporters (45%): It reabsorbs sodium along with other substances like
    • Amino acids (Sodium-amino acid co-transporter)
    • Phosphate (Sodium-phosphate co-transporter)
    • Citric acid (Sodium-citric acid co-transporter)
  3. Sodium Hydrogen Exchanger (45%)
    • Antiporter.
    • It provides H+ ions and aids in the absorption of Bicarbonate
  • Na/K ATPase is present on the Basolateral side, which creates the gradient for Sodium.
  • Sodium Bi-Carbonate Co-transporter (NBC): Helps in Na reabsorption in the basolateral membrane.

Proximal Tubule has two parts:

  • Proximal Convoluted Tubule (PCT): It is a little impermeable for chloride reabsorption, leading to a higher concentration of chloride in the Proximal convoluted tubule.
  • Proximal Straight Tubule (PST): Na+ is reabsorbed along with chloride.

questions.text: When the outer sheath and nerve fiber remain intact while the inner axons are affected, this condition is referred to as
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Axonotmesis

Explanation:

  • The intact outer sheath and damaged inner axon are known as axonotmesis.
  • Tinel’s sign is positive and progressive. It is an axonal breakdown.
  • Recovery is not complete.
  • An injury to the peripheral nerve of one of the extremities of the body. The axons and their myelin sheath are damaged, but the endoneurium, perineurium and epineurium remain intact is defined as axonotmesis.

The Seddon classification is a system used to categorize peripheral nerve injuries based on the degree of damage to the nerve and its components.

 

Type

Description

Prognosis

Neurapraxia

(Grade I) (Option A)
  • Temporary conduction block, myelin damage only.
  • No neuroma and no degeneration.
  • Recovery is complete within 6 weeks.

Axonotmesis

(Grade II) (Option B)
  • Axonal damage, connective tissue intact.
  • Neuroma in continuity.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Recovery can take up to months
  • Complete recovery may not occur.
  • Motor march present

Neurotmesis

(Grade III) (Option D)
  • Complete nerve disruption.
  • End or side neuroma.
  • Degeneration: Proximally+distally.
  • Spontaneous recovery never occurs.
  • Repair is required (poor recovery)

 

Axonopraxia (Option B) There is a partial axonal disruption with no significant damage to the surrounding nerve structure.

questions.text: What would be the minimum percentage for normal sperm morphology in a seminal fluid analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 4%

Explanation:

4% is the minimum percentage of sperm with normal morphology considered acceptable.

Semen Analysis and Normal Values:

  • First investigation for infertility in males.
  • Performed after 1 year of unprotected intercourse without conception or earlier if there are known risk factors for infertility.
  • Abstain: 2-7 days.
  • Analysis: Within 1 hour on the liquefied semen (takes 20-30 min).

Parameters

Normal (Normozoospermia)

(WHO 2021 Guidelines)

Volume

> 1.4 ml

pH

7.2-8.0

Concentration

At least 16 million/ ml

Total count

39 million/ejaculate

Total Motility

42% or more

Progressive motility

30% or more

Morphology (most important)

4% or more

Pus cells (WBC)

1-2 million/ml

Viability

54% or more

Note:

  • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia (OATZ) means all parameters are subnormal, as seen in varicocele and smoking.
  • The most important parameters in sperm analysis are Morphology > Motility > Concentration.

questions.text: Which among the following has the highest airway resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Bronchi

Explanation:

The medium to large-size bronchi, specifically the lobar and segmental bronchi, are the site of maximum resistance to airflow. This is because these bronchi have a relatively larger radius but are fewer in number, resulting in higher individual resistance.

  • According to Poiseuille's law, resistance to airflow (R) is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the radius (r) of the airway.
  • Resistance: R = 8ηL/πr4
  • Therefore, small changes in the radius result in significant changes in resistance. Despite the smaller radius of the bronchioles, their parallel arrangement results in a lower total resistance.

questions.text:
Match the following syndromes with their respective karyotypes:


	
		
			
			Condition
			
			
			Karyotype 
			
		
		
			
			1. Turner's syndrome
			
			
			A) 46 + XX
			
		
		
			
			2. Swyer syndrome
			
			
			B) 46 + XY
			
		
		
			
			3. Androgen insensitivity syndrome
			
			
			C) 46 + XY
			
		
		
			
			4. MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser) syndrome
			
			
			D) 45 + X0
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A

Explanation: The correct answer is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

Condition

Karyotype

1. Turner's syndrome

A) 45 + X0

2. Swyer's syndrome

B) 46 + XY

3. Androgen insensitivity syndrome

C) 46 + XY

4. MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser) syndrome

D) 46 + XX

Turner's syndrome:

  • Genetic condition where one of the X chromosomes is partially or completely missing (45,X0), leading to ovarian failure and hypogonadism.
  • Affected individuals typically present with short stature, a webbed neck, low hairline, widely spaced nipples, and absent or poorly developed secondary sexual characteristics, including amenorrhea.

Swyer syndrome (pure gonadal dysgenesis):

  • Caused by mutations in the SRY gene, resulting in undeveloped gonads that cannot produce hormones or anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH).
  • Patients appear phenotypically female with normal external genitalia and a uterus, but they experience primary amenorrhea and lack secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Their dysgenetic gonads carry a risk of malignant transformation.
  • This syndrome is male pseudohermaphroditism with pure 46 XY gonadal dysgenesis.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser (MRKH) syndrome:

  • Characterized by the absence of the uterus, cervix, and upper vagina in females with a 46,XX karyotype, but the ovaries and external genitalia are normal.
  • These individuals present with primary amenorrhea, as the uterus fails to develop.

Complete androgen insensitivity syndrome (CAIS):

  • Individuals with a 46,XY karyotype cannot respond to androgens due to defective androgen receptors, resulting in the development of female external genitalia and the absence of a uterus and cervix.
  • They have normal breast development, primary amenorrhea, and may have inguinal swelling due to undescended testes.

questions.text: During exercise, once a state of balance is achieved, it was observed that the body's oxygen consumption rate was 1500 ml/min. To determine the MET score, consider a baseline oxygen consumption rate of 250 ml/min.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6

Explanation:

  • MET (Metabolic Equivalent of Task) is a unit used to estimate energy expenditure during physical activity, defined as the ratio of metabolic rate during activity to resting metabolic rate.

Formula to Calculate MET:

MET = Oxygen consumption during exercise/ Resting oxygen consumption

Given:

  • Oxygen consumption during exercise = 1500 ml/min
  • Resting oxygen consumption = 250 ml/min

Calculation:

MET = 1500 ml/min/ 250 ml/min= 6

Thus, the MET score is 6, indicating that the energy expenditure during exercise is 6 times higher than at rest.

 

Factors affecting MET:

  • Body weight: Heavier individuals generally have a higher absolute energy expenditure during physical activities than lighter individuals.
  • Fitness level: More physically fit tend to have a more efficient cardiovascular system and improved oxygen utilization, resulting in lower energy expenditure for the same activity than individuals with lower fitness levels.
  • Age: Generally, younger individuals have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities than older individuals.
  • Activity duration and intensity: Longer durations or higher intensity activities result in higher energy expenditure.
  • Body composition: Individuals with a higher percentage of lean muscle mass typically have a higher metabolic rate and may expend more energy during physical activities.
  • Environmental factors: Extreme temperatures or high altitudes can increase the body’s energy demands, leading to higher energy expenditure and potentially higher MET values.

questions.text:
What of the following instruments are used in the caesarean section?


	Bard-Parker blade
	Doyen's retractor
	Cusco's speculum
	Allis forceps
	Shirodkar's uterine clamp
	Green Armytage forceps
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 2, 4, 6

Explanation: The correct answer is 1, 2, 4, 6 used in the cesarean section.

The instruments used in a caesarean section include:

(1) Bard-Parker Blade: Used for making precise abdominal, skin and subcutaneous tissue incisions.

(2) Doyen's Retractor: Applied to retract back the edges of the incision or tissue as well as the bladder for better exposure of the lower uterine segment during cesarean section.

(4) Allis Forceps: Typically used for securely grasping and holding tissues (e.g., peritoneum, rectus sheath, vaginal mucosa).

(6) Green Armytage Forceps: Utilized specifically in gynaecological surgeries, including caesarean sections, to compress a wide area and control bleeding as a hemostat.

(3) Cusco’s Speculum (Option B & D) is a self-retaining bivalve instrument used for visualizing the cervix, vaginal fornices, and performing procedures like Pap smears.

(5) Shirodkar's uterine clamp (Option A & B) is a surgical instrument used in gynecological procedures, such as sling surgeries and tubal procedures, to securely grasp and stabilize the uterus.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy was brought to the ER following a motor vehicle collision complaining of pain over the hip. The x-ray is given below. What will be the next step of management?

choices.text: Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability
Open reduction and reconstruction of posterior pillar of acetabulum

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Closed reduction and assessment of hip stability

Explanation:

  • The above X-ray shows characteristics of posterior dislocation of the left hip. Deformity observed is flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the hip. Closed reduction is a non-surgical technique to realign the displaced bone to its normal position.

Posterior dislocation of hip

Anterior dislocation of hip

Mechanism of injury:
Caused by force along the femoral shaft with the hip flexed (e.g., dashboard injury in motor accidents).

Mechanism of injury:

Rare injury that occurs with forced abduction and external rotation.

Clinical Features:

  • History of trauma.
  • Pain, swelling.
  • Deformity: flexion, adduction, internal rotation.
  • Shortening of the leg.
  • Femoral head is palpable in the gluteal region.

Radiological Features:

  • Femoral head displaced from the acetabulum.
  • The thigh is internally rotated, the lesser trochanter is not seen, and Shenton’s line is broken.
  • May require a CT scan for associated fractures.

Clinical features:

  • The limb appears externally rotated.
  • Possible lengthening of the affected limb
  • The femoral head is palpable in the groin.

 
 

Management of posterior hip dislocation:

Immediate Reduction:

  • Reduction must be performed as soon as possible as delays over 6 hours increase risks of osteonecrosis and osteoarthritis.
  • Closed reduction is preferred unless a femoral neck fracture is present.

 

CT pelvis with 3D reconstruction (Option B) can give a better view of the structures around the hip joint and help detect associated fractures. Not used for first line management

High-weight skeletal traction (Option C) The immediate next step of managing posterior hip dislocation would be closed reduction initially, followed by traction for 3 weeks.

Open reduction and reconstruction of the posterior pillar of the acetabulum (Option D) Open reduction is an invasive procedure, and hence it is required only if closed reduction is unsuccessful or if there is a loose intra-articular fragment which prevents proper reduction, or if the acetabular fragment is large.

questions.text: What is the normal uterocervical length?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 7 cm

Explanation: Uterocervical length is typically 6-7 cm in a non-pregnant state and measured using Sims’ uterine sound.

  • Cervical length:
    • Measured from the internal to the external os.
    • 2-4 cm (up to 5 cm) in non-pregnant women.
    • 3-5 cm in early pregnancy as it stretches.
  • A short cervix during pregnancy increases the risk of early labor and delivery, making it an essential measure to monitor.

questions.text:
What of the following symptoms are seen in endometriosis?


	Infertility
	Dysmenorrhea
	Vaginal discharge
	Vaginal bleeding
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 1, 2, 4

Explanation: The symptoms of endometriosis include infertility (1), dysmenorrhea (2), and vaginal bleeding (4).

Endometriosis is the abnormal growth of endometrial-like tissue outside the uterus. It is estrogen-dependent and typically occurs in women of childbearing age.

Category

Clinical Features/Complications

Fertility-related
  • Infertility
  • Increased risk of ectopic pregnancy

Pain-related
  • Chronic pelvic pain
  • Dysmenorrhea
  • Dyspareunia
  • Dyschezia

Organ-specific
  • Gastrointestinal:
    • Bowel obstruction
    • Rectal bleeding
  • Ovarian:
    • Endometriomas
    • Ovarian torsion
    • Rupture of chocolate cyst
  • Urinary:
    • Ureteral obstruction
    • Hydronephrosis

Structural
  • Adhesions
  • Frozen pelvis
  • Vaginal bleeding

questions.text: What is the needle placement angle when using the interrupted suturing technique to suture a laceration in the ER?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) 90 degrees

Explanation:

  • When using the interrupted suturing technique, the needle should be placed perpendicular to the skin surface, creating a 90-degree angle.
  • This angle allows for proper penetration and closure of the wound edges.
  • By inserting the needle at a right angle to the skin, the sutures can adequately hold the tissues together and provide optimal wound closure and healing.

 

60 degrees (Option A) would be too shallow for proper needle placement during interrupted suturing.

70 degrees (Option B) is also too shallow for interrupted suturing.

80 degrees (Option C) is closer to the correct angle of 90 degrees but is still not ideal for interrupted suturing.

questions.text: A female patient having frothy vaginal discharge was found to have a strawberry cervix. Which of the following is the drug of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Metronidazole

Explanation: The clinical features, including frothy vaginal discharge and strawberry cervix, point towards trichomoniasis. The drug of choice is metronidazole.

Trichomoniasis:

  • Sexually transmitted infection caused by Trichomonas vaginalis.

  • Clinical Findings:

    • Vulvar erythema and edema.

    • Copious, frothy, yellow-green, foul-smelling discharge.

    • Punctate lesions on the cervix (strawberry cervix).

    • Vaginal pH > 4.5.

  • Treatment:

    • First-line Treatment: Metronidazole: 400 mg three times a day for 5 days or a single dose of 2 g.

    • Alternative Treatments:

      • Tinidazole: 2 g as a single dose.

      • Secnidazole: 2 g as a single dose.

    • Partner Treatment: Both partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent recurrence.

  • Benefits of Single Dose Therapy: Ensures better compliance.

questions.text: What causes the stimulation of the Pacinian corpuscle?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Pressure

Explanation:

  • Pacinian Corpuscles are rapidly adapting receptors that are particularly sensitive to rapid changes in pressure and vibrations of tissues.

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Rapidly Adapting Tactile Receptors

Structure

Function

Location

Adaptation

Pacinian Corpuscle

Encapsulated nerve ending
  • Detect tissue vibration or other rapid changes in the mechanical state of tissues
  • Stimulated by rapid local compression of the tissue

Immediately beneath the skin and deep in the fascial tissues of the body

Adapts in a few hundredths of a second

Meissner Corpuscle

Elongated, encapsulated nerve ending of a large myelinated sensory nerve fiber
  • Sensitive to movement of objects over the skin and low-frequency vibrations
  • crucial for spatial location discernment of touch sensations

Nonhairy skin, particularly abundant in fingertips and lips.

Adapts in a fraction of a second

Hair End

Nerve fiber entwined at the base of each hair

Detects :

  • Movement of objects on the body surface or
  • Initial contact with the body

Hairy skin

Adapts readily

 

 

 

Specialized mechanoreceptors

Superficial

Superficial

Deep

Deep

Discriminatory touch, Stroking

Texture, Edges, Braille

Pressure, Vibration

Sustained pressure

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

Rapidly adapting

Slowly adapting

questions.text: Which of the following poisoning agent does not inhibit cytochrome oxidase?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: C) Methane

Explanation:

Cytochrome c oxidase is complex 4 in the electron transport chain. It is inhibited by the following:

  • Carbon monoxide
  • Cyanide
  • Hydrogen sulfide

Thus, cytochrome oxidase is not inhibited by methane.

questions.text: What might you suspect as the diagnosis for a 26-year-old male patient who arrives at the emergency department complaining of abdominal pain and constipation persisting for the last three days? The patient recalls being struck in the abdomen by a bull three days ago. Could you examine the provided X-ray to aid in your assessment?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) Hollow viscus perforation

Explanation:

  • Hollow viscus perforation refers to the rupture or perforation of a hollow organ within the abdominal cavity.
  • In this case, the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation, along with a history of abdominal trauma from a bull gore, raise suspicion for a hollow viscus injury.
  • The X-ray suggestive of perforation, such as free air under the diaphragm

 

Hemothorax (Option A) Accumulation of blood in the pleural cavity due to trauma, does not match the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation resulting from a bull gore injury.

Pneumothorax (Option C) Air in the pleural cavity causing lung collapse, doesn't align with the patient's symptoms of abdominal pain and obstipation due to bull gore injury. Pneumothorax typically presents with sudden chest pain, breathing difficulty, and decreased breath sounds.

Intestinal obstruction (Option D) Blockage of intestinal flow, partially fits the patient's presentation but doesn't explain the bull gore injury and X-ray findings of perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to detect HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: A) Ion exchange chromatography

Explanation:

  • Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is measured by ion exchange chromatography. This method is based on difference in charge. A mixture of charged proteins is analyzed over carboxymethylcellulose paper which is negatively charged. A positively charged resin bed separates negatively charged HbA1c. It has the advantage of separating hemoglobin variants into peaks. Some hemoglobin variants may interfere with results.

 

Electrophoresis (Option B) : It is the movement of biomolecules in the electric field.

  • It depends on charge, size and shape
  • It is used to separate the components of a protein mixture
  • It denatures the protein structure and coats all the protein with a negative charge.

Immunoassay (Option C) measures the presence or concentration of a macromolecule in a solution through the use of an antibody (usually) or an antigen, e.g. ELISA

Affinity chromatography (Option D) is based on affinity between the molecules. A mixture of enzymes and other proteins is analysed wherein the other protein elutes first. It is used to separate enzymes, vitamins, antibodies and hormones.

questions.text: Fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) is required in which of the following interpretations of HER2/NEU?
questions.solution:
Correct answer B) 2+

Explanation:

  • HER2/NEU 2+ in immunohistochemistry (IHC) requires fluorescence in-situ hybridization (FISH) for interpretation.
  • FISH confirms HER2/NEU gene amplification in cases with equivocal IHC scores (2+), indicating neither definitively negative nor positive.
  • FISH determines HER2/NEU overexpression, rendering the test positive.

 

1+ (Option A) IHC score suggests low HER2/NEU expression, usually considered negative, not requiring FISH.

3+ (Option C) IHC score indicates strong HER2/NEU overexpression, typically positive, not necessitating FISH.

All of the above (Option D) FISH is essential only for 2+ IHC results to confirm positivity; it's not needed for 1+ or 3+ scores.

questions.text: All of the following increases gastric acid secretion except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Serotonin

Explanation:

  • Serotonin (5-HT) plays a key role in gastrointestinal motility.
  • During peristalsis, stretching of the intestinal wall triggers the release of serotonin.
  • Serotonin activates the myenteric plexus, regulating peristaltic movement.

Hormones and Enzymes Increasing Gastric Acid Secretion

  • Gastrin (Option A ruled out)
    • Source: G cells in the stomach antrum and duodenum
    • Mechanism:
      • Stimulates ECL cells to release histamine
      • Directly activates parietal cells to increase H+/K+ ATPase expression
  • Histamine (Option B ruled out)
    • Source: ECL cells (in response to gastrin)
    • Mechanism:
      • Binds to H2 receptors on parietal cells
      • Increases cAMP levels, activating H+/K+ ATPase to enhance acid secretion
  • Acetylcholine (Option C ruled out)
    • Source: Vagus nerve (parasympathetic stimulation)
    • Mechanism:
      • Binds to muscarinic receptors on parietal cells
      • Increases intracellular calcium, stimulating H+/K+ ATPase activity
  • Other Factors
    • Amino Acids: Stimulate gastrin release, indirectly increasing acid secretion
    • Ghrelin: Secreted by the stomach, potentially enhancing acid secretion

questions.text: A primigravida in her 10th week of gestation presents with spotting. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 12 weeks. Transvaginal ultrasound was done and it is given below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Hydatidiform mole

Explanation: Primigravida with spotting and a "snowstorm" appearance on ultrasound points towards a diagnosis of hydatidiform mole.

Hydatidiform mole:

  • Benign form of the gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD).
  • Characterized by abnormal trophoblastic tissue growth in the uterus, leading to swollen, fluid-filled villi and markedly elevated β-hCG levels, often exceeding 100,000 mIU/mL.
  • While initially benign, it can occasionally progress to persistent gestational trophoblastic disease or malignancy.
  • Clinical Findings:
    • Amenorrhea
    • Uterine Bleeding (Most common feature)
    • Uterine Growth: Larger than expected for gestational age and softer in texture.
    • Absence of Fetal Heart Sounds: Complete moles show no fetal heart motion.
    • Theca-Lutein Cysts: Ovaries may show cysts >6 cm.
    • Hyperthyroidism
    • Severe Preeclampsia/Eclampsia
    • Lower abdominal pain
    • Hyperemesis gravidarum
  • Diagnosis:
    • Serum β-hCG > 1,00,000 mIU/ml
    • Ultrasonography: Complete mole appears as an echogenic uterine mass with anechoic cystic spaces, resembling a "snowstorm" appearance, with no visible fetus or amniotic sac.
  • Management:
    • Suction and evacuation after cervical preparation.
    • Follow-up: Serial hCG monitoring.
    • Prophylactic chemotherapy: Administer methotrexate (1 mg/kg/day) on days 1, 3, 5, and 7 for high-risk women (WHO score >7).
    • Avoid pregnancy for at least one year.

Blighted ovum (Option A) is an anembryonic gestation where the fertilized egg implants in the uterus, but no embryo develops. On ultrasound, it shows a gestational sac without a fetal pole.

Missed abortion (Option B): In this condition, the fetus dies but remains in the uterus, causing no immediate symptoms. Ultrasound reveals an empty sac or absence of fetal cardiac activity and movement in an early pregnancy.

Ectopic pregnancy (Option C) is a life-threatening condition where the fertilized egg implants outside the uterine cavity, usually in the fallopian tube, and requires immediate intervention. Ultrasound shows no intrauterine pregnancy.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient came to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria. A 2x2 cm bladder mass is seen which is low grade transitional cell carcinoma. Which among the following is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
Correct answer A) Transurethral resection of the tumour

Explanation:

  • Transurethral resection of the tumour (TURBT) is the initial standard treatment for low-grade transitional cell carcinoma (TCC) of the bladder.
  • This procedure is performed using a cystoscope inserted through the urethra to remove the tumor from the bladder.
  • TURBT allows for both diagnostic and therapeutic purposes, as the tumor is removed and sent for histopathological examination to confirm the diagnosis and assess the stage and grade of the tumor.

 

Resection with ileal conduit (Option B) is not the ideal management for low-grade transitional cell carcinoma of the bladder. It is typically reserved for cases of invasive or high-grade bladder cancer that cannot be adequately treated with transurethral resection alone.

Partial cystectomy with bladder reconstruction (Option C) may be considered particularly if the tumour is in a favourable location and can be completely excised while preserving bladder function. However, transurethral resection is generally the preferred initial treatment for most cases of low-grade bladder cancer.

Neoadjuvant chemotherapy (Option D) It is typically used for muscle-invasive bladder cancer or cases with a high risk of progression.

Tumor Stage

Tis (Carcinoma in situ)

TURBT (Transurethral Resection of Bladder Tumor)

  • May be used for initial diagnosis and tumor resection if not already performed

Intravesical BCG

  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Weekly for 3 weeks at months 3, 6, 12, 18, 24, 30, and 36

Continue BCG Maintenance Therapy

  • Up to 3 years

Ta (Non-muscle invasive)

TURBT

  • Complete resection of tumor

Low-risk:

  • Single Instillation (SI) of Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine, mitomycin)
  • SI within 24 hours of TURBT
  • Alternative: Continuous saline bladder irrigation

Intermediate-risk:

  • Intravesical Chemotherapy (e.g., gemcitabine)
  • Induction: 6 weekly courses
  • Maintenance: Up to 1 year

T1 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- For initial diagnosis and tumor debulking

High-risk:

  • Intravesical BCG
  • Induction: Weekly for 6 weeks
  • Maintenance: Up to 3 years

Consider Cystectomy

  • If BCG is not tolerated or ineffective- Alternative: Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

T2 (Muscle invasive)

TURBT- May be used for tumor resection and staging

Initial Treatment:

  • Consider Cystectomy
  • Alternatively, Trimodality therapy (TURBT + Chemoradiation)

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Depending on response and tumor characteristics

T3 (Advanced muscle invasive)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy with possible neoadjuvant chemotherapy

TURBT - Often not performed if cystectomy is planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Based on pathology and staging
  • Neoadjuvant therapy may continue

T4 (Locally advanced)

Initial Treatment:

  • Cystectomy
  • Neoadjuvant Chemotherapy, if not yet administered

TURBT- Typically avoided if cystectomy and neoadjuvant therapy are planned

Adjuvant Therapy:

  • Additional chemotherapy or radiation based on residual disease and staging

questions.text: Identify the type of marked chromosome in the given karyotype.
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Acrocentric

Explanation:

  • An acrocentric chromosome has the centromere located near one end, resulting in a long arm and a very short (or almost nonexistent) short arm. Human chromosomes 13, 14, 15, 21, and 22 are acrocentric. Acrocentric chromosomes are characterized by having satellites or small structures called stalks attached to their short arms, which contain multiple copies of ribosomal RNA genes.

 

Metacentric (Option B) chromosome has the centromere located approximately in the middle, resulting in two arms of roughly equal length. Human chromosomes 1, 3, 16, 19, and 20 are metacentric.

Submetacentric (Option C) chromosome has the centromere slightly off-center, resulting in one arm being longer than the other. Human chromosomes 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12, 17, and 18 are submetacentric

Telocentric(Option D) A telocentric chromosome has the centromere at one end, resulting in a chromosome that has only one arm. Humans do not have telocentric chromosomes, but they are found in some species such as mice.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true?

1. Due to increasing mammography there occurs over diagnosis of breast carcinoma

2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination

3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection

4. Cervix cancer screening is done by a pap smear
questions.solution:
Correct answer D) 1, 3, 4

Explanation:

Explanation of Each Statement:

Statement

True/False

Explanation

1. Due to increasing mammography, there occurs overdiagnosis of breast carcinoma.

True

Widespread mammography detects early-stage cancers and indolent tumors, leading to overdiagnosis and possibly unnecessary treatments.

2. Colon cancer screening is done by digital rectal examination (DRE).

False

DRE alone is NOT an effective screening test for colon cancer. Preferred tests are colonoscopy, fecal occult blood test (FOBT), and fecal immunochemical test (FIT).

3. Oral cancer screening is done by visual inspection.

True

Oral cancer screening involves visual examination and palpation of the oral mucosa, especially in high-risk individuals (e.g., smokers, betel nut chewers).

4. Cervical cancer screening is done by a Pap smear.

True

Pap smear (Papanicolaou test) detects cervical dysplasia and early-stage cancer, making it the gold standard screening test. HPV testing is also recommended in some guidelines.

Thus, Option D is correct.

questions.text: How does RNAi impact gene expression?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Knockdown

Explanation:

  • RNAi primarily functions through mRNA degradation and inhibiting protein synthesis, with applications in gene manipulation and therapy.

RNA Interference (RNAi)

  • Definition: Biological process where double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) silences specific gene expressions.
  • Mechanisms:
    • Degradation of messenger RNA (mRNA) molecules corresponding to the target gene.
    • Reduction of expression levels of the target gene.
  • Applications:
    • Tool in genetic research and biotechnology for gene knockdown.
    • Understanding gene function.
    • Developing therapeutic strategies.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is accurate for measuring the nasogastric tube?

choices.text: Tip of nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum
Angle of mouth to tragus to xiphisternum
Ala of nose to angle of mandible to xiphisternum
Angle of mouth to ear lobule to umbilicus

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tip of nose to ear lobule to xiphisternum

Explanation:

  • The correct method for measuring a nasogastric tube involves measuring the distance from the tip of the patient's nose to the ear lobule and then down to the xiphisternum, which is the lower end of the sternum. This measurement helps determine the appropriate length of the nasogastric tube that needs to be inserted.

Nasogastric (NG) Tubes:

  • Inserted through the nose and passed into the stomach
  • Larger in diameter (typically 14-18 French)
  • Common markings:
    • Measurement markings in centimeters to indicate the insertion depth
    • 'STOMACH' printed on the tube to confirm correct placement

Indications:

  • Decompression of the stomach (e.g., in intestinal obstruction)
  • Enteral feeding in adults and older children
  • Medication administration

questions.text: A primigravida is in labour. Her per-vaginal examination revealed a posterior cervix with 5 cm cervical length, 1 cm dilatation, soft consistency, and head at -1 station. Calculate the modified Bishop score.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 5

Explanation: The Modified Bishop score of the given patient is calculated to be 5.

Based on the given information:

  • Cervical dilation: 1 cm → 1 point
  • Cervical length: 5 cm→ 0 points
  • Cervical consistency: Soft → 2 points
  • Position: Posterior → 0 points
  • Fetal station: -1 → 2 point

Total Score = 1 (dilation) + 0 (cervical length) + 2 (consistency) + 0 (position) + 2 (station) = 5

Modified Bishop score is calculated as:

Criteria

0 Points

1 Point

2 Points

3 Points

Dilation (cm)

Closed

1-2

3-4

≥5

Cervical length

4 cm

2-4 cm

1-2 cm

<1cm

Station

-3

-2

-1, 0

+1, +2

Consistency

Firm

Medium

Soft

 

Position

Posterior

Mid position

Anterior

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Total Score: The sum of points from all five criteria.

Interpretation:

  • ≤6: Unfavorable cervix (Cervical ripening agents may be necessary)
  • ≥9: Favorable cervix for induction (high likelihood of successful induction)

questions.text: A 42-year-old man who was under home isolation after testing positive for COVID-19 develops breathing difficulty and is brought to the ER. The patient is alert and responsive but is breathing rapidly. SpO2 is measured to be 86%. He is administered oxygen via a face mask with a reservoir bag with a flow rate of 10 L/min. After a trial of one hour, his SpO2 is 88%. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) High-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy

Explanation:

  • In this scenario, the patient is experiencing hypoxemia with a SpO₂ of 86% despite receiving oxygen via a non-rebreather mask at 10 L/min for one hour, resulting in only a slight improvement to 88%.
  • This indicates inadequate oxygenation and suggests the need for more effective respiratory support.
  • The most appropriate next step is to initiate high-flow nasal cannula oxygen therapy to improve oxygenation and reduce the work of breathing.

High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) / High-Flow Humidified Nasal Cannula (HFHNC):

  • It works by delivering warmed & humidified gas, preventing nasal mucosa drying, and overcoming the limitations of traditional cannulas.
  • Provide flows up to 60 L/min, allowing for accurate delivery of high FiO2 levels
  • Generates positive airway pressures of over 5 cm H2O, making it a potential substitute for low-level CPAP (Conitinous Positive Airway Pressure).
  • Can deliver 100% FiO2

  • Advantages:
    • Better tolerance compared to traditional face masks, allowing for greater comfort during oxygen therapy.
    • Accurate delivery of high FiO2 in various clinical situations.
    • Improved mortality rates in patients experiencing acute hypoxemic respiratory failure due to Sepsis and SARS-CoV-2 infection.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Higher cost compared to standard oxygen delivery devices.
    • Limited availability outside of critical care settings

Incorrect Options:

Increase flow rate to 15 L/min (Option A):

  • May provide a small improvement in oxygenation.
  • However, given that the patient's SpO2 only improved from 86% to 88% after one hour of oxygen therapy at 10 L/min, a further increase in flow rate alone is unlikely to be sufficient.

Endotracheal intubation (Option C) is a more invasive procedure typically reserved for patients with severe respiratory distress who cannot maintain adequate oxygenation or ventilation despite non-invasive interventions.

No specific intervention is necessary (Option D): After an hour of oxygen therapy, the patient's SpO2 is still below the target range, indicating that a specific intervention is required to improve oxygenation.
