questions.text:
Which of the following structures are incised by a surgeon during an appendectomy performed initially with a gridiron incision?

1. External oblique

2. Internal oblique

3. Transversus abdominis

4. Rectus abdominis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

A gridiron incision (also known as McBurney's incision) is a muscle-splitting incision used for an open appendectomy. The incision is made at McBurney's point (one-third of the way from the anterior superior iliac spine to the umbilicus).

Layers Incised in a Gridiron Incision:

  1. Skin & Subcutaneous tissue
  2. External oblique aponeurosis → Incised
  3. Internal oblique muscle →Split along its fibers (NOT cut transversely)
  4. Transversus abdominis muscle → Split along its fibers
  5. Transversalis fascia & Peritoneum → Opened to access the appendix

Why Not Rectus Abdominis?

  • Rectus abdominis is NOT involved because the gridiron incision is made in the right lower quadrant, where the rectus abdominis does not extend laterally.
  • If a paramedian or midline incision were used, rectus abdominis would be involved

questions.text: What is the dose of carbetocin used in the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 100 mcg

Explanation: The correct dosage of carbetocin for the prevention of postpartum hemorrhage is 100 mcg. Carbetocin is a synthetic analogue of oxytocin, used in obstetrics to reduce the risk of postpartum hemorrhage due to its long-lasting effects.

Drugs used in PPH:

Drug/Treatment

Dosage/Administration

Key Notes

Oxytocin (IV)

10-20 units in drip
  • Drug of choice for uterine atony
  • Never give undiluted bolus dose (causes hypotension and arrhythmias)
  • Oxytocin overdose causes water intoxication

Carbetocin

100 mcg in 1 ml IV over 1 min
  • Synthetic analogue of oxytocin, more sustained release
  • Onset: 2 mins, lasts 1 hour (compared to oxytocin's onset of 5 mins and lasts 20 mins)
  • Equivalent to 16 hrs of oxytocin drip

Methylergometrine

0.2 mg IV (also IM, IV acts faster)
  • Peak action in 90 seconds
  • Can be given IM, but IV acts faster

Misoprostol (PGE1)

1000 μg per rectum or 200-400 μg sublingually
  • Prostaglandin used for postpartum hemorrhage
  • Effective for uterine contraction

Carboprost (PGFα)

250 μg IM only
  • Never given IV (causes sudden hypertension)
  • Can be administered intra-myometrial
  • Used when other drugs are ineffective

Tranexamic Acid

1 gm IV
  • Anti-fibrinolytic agent
  • Helps prevent bleeding by inhibiting fibrinolysis

Fibrinogen

Maintain >100 mg/dl
  • For maintaining fibrinogen levels
  • Can be administered as 10 units of cryoprecipitate or 1 litre of fresh frozen plasma (FFP)

questions.text: Which of the following methods cannot be used to precipitate proteins?

choices.text: Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

Explanation:

  • At the isoelectric pH, proteins are least soluble because they have no net charge. This results in minimal repulsion between molecules, causing them to aggregate and precipitate. Hence, high solubility is not a characteristic of the isoelectric pH.

 

Add alcohol and acetone (Option A) Alkaloidal reagents are negatively charged. In an acidic medium, proteins are positively charged. So, by neutralization of charges, negative ion precipitates out.

Using heavy metals and ion (Option B) Neutralisation of charges occur which lead to precipitation of positive ion as heavy metals are positively charged.

Adding trichloroacetic acid (Option D) It is negatively charged. In an acidic medium, proteins are positively charged. So, neutralization of charges occurs and the negative ion is separated.

questions.text: Which of the statements below is correct?

choices.text: In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive
Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease
Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease
Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease

questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Positive predictive value depends on prevalence of disease

Explanation:

Positive Predictive Value (PPV):

  • It is the probability that individuals with a positive test result truly have the disease or condition of interest.
  • It indicates how well a test result predicts the presence of the disease.
  • Formula:

Negative Predictive Value (NPV):

  • It is the probability that individuals with a negative test result do not have the disease, reflecting the diagnostic power of a test to exclude disease correctly.
  • It indicates how well a negative test result predicts the absence of the disease.
  • Formula:

 

Incorrect Options:

In a population with low prevalence of the disease, positive result with a highly sensitive test means true positive (Option A):

  • In low disease prevalence, a positive result with a highly sensitive test doesn't always mean a true positive.

Sensitivity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option B):

  • Sensitivity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals with the disease.

Specificity depends on prevalence of the disease (Option D):

  • Specificity isn't influenced by disease prevalence; it measures a test's ability to identify individuals without the disease.

questions.text: What is the most frequent reason for hospital admission following daycare surgery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Postoperative nausea and vomiting

Explanation:

  • The most frequent reason for hospital admission following daycare surgery is: Postoperative nausea and vomiting

Daycare surgery:

  • Also known as same-day, outpatient, or ambulatory surgery, involves procedures where patients are admitted and discharged within a 12-hour period.

Key aspects:

  • Advantages:
    • Reduced healthcare costs due to elimination of overnight hospital stays.
    • Decreased risk of hospital-acquired infections.
    • Increased patient comfort and satisfaction by recovering at home.
  • Patient Selection Criteria:
    • Generally healthy individuals (ASA I or II).
    • Procedures with minimal anticipated postoperative complications.
    • Availability of a responsible adult at home for post-discharge care.
  • Common Procedures:
    • Carpal tunnel release.
    • Dental extractions.
  • Postoperative Care:
    • Monitoring in a recovery area until anesthesia effects diminish.
    • Provision of discharge instructions, including signs of complications.
    • Scheduled follow-up appointments to ensure proper recovery.

In daycare (ambulatory) surgery, the most common postoperative complication: PONV

Postoperative Nausea and Vomiting (PONV):

Category

Details

Risk factors
  • Female gender
  • Non-smoker
  • History of PONV/motion sickness
  • Post-op opioid

Intra-op modifications
  • Use Propofol (antiemetic)
  • Use Nitrogen (N) instead of Nitrous Oxide (N₂O)
  • Use Remifentanil (least incidence of PONV)

Drug of Choice
  • Ondansetron (4-8 mg)
  • Anticholinergics (e.g., Scopolamine)
  • Steroids (e.g., Dexamethasone)

questions.text: miRNA binds to which part of the mRNA to inhibit translation?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: B) 3'UTR

Explanation:

  • The miRNA along with the proteins forms the RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC complex) and binds to the 3’ end of the target mRNA to be degraded. Thus, miRNA is synthesized from DNA and it binds to 3’ UTR.

 

Gene body (Option A) gene has regulatory regions such as the promoter where the enzymes bind that initiate the transcription. Furthermore, a gene has a start and a stop site,

  • In between the start and stop site is the region that is transcribed into mRNA. This includes exons and introns. Introns and exons together are called the transcriptional region, or the gene body.

Gene promoter(Option B) It is present upstream to the operator site and serves as the initiation site where RNA polymerase binds to and initiates the transcription of certain genes.

5’ UTR(Option D) is the region of a messenger RNA (mRNA) that is directly upstream from the initiation codon. This region is important for the regulation of the translation of a transcript by differing mechanisms in viruses, prokaryotes, and eukaryotes. Also known as the operator gene.

questions.text: What is the frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 50 Hz

Explanation:

  • The frequency of tetanic stimulation used in neuromuscular monitoring is typically 50 Hz.
  • This frequency is used to deliver a rapid, sustained series of stimuli that can help evaluate the neuromuscular block.

Neuromuscular Monitoring:

Heading

Details

Definition

A monitor that assesses the effect of neuromuscular blockers on the neuromuscular junction.

What it monitors
  • Onset of blockade
  • Intensity of blockade
  • Reversal from blockade
  • Involves two electrodes attached along the course of the ulnar nerve.

Procedure
  • Stimulate the ulnar nerve.
  • Observe the response in the adductor pollicis muscle.
  • Assess contraction to determine the degree of neuromuscular junction blockade.

Common site

Ulnar nerve

Principle

Supramaximal electrical stimulus is given to an accessible peripheral nerve (e.g., ulnar nerve), and the response is observed in the corresponding muscle group.

Types of Stimulus Given
  • Single twitch
  • Train of four (TOF): Most common; 4 stimuli delivered at 2 Hz
  • Tetanic stimulus: Continuous stimulus at 50 Hz
  • Double burst stimulation

Post-Tetanic count
  • Counting of responses to single twitch stimulation after tetanic stimulation at 50 Hz or 100 Hz for 5 seconds.
  • Indicates profound neuromuscular blockade if post-tetanic count is less than 5.

Patterns of Nerve Stimulation for the evaluation of the neuromuscular function:

Stimulation Pattern

Mechanism

Interpretation

Clinical Implication and Limitation

Single-Twitch Stimulation

Single electrical stimulus applied at a frequency of 0.1 Hz to 1 Hz.
  • Requires comparison to pre-NMBA administration value.
  • Muscle response to the stimulus reflects neuromuscular block onset; changes in twitch height help assess blockade.
  • Used to evaluate onset of neuromuscular block.
  • Limited utility as a standalone test.

Train-of-Four (TOF) Stimulation


 

Four supramaximal stimuli delivered at 0.5-second intervals (2 Hz).
  • Fade between responses indicates degree of block.
  • TOF count assesses onset.
  • TOF ratio measures recovery.
  • Fade suggests nondepolarizing block.
  • Most common pattern for intraoperative monitoring.
  • Cannot measure deep block or phase I block.

Double-Burst Stimulation (DBS)


 

Two bursts of 50-Hz stimulation with a 750-ms interval.
  • Fade between the two bursts indicates block.
  • Fade between bursts correlates with TOF ratio.
  • DBS is more sensitive for detecting fade.

Better tactile detection of residual block than TOF but cannot reliably assess recovery at higher TOF ratios.

Tetanic Stimulation

High-frequency stimulation (50-100 Hz for 5 seconds) causing sustained muscle contraction.

Fade indicates nondepolarizing block; sustained response suggests normal transmission or depolarizing block.
  • Painful and limited use in practice.
  • May cause lasting muscle antagonism, affecting recovery assessment.

Post Tetanic Count (PTC) Stimulation


 

Tetanic stimulation (50 Hz for 5 seconds) followed by single twitches at 1 Hz after 3 seconds.

Counts discernible twitches after tetanic stimulation; assesses deep block not detectable by TOF.
  • Used for monitoring deep neuromuscular blockade.
  • Requires 6-minute intervals, limiting continuous use.

questions.text: What is the maximum rate of oxygen flow that can be maintained using a traditional oxygen mask?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 10 L/min

Explanation:

  • A conventional oxygen mask, also known as a simple face mask, is a device used for oxygen delivery to patients who require supplemental oxygen.
    • The mask covers the nose and mouth, allowing the patient to breathe in a mixture of oxygen and room air.
    • The maximum oxygen flow rate that can be delivered with a conventional oxygen mask is typically around 10 L/min.
    • This flow rate ensures that a sufficient amount of oxygen is delivered to the patient, maintaining an adequate oxygen concentration or fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2).
    • Higher flow rates may not significantly increase the delivered oxygen concentration and may lead to discomfort for the patient.

Type of mask

Nasal Prong

Face Mask (Simple face mask)

NRBM

Flow rate

1 to 6 L

6 to 10 L

10 to 15 L

FiO2

25 to 45%

35 to 60%

65 to 95 %

questions.text: In conventional oxygen therapy, which device will deliver the highest FiO2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) High Flow Nasal Cannula

Explanation:

  • High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) therapy is a mode of respiratory support that delivers a high flow of heated and humidified oxygen-enriched air through nasal prongs to patients with respiratory distress.
  • Can deliver 100% FiO2

1. High-Flow Devices: High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC), Venturi mask

2. Low-Flow Devices: Nasal Prongs, Simple Face Mask, Non-Rebreather Mask (NRBM)

Low-Flow Devices:

Type of mask

Nasal Prong

Face Mask (Hudson mask)

(Option B)

NRBM

(Option C)

Flow rate

1 to 6 L

6 to 10 L

10 to 15 L

FiO2

25 to 45%

35 to 60%

65 to 95 %
 


High-Flow Devices: High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC), Venturi mask

High-Flow Nasal Cannula (HFNC) / High-Flow Humidified Nasal Cannula (HFHNC):

  • It works by delivering warmed & humidified gas, preventing nasal mucosa drying and overcoming the limitations of traditional cannulas.
  • Provide flows up to 60 L/min, allowing for accurate delivery of high FiO2 levels
  • Generates positive airway pressures of over 5 cm H2O, making it a potential substitute for low-level CPAP (Conitinous Positive Airway Pressure).
  • Can deliver 100% Fio2.

Venturi Mask: (Option A) is also a high-flow device with fixed performance that delivers a precise concentration of oxygen (FiO₂) by mixing oxygen with ambient air at specific flow rates, typically ranging from 2 to 15 L/min. It is often used in patients requiring controlled oxygen therapy, such as those with COPD.

questions.text: How long should elective surgery be deferred for a patient who had a cough and fever, after he has recovered from COVID-19, and has not required any hospitalization?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6 weeks

Explanation:

  • For a patient who has recovered from COVID-19 and has not required hospitalization, elective surgery should typically be deferred for 6 weeks.
  • Studies suggest that performing surgery within 6 weeks of a COVID-19 diagnosis may be associated with increased postoperative complications. Delaying surgery beyond this period can reduce such risks.

Time since COVID-19 infection

Recommendation

Less than 2 Weeks

Elective surgeries should not occur within two weeks of a COVID-19 infection, allowing anesthesiologists and surgeons to assess the severity of the patient's symptoms and reduce unnecessary risk of transmitting the infection to healthcare professionals.

2 to 7 Weeks

Between two and seven weeks after the patient's COVID-19 infection, anesthesiologists and surgeons should conduct a risk assessment, considering factors such as age, comorbidities, severity of the infection, and surgical risk. If the patient and surgery are determined to be low risk, the procedure may be scheduled during this period after thorough discussion and shared decision-making with the patient.

More than 7 Weeks

Delay of the surgery beyond seven weeks should be considered if the patient continues to have COVID-19 symptoms or other health concerns that may increase the risk of proceeding with surgery.

Incorrect Options:

8-10 weeks (Option B):

  • Delaying elective surgery for 8-10 weeks post-COVID-19 recovery may further reduce postoperative risks, especially in patients with persistent symptoms or those who had severe infections.
     

12 weeks (Option C):

  • While a 12-week delay might be considered for patients with severe or prolonged symptoms, current guidelines do not universally recommend such an extended delay for all patients.
     

4 weeks (Option D):

  • Undergoing elective surgery within 4 weeks of a COVID-19 diagnosis is generally associated with higher risks of postoperative complications. A minimum delay of 6-7 weeks is recommended to mitigate these risks.

questions.text: A patient presented with severe watery diarrhea resembling rice water stools. Damage to which structure is most likely responsible for this diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Zona Occludens

Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of severe rice watery diarrhea is indicative of Cholera.

Junctions and their function:

In epithelial cells, junctions are organized in a specific pattern from the apical to the basal surface.

  • At the apical region, the cell membranes fuse to form a tight junction (zonula occludens), which encircles the cells.
  • Below this is the zonula adherens, where proteins link to the cytoskeleton of both cells, separated by a small intercellular space with adhesion proteins.
  • Further down is a desmosome, a spotlike structure with attachment proteins connecting the cells.

The sequence of junctions from apical to basal is:

  1. Tight junctions (Zonula occludens)
  2. Adherens junctions (Zonula adherens)
  3. Desmosomes (Macula adherens)
  4. Gap junctions
  5. Hemidesmosomes

 

  

 

 

Functions:

  • Tight junctions (Zonula occludens) (Option A): Found in epithelia of the stomach, intestines, and bladder, these prevent the passage of substances between cells by fusing membranes with claudin proteins.
  • Zonula adherens (Option C ruled out): Links adjacent cells through cytoskeleton attachments, reinforced by actin filaments.
  • Desmosomes: Seen in skin and cardiac muscle, they prevent cell separation under mechanical stress by anchoring to intermediate filaments.
  • Hemidesmosomes (Option D ruled out): at the base of epithelial cells, anchoring them to the basement membrane and connective tissue.
  • Gap junctions (Option B ruled out): Channels (connexons) between cells allowing molecular and electrical communication, crucial for cardiac muscle and nerve function.

Cholera MOA:

Mechanism of Action

  • Mucus Crossing: Hemagglutinin-protease cleaves mucus and fibronectin.
  • Epithelial Adhesion: Toxin coregulated pilus (TCP) helps the bacteria adhere to the epithelial surface without invading or damaging cells, remaining attached throughout the infection.

Enterotoxin

  • Structure: Consists of one A (active) subunit and five B (binding) subunits.
  • Dissociation in Enterocytes:
    • A subunit splits into A1 and A2 fragments.
    • A1 Fragment Action: Activates cellular adenylate cyclase, leading to increased cyclic AMP (cAMP) levels. This results in an outflow of large quantities of water and electrolytes into the intestinal lumen, causing watery diarrhea.
  • Receptor Binding: B subunits attach to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the surface of jejunal epithelial cells.

Clinical Features

  • Stool Characteristics: "Rice water" stools with a mild sweet odor.
  • Diarrhea Progression: Initially mild diarrhea and vomiting, rapidly progressing to sudden massive diarrhea.
  • Electrolyte Imbalance: Hypokalemia, base-deficit acidosis.
  • Shock: Due to fluid loss and electrolyte imbalance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient who underwent a tooth extraction three days ago presents with a submandibular mass. The lesion is asymptomatic, and on drainage, the discharge is foul-smelling with yellow granules. What is the most likely implicated pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Actinomyces israelii

Explanation:

  • The patient had a recent tooth extraction, and the subsequent mass in the submandibular region suggests an infection spreading from the oral cavity. Actinomyces israelii is a commensal bacterium in the oral flora, and it can cause infection when there is a breach in the mucosal barrier, such as after dental procedures or trauma. The presence of foul-smelling discharge and yellow granules is a characteristic finding in actinomycosis.

Features

Actinomycetes

Acid-fastness

Nonacid-fast

O2 Requirement

Anaerobe

Habitat
  • Found as oral flora
  • Infections occur endogenously

Risk factors

Immunocompetent also

Clinical forms

Cervicofascial, abdominal, and others.

Granules

Yellow Sulfur granules are hard and not emulsifiable, consist of branching filamentous bacilli, and are surrounded by clubs (sun-ray appearance)

Culture
  • Spidery molar teeth colony in solid media
  • Fluffy ball at the bottom of the liquid medium

Treatment

Penicillin

Incorrect Options:

Fonsecaea Pedrosoi (Option A) causes chromoblastomycosis, a chronic, granulomatous infectious skin disease also known as verrucous dermatitis seen in barefoot walkers.

Mucor (Option B) causes mucormycosis. It commonly causes pneumonia, sinusitis, and CNS infection in immunocompromised people.

Histoplasma Capsulatum (Option D) causes Histoplasmosis from bat or bird droppings. Histoplasmosis commonly causes pneumonia and meningitis in immunocompromised people.

questions.text: Identify the correct ‘organism-drug to which it is intrinsically resistant’ pair:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Candida Krusei - Fluconazole

  • Among the given options, Candida krusei is intrinsically resistant to fluconazole.

Antifungal Drug Classes and their Resistance:

Drug Class

Examples of Clinically Used Drugs

Mechanism of Action

Mechanism of Acquired Resistance

Species with Intrinsic or High Rates of Resistance

Azoles

Fluconazole, Voriconazole, Posaconazole

Inhibition of ergosterol biosynthesis

Increased efflux pump activity, ERG11 mutations, CYP51 promoter mutations

Candida glabrata, Candida krusei, Candida auris, Aspergillus fumigatus (Option B)

Echinocandins

Caspofungin, Micafungin, Anidulafungin

Inhibition of β-1,3-glucan synthase

Mutations in hot-spot regions of FKS genes

Cryptococcus spp., Fusarium spp.

Polyenes

Amphotericin B

Ergosterol sequestration

Decreased membrane ergosterol, ERG mutations

Candida auris, Aspergillus terreus

Aspergillus niger - Voriconazole (Option A): Aspergillus niger is typically susceptible to voriconazole and does not show intrinsic resistance to this drug.

Candida albicans - Amphotericin B (Option C): Candida albicans is usually susceptible to amphotericin B. Resistance to this drug, if present, is acquired rather than intrinsic.

questions.text: Which of the given statements accurately reflects the characteristics of trematodes?

choices.text: Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles
Fasciola hepatica is not acquired through contaminated water
Triclabendazole is the treatment of choice for all trematode infections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fasciola hepatica are seen in the intrahepatic biliary radicles

Explanation:

Fasciola Hepatica

  • Fasciola hepatica, commonly known as the liver fluke, is a parasitic trematode (flatworm) that primarily infects the livers of various mammals, including humans. It causes the disease fascioliasis, leading to liver damage, biliary obstruction, and inflammatory reactions.

Morphology

Adult Fluke:

 

  • Shape: Leaf-shaped, flat, and broad.
  • Size: Approximately 2-3 cm in length and 1 cm in width.
  • Color: Typically brown or grey.
  • Distinctive Features:
    • Cone-shaped anterior end.
    • Two suckers, an oral sucker at the front and a ventral sucker close to it, used for attachment to host tissues.
    • The fluke’s body is covered by a tegument (a protective outer layer) with spines aiding in attachment.

Eggs:

 

  • Size: Large, oval, and approximately 130-150 µm in length.
  • Color: Yellowish-brown.
  • Characteristics:
    • Each egg has an operculum (a lid-like structure) at one end, which opens to release the miracidium (the larval stage).
    • Eggs are unembryonated when passed out in feces.

Life Cycle

 

  1. Eggs in Water
    • Eggs are expelled in the feces of infected mammals (definitive hosts).
    • Under suitable environmental conditions, miracidia are released from eggs after 9–15 days.
  2. Infection of Snails (Intermediate Host)
    • Miracidia penetrate specific freshwater snails, such as Lymnaea spp.
    • Inside the snail, they progress through stages: sporocyst, redia, and eventually cercaria.
  3. Release and Encystment
    • Cercariae exit the snail and encyst on aquatic vegetation, transforming into metacercariae, the infective stage.
  4. Infection of Mammals (Definitive Host)
    • Mammals, including humans, become infected by consuming contaminated water or vegetation with metacercariae.
    • In the duodenum, metacercariae excyst, penetrate the intestinal wall, migrate to the liver, and lodge in the bile ducts, maturing into adult flukes.

Clinical Presentation

Acute Phase (Invasive or Hepatic Stage):

  • Duration: Begins about 2-3 weeks post-infection and may last for several months.
  • Symptoms:
    • Fever, right upper quadrant abdominal pain.
    • Hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), and occasionally jaundice.
    • Nausea, vomiting, and weight loss.
    • Eosinophilia (elevated eosinophil count in blood).

Chronic Phase (Biliary Stage):

  • Duration: Occurs months to years post-infection.
  • Symptoms:
    • Biliary colic, obstructive jaundice, and cholangitis (inflammation of the bile ducts).
    • Gallbladder symptoms, liver abscesses, and secondary bacterial infections in severe cases.
    • Possible fibrosis of the bile ducts with prolonged infection.

Investigations

  1. Serology:
    • ELISA for detection of anti-Fasciola antibodies (sensitive in both acute and chronic infections).
    • Immunoblotting can also confirm the diagnosis.
  2. Stool Examination:
    • Microscopic detection of eggs in stool samples; however, eggs are typically not present in the acute phase and may be difficult to detect in chronic cases.
  3. Imaging:
    • Ultrasound: Useful in detecting hepatobiliary abnormalities such as bile duct dilation or liver abscesses.
    • CT/MRI: May show liver lesions or track the migration of larvae in the liver.
  4. Blood Tests:
    • Eosinophilia is common in the acute phase.
    • Liver function tests: Elevated liver enzymes, especially in chronic disease.

Management

Antiparasitic Treatment:

  • Triclabendazole: The drug of choice, effective against both adult and larval stages. Dosage: Oral dose of 10-12 mg/kg, with a repeat dose after 12 hours if needed.

Alternative Medications:

  • Bithionol: Sometimes used if triclabendazole is unavailable.

Incorrect Options:

Schistosoma are Monoecious (Option B) Schistosoma is dioecious, i.e., males and females are separate.

Fasciola Hepatica is not acquired through Contaminated Water (Option C) Fasciola hepatica is primarily acquired through ingestion of contaminated water or food that contains metacercariae, the infective stage of the fluke.

Triclabendazole is the Treatment of Choice for all Trematode Infections (Option D) While triclabendazole is an effective treatment for Fasciola hepatica infections, it is not the treatment of choice for all trematode infections. Other medications, such as praziquantel, are commonly used for the treatment of various trematode infections, including schistosomiasis.

questions.text:
An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. X-ray spine showed osteolytic lesions. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?


	Hb - 6.9g/dl
	WBC 4000/cm3 with normal differential count
	Serum calcium 13mg/dl
	Creatinine 2.3mg/dl
	Total protein 9g/dl
	Albumin 2.4g/dl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Multiple myeloma

  • The clinical scenario of an elderly woman with confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain, along with hypercalcemia, renal failure (elevated creatinine), anemia, osteolytic lesions (CRAB features), hypoalbuminemia, and elevated total proteins, points towards the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

Multiple Myeloma (MM):

  • Malignant disorder characterized by proliferation of a single clone of plasma cells derived from β-cells in the bone marrow.
  • It is the second most common adult hematological malignancy.
  • Most common cancer with skeletal components as its primary site.

Investigations of Multiple myeloma:

  • Hematological Analysis:
    • It may reveal anemia; ESR is usually elevated.
    • Rare cases of plasma cell leukemia with high plasma cell counts >2000 plasma cells/μL.
    • Serum calcium and urea nitrogen may be elevated.
    • Serum alkaline phosphatase is usually normal.
    • Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation
  • A/G ratio: Decreased
    • Increased level of β2 microglobulin.
    • Decreased albumin
  • Renal function test: Increased serum creatinine and uric acid.
  • Imaging:
    • Chest and bone radiographs: Lytic lesions/diffuse osteopenia
    • MRI: Extent of bone marrow infiltration and cord or root compression in patients with pain syndrome
    • PET/CT: Assess bone damage, extramedullary sites of the disease
  • Anion gap: (Na+ + K+) – (Cl- + HCO3-): Decreased
  • Serum or urine electrophoresis: M spike
  • Serum light chain assay: Increased
  • Immunofixation: Detects subtypes of light chain.
  • 24-hour urine specimen: Bence Jones protein (serum-free light chains) excretion
  • Fat pad biopsy: To detect amyloid deposits
  • Flow cytometry: CD 138+ (bone marrow plasma cells)
  • FISH:
    • Done to detect chromosomal abnormalities
    • Chromosome 17 deletion and translocation leads to poor prognosis.
  • Bone marrow biopsy: Plasmacytosis >10%

Clinicopathologic diagnosis of multiple myeloma is based on the following:

  • Clonal plasma cells in bone marrow
  • Presence of CRAB criteria (hypercalcemia, renal dysfunction, anemia and bone lesions)

Metastatic breast cancer (Option A): While metastatic breast cancer can involve bones and cause hypercalcemia, the presence of monoclonal gammopathy (elevated total protein) and anemia strongly favors multiple myeloma.

Primary hyperparathyroidism (Option C) is typically characterized by hypercalcemia and low phosphorus but does not cause anemia, monoclonal gammopathy, hypoalbuminemia, or osteolytic bone lesions.

Milk-alkali syndrome (Option D) arises from excessive intake of calcium and alkali (often in the form of calcium supplements or vitamin D). It results in hypercalcemia, alkalosis, nephrocalcinosis, and nephrolithiasis, none of which are evident in this patient.

questions.text:
As per the verbal autopsy report 2010-2013, arrange the most common cause of death among 1-4-year-old children in descending order:

. Diarrhea

2. Pneumonia

3. Malaria

4. Injuries
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) 2>1>4>3

Explanation:

  • Pneumonia: Leading cause of death in children aged 1-4 years, particularly where healthcare and vaccination are limited.
  • Diarrhea: Common cause of childhood mortality, worsened by inadequate water, sanitation, and healthcare.
  • Injuries: Also a leading cause of child mortality, including accidents and trauma, though slightly less common than pneumonia, diarrhea, and malaria.
  • Malaria: Significant cause of death in areas with high mosquito-borne malaria prevalence, especially risky for young children.

questions.text:
During the discharge of a COVID patient who was treated with steroids and remdesivir, which of the following will you inform him about?


	Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge
	Watch for the persistence of Anosmia
	Watch for headache and nasal discharge
	Monitor glucose levels
	Watch for Sinusitis like symptoms
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 3, 4 and 5

  • Patients treated with steroids and remdesivir for COVID-19 require careful monitoring during discharge. It is crucial to monitor glucose levels (4) because steroids can cause hyperglycemia. Additionally, watching for sinusitis-like symptoms (5), including headache and nasal discharge (3), is important due to the increased incidence of mucormycosis in COVID-19 patients.

Revised Discharge Policy for COVID-19:

  • Mild Cases of COVID-19:
    • Discharge criteria:
      • At least 7 days have passed since testing positive.
      • No fever for 3 successive days.
    • No testing is required prior to discharge.
  • Moderate Cases Admitted to Dedicated COVID Health Centre
    • Patients with resolved signs/symptoms and saturation >93% for 3 successive days:
      • Discharge after resolution of symptoms and maintaining saturation above 93% for 3 successive days (without oxygen support).
      • Stable comorbidities, if any, are required.
      • No testing is required prior to discharge.
    • Patients on oxygen with unresolved signs/symptoms and ongoing oxygen therapy demand:
      • Discharge only after the following criteria are met:
        • Resolution of clinical symptoms.
        • Ability to maintain prescribed oxygen saturation for 3 successive days without oxygen support.
        • Stable comorbidities, if any.
  • Severe Cases, Including Immunocompromised Patients (HIV, transplant recipients, malignancy, etc.)
    • Discharge will be based on clinical recovery.
    • The decision is at the discretion of the treating medical officer.

Repeat RT-PCR after 7 days of discharge (Option 1): This is not recommended under the updated COVID-19 discharge criteria.

Watch for persistence of anosmia (Option 2): Anosmia is a common post-COVID symptom that may persist for weeks to months in recovered patients. It is not considered a dangerous sign and does not require active monitoring during the discharge period.

questions.text: What does the point labeled C denote?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Onset of symptoms

  • The onset of symptoms marks the transition from subclinical disease to the clinical disease stage.

 

Incorrect Options:

Onset of pathological changes (Option B): Onset of pathological changes occurs before the subclinical stage

Usual time of diagnosis (Option C): Usual time of diagnosis varies and can happen at any stage.

Exposure to etiologic agent (Option D): Exposure to the etiologic agent precedes the subclinical stage.

questions.text: Which of the following is included in the Pentavalent vaccine?

choices.text: Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio
Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine
Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Diphtheria, Tetanus, HBV, Haemophilus influenza B, Pertussis

Explanation:

  • The pentavalent vaccine includes the following components:
    • Diphtheria
    • Tetanus
    • HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
    • Haemophilus influenza B (Hib)
    • Pertussis (Whooping Cough)
  • The pentavalent vaccine combines these five components into a single formulation to provide protection against these diseases.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, HBV, Injectable Polio: This option is incorrect because it includes "Injectable Polio" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

Option B - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Typhoid, HBV, Hib: This option is incorrect because it includes "Typhoid" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

Option C - Diphtheria, Pertussis, Tetanus, Haemophilus influenza B, Pneumococcal vaccine: This option is incorrect because it includes the "Pneumococcal vaccine" as one of the components of the pentavalent vaccine.

questions.text: A homogenous sample of 4 groups was taken as shown below. The height and weight of each group had a correlation coefficient of 0.6. What will be the total coefficient of correlation of the whole group?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Equal to 0.6

Explanation:

  • A correlation coefficient of 0.6 within each group indicates a positive relationship between height and weight.
  • If this relationship holds consistently across all groups, it suggests a strong positive correlation within the entire dataset.
  • This is depicted by tight clustering of data points along an upward-sloping trend line on the scatter plot.

The correlation coefficient is a statistical measure that describes the strength and direction of a relationship between two variables. It ranges from -1 to 1:

  • +1 means a perfect positive correlation (as one variable increases, the other also increases).
  • -1 means a perfect negative correlation (as one variable increases, the other decreases).
  • 0 means no correlation (no relationship between the variables).

 

Incorrect Options:

Less than 0.6 (Option B): If a positive correlation of 0.6 exists within each group, and it holds consistently across all groups, the total correlation for the entire dataset would be at least 0.6.

More than 0.6 (Option C): Total correlation might surpass 0.6, but without more details like group weights or sample sizes, we can't be sure.

Skewed coefficient of 0.6 (Option D): The term "skewed coefficient" typically refers to an asymmetrical distribution, not the correlation coefficient itself.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man suddenly developed right-sided weakness and aphasia within 2 hours. His BP recorded was 160/110mmHg and NCCT was clear. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - CT angiography to look for large vessel occlusion:

  • The clinical scenario of an older man presenting with acute onset right-sided weakness, aphasia, high blood pressure, and a clear non-contrast CT scan points toward the diagnosis of acute ischemic stroke. The next step is to perform CT angiography to identify large vessel occlusion, as this guides the decision for mechanical thrombectomy or thrombolysis.

Workup for stroke

Initial Assessment and Stabilization
  • Upon arrival, ensure the ABCs (Airway, Breathing, Circulation) are stable.
  • Blood glucose levels should be checked quickly to address hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia.

Determining Stroke Type: Imaging is Key
  • A non-contrast CT scan is the primary imaging modality for differentiating between ischemic and hemorrhagic strokes.
  • Clinical features may suggest stroke type, but imaging is essential for confirmation as no clinical finding can definitively differentiate between the two.

Further Investigations: Uncovering the Cause
  • Detailed History and Physical Exam: Consider risk factors (hypertension, diabetes, smoking, atrial fibrillation, etc.) and perform a neurological exam to localize the affected brain area.
  • Laboratory Tests: Perform CBC, electrolytes, renal function, blood glucose, lipid profile, coagulation studies, ESR, and ECG (to detect arrhythmias and signs of recent MI).

Visualizing the Cerebral Vasculature: Imaging Techniques
  • CT Angiography (CTA): Assesses cerebral vasculature and identifies blockages/stenosis, but is performed after non-contrast CT has ruled out hemorrhage (not for stroke type differentiation).
  • CT Perfusion Imaging: Assesses blood flow, identifying reduced perfusion and ischemic penumbra.
  • MRI: Provides more detail but takes longer than CT and is not as widely available, thus not the first imaging choice for acute stroke evaluation. (Option B)
  • MRA: Offers detailed images of blood vessels, similar to CTA.
  • Cerebral Angiography: Gold standard for vessel evaluation, used when other techniques are inconclusive or before endovascular intervention.
  • Ultrasound Techniques: Carotid Duplex Ultrasonography assesses carotid stenosis but is not a first-line acute imaging modality; Transcranial Doppler (TCD) measures blood flow velocity in intracranial arteries.

Tailoring Investigations Based on Stroke Type
  • Ischemic Stroke: Focuses on identifying the source of the blockage (cardioembolic, artery-to-artery embolic, small vessel disease).
  • Hemorrhagic Stroke: Investigations focus on identifying causes of bleeding (e.g., hypertension, aneurysm, vascular malformation).

 

Tablet labetalol 10 mg stat (Option C): Labetalol is a first-line antihypertensive in acute stroke management, especially to control elevated blood pressure. However, before administering any antihypertensive medication, the priority is to determine the presence of large vessel occlusion using CT angiography.

Thrombolysis (Option D) with alteplase is first-line therapy for acute ischemic stroke, but it is only effective if there is no large vessel occlusion. CT angiography is essential to assess for large vessel occlusion. If present, mechanical thrombectomy is preferred, making CT angiography a necessary first step before thrombolysis.

questions.text: For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient should have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs. This should include at least one:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Diuretic

  • For the diagnosis of resistant hypertension, the patient must have uncontrolled hypertension despite taking three antihypertensive drugs, including at least one diuretic. While calcium channel blockers, beta blockers, or alpha blockers can be part of the treatment regimen, the inclusion of a diuretic is essential to confirm the diagnosis of resistant hypertension.

Resistant Hypertension:

  • Refers to blood pressure persistently greater than 140/90 mmHg despite using three or more antihypertensive agents, including a diuretic.
  • Population at Risk: It is more common in individuals over 60 years old and those at higher cardiovascular risk.
  • Causes:
    • Nonadherence to therapy.
    • Secondary causes such as obesity, primary aldosteronism, and excessive alcohol intake.
    • Use of certain nonprescription or prescription drugs.
  • Evaluation:
    • Home blood pressure monitoring can help determine if office readings are accurate.
    • Secondary hypertension evaluation is recommended if no apparent cause of resistance is found.
  • Management: Mineralocorticoid receptor antagonists, particularly spironolactone, are effective as add-on therapies.

questions.text: Which mechanism is responsible for the inhibition of the acetylcholinesterase enzyme by organophosphorus compounds?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: C) Irreversible competitive inhibition

Explanation:

  • Organophosphorus compounds, such as certain pesticides and nerve agents, can irreversibly inhibit the activity of acetylcholinesterase (AChE
  • The inhibition caused by organophosphorus compounds is considered irreversible because these compounds form strong covalent bonds with the active site of the enzyme. They covalently bind to the serine residue within the active site of AChE, forming a stable complex that cannot be easily reversed or dissociated.

 

Reversible competitive inhibition (Option A) occurs when an inhibitor molecule competes with the substrate for binding to the active site of the enzyme.

Non-competitive inhibition (Option B) occurs when an inhibitor binds to a site on the enzyme other than the active site, altering its conformation and reducing its activity.

Suicidal inhibition (Option D) is another term used to describe the irreversible nature of inhibition caused by organophosphorus compounds. It refers to the fact that the inhibitor "kills" the enzyme by permanently modifying it, leading to its inactivation.

questions.text: Which vaccine is linked to the risk of intussusception when administered?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Rotavirus vaccine

Explanation:

  • The administration of the Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a small risk of intussusception.
  • The association between the Rotavirus vaccine and intussusception was first observed with an earlier version of the vaccine called RotaShield, which was withdrawn from the market in 1999.
  • Subsequent studies on newer rotavirus vaccines, such as RotaTeq and Rotarix, have found a small increased risk of intussusception following vaccination.

 

Incorrect Options:

Oral Polio vaccine (Option B): OPV is used to protect against polio and has not been found to have a significant association with intussusception.

Adenovirus vaccine (Option C): Intussusception is not a known side effect or risk associated with the administration of Adenovirus vaccines.

Measles vaccine (Option D): The Measles vaccine is not associated with an increased risk of intussusception.

questions.text: Which of the following substances is not characterized by amphipathicity?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Triglycerides

Explanation:

  • Triglycerides are not Amphipathicitic in nature.

Amphipathic Lipids:

  • Characteristics: Both hydrophobic and hydrophilic; contain a polar head group and a nonpolar tail.
  • Functions and Structures:
    • Membranes: Bilayer structure with hydrophobic tails inward and hydrophilic heads outward
    • Micelles: Spherical structures with hydrophobic tails in the center and hydrophilic heads on the surface; aid in fat digestion.
    • Liposomes: Spherical vesicles with lipid bilayers enclosing an aqueous compartment
    • Emulsions: Larger particles of nonpolar lipids dispersed in water, stabilized by amphipathic lipids; prevent coalescence.
  • Examples:
    • Phospholipids
    • Sphingolipids
    • Cholesterol

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)?

choices.text: Patient can be clinically euvolemic to hypervolemic

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

  • In SIADH, urinary sodium is typically > 40 mEq/L, not < 20 mEq/L, due to volume expansion and natriuresis.

Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone Secretion (SIADH)

Definition

Excessive ADH release leading to impaired water excretion and hyponatremia with euvolemia or hypervolemia. (Option D)

Etiology
  • CNS disturbances: Stroke, infection, subarachnoid hemorrhage, etc.
  • Malignancies: Small cell lung cancer (most common), other cancers.
  • Drugs: Carbamazepine, oxcarbazepine, SSRIs, "Ecstasy", NSAIDs, etc.
  • Surgery: Pain-induced ADH hypersecretion.
  • Pulmonary diseases: Pneumonia (Option A ruled out), respiratory failure, etc.
  • Hormone deficiency: Hypopituitarism, hypothyroidism.
  • HIV: Associated with infections.
  • Hereditary SIADH: V2 receptor mutation.

Pathophysiology
  • ADH function: Regulates water balance by controlling plasma osmolality; excess ADH causes water retention, leading to hyponatremia.
  • Volume regulation: In hypovolemia, ADH release is driven by volume receptors, worsening hyponatremia.

Clinical Presentation
  • Acute hyponatremia: Nausea, vomiting, headache, seizures, coma.
  • Chronic hyponatremia: Nonspecific symptoms (nausea, confusion, falls in elderly).

Diagnosis

Schwartz and Bartter Criteria:

  • Serum sodium <135 mEq/L (Option B)
  • Serum osmolality <275 mOsm/kg
  • Urine sodium >40 mEq/L
  • Urine osmolality >100 mOsm/kg (Option C)
  • The absence of clinical evidence of volume depletion (like normal skin turgor, blood pressure within the reference range)
  • The absence of hyponatremia due to other causes (like adrenal insufficiency, hypothyroidism, cardiac failure, pituitary insufficiency, renal disease with salt wastage, hepatic disease, drugs that impair renal water excretion.)

Tests:

  • Renal function, serum osmolality, cortisol levels, thyroid tests, imaging for underlying causes.

Management
  • Fluid restriction: For mild to moderate symptoms.
  • Hypertonic saline (3%): For severe hyponatremia, with careful correction rate (<8 mEq/L in 24 hrs).
  • Medications:
    • Vasopressin receptor antagonists (Conivaptan, Tolvaptan)
    • Other: Loop diuretics, salt tablets, demeclocycline, lithium.

Complications
  • Osmotic demyelination syndrome: Risk from rapid sodium correction.
  • Severe hyponatremia: Can lead to seizures, coma, and death in acute cases.

questions.text: What does the standardized age mortality ratio indicate?

choices.text: Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution
Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard sex distribution
Removal of bias due to different age group population in different countries
To eliminate age structure of different countries

questions.solution:
Correct Option: A) Death rate of a population adjusted to a standard age distribution

Explanation:

  • Standardized age mortality ratio adjusts death rates to a standard age distribution for fair comparisons.
  • Helps remove bias caused by differences in age structure when comparing mortality rates.
  • Calculates expected deaths in a population with the same age-specific death rates as a standard population.
  • Commonly used in epidemiology, public health, and demographic research for comparing mortality rates.

Types of Rate

Description

Examples

Crude Rates

Actual observed rates are calculated directly from raw data without adjustments.

Crude birth rate: Number of births / Total population * 1000

Specific Rates

Rates that focus on specific causes

Tuberculosis mortality rate: Deaths due to TB / Population at risk * 100,000

Standardised Rates

Rates are adjusted to account for differences in the composition of populations when comparing different groups or populations.

Age-standardized mortality rate.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B, C, and D do not accurately describe the purpose of standardized age mortality ratio.

questions.text: What factor is the external validity of a screening test associated with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Generalizability

Explanation:

External validity of a screening test is related to its generalizability, which determines if the test results can be applied to a broader population beyond the study sample.

 

Incorrect Options:

Stability (Option A): Stability refers to consistency over time.

Objectivity (Option B): Objectivity pertains to bias.

Repeatability (Option D): Repeatability concerns consistency within individuals.

questions.text: What is the repair mechanism associated with CRISPR-cas9?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Non-homologous end joining

Explanation:

  • CRISPR-Cas is a genome-editing tool that can be used to introduce specific genetic modifications, including gene knock-ins (adding new genetic material) and gene knock-outs (disrupting or deleting existing genes).

 

CRISPR-Cas Mechanism:

  • Guide RNA: Directs the Cas enzyme to the specific DNA sequence.
  • Cas Enzyme: Cuts the DNA at the target location.
  • DNA Repair:
    • NHEJ (Non-Homologous End Joining) (Option A): Repairs the break by directly ligating the DNA ends, often leading to gene knockout.
    • HDR (Homologous Directed Repair): Uses a template to repair the break accurately, allowing for gene knock-in.

 

Base excision repair (Option B) is a DNA repair mechanism that primarily deals with the repair of damaged or abnormal bases in the DNA molecule.

Nucleotide excision repair (Option C) is a DNA repair pathway that primarily deals with the removal and repair of bulky DNA lesions, such as UV-induced thymine dimers or certain chemical adducts.

Mismatch repair (Option D) is a DNA repair system that corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as mismatches or small insertions or deletions that can result in DNA loops.

questions.text: Treatment of choice for an acute attack of cluster headache is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Subcutaneous sumatriptan:

  • For an acute attack of cluster headache, the treatment of choice is 100% oxygen at 10-12 L/minute and subcutaneous sumatriptan.

Cluster Headache:

  • Rare primary headache, with a prevalence of ~0.1%, characterized by excruciating, nonfluctuating, retro-orbital pain of explosive quality.
  • Periodicity:
    • Attacks occur daily, with one or two short-duration, unilateral pain episodes lasting 15-180 minutes.
    • Cluster bouts last for weeks, followed by a pain-free interval, typically lasting less than a year.
    • Chronic cluster headache is defined by <3 months of sustained remission.
  • Symptoms:
    • Ipsilateral autonomic symptoms: Conjunctival injection, lacrimation, nasal congestion, and aural fullness.
    • Sympathetic dysfunction (e.g., ptosis)
    • Unilateral photophobia and phonophobia
  • Treatment of Acute Attack of Cluster Headache:
    • Oxygen: Inhaled 100% oxygen at 10-12 L/min for 15-20 minutes. (Option C & D)
    • Sumatriptan: Subcutaneous 6 mg is effective, reducing attack duration to 10-15 minutes.
    • Sumatriptan and Zolmitriptan Nasal Sprays: Effective alternatives for patients who prefer not to self-inject.
    • Noninvasive Vagus Nerve Stimulation (nVNS): FDA approved for episodic cluster headache; involves three 2-minute stimulation cycles at headache onset.

Oral sumatriptan (Option A) is not suitable for acute cluster headache attacks because it may not provide the same rapid relief as subcutaneous sumatriptan.

questions.text: What is the term used to describe the rise in the occurrence of non-communicable diseases observed in recent years?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Secular

Explanation:

  • In the context of health and disease patterns, a secular trend typically indicates a gradual and persistent increase or decrease in the incidence or prevalence of a particular condition over many years or decades.
  • In the given scenario, the increase in the incidence of non-communicable diseases over the past few years suggests a long-term and sustained change in the prevalence of these diseases. This pattern is consistent with a secular trend, as it indicates a significant shift in disease burden over an extended period of time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Seasonal (Option A): Seasonal trends refer to patterns that occur within a specific season or time of the year. Therefore, this option is not appropriate for the given scenario.

Cyclical (Option B): The scenario does not describe a cyclical pattern as the increase in non-communicable diseases is not occurring in a cyclic or predictable manner.

Periodic (Option C): The scenario does not suggest that the increase in non-communicable diseases is occurring at regular intervals or in a repeated fashion.

questions.text: What is the most effective study design to demonstrate the relationship between cause and effect among the options listed below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Cohort study

Explanation:

  • Cohort study is the best study design to demonstrate cause and effect relationships.
  • Reasons include:
  • Temporal sequence: Follows individuals over time, establishing exposure preceding outcome.
  • Exposure assessment: Collects detailed exposure information for accurate measurement.
  • Control for confounding: Includes measures to minimize influence of other factors.
  • Large sample size: Enhances statistical power and generalizability.
  • Long-term follow-up: Allows evaluation of short-term and long-term outcomes.

 

Incorrect Options:

Case control study (Option A): Case-control studies are retrospective and rely on recall, not ideal for establishing cause and effect.

Cross-sectional study (Option C): Cross-sectional studies provide snapshot but lack temporal sequence to establish causality.

Clinical trial (Option D): Clinical trials focus on specific treatments, may not address broader cause and effect relationships.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient with class II pulmonary hypertension presents with a negative vasoreactive test. Which of the following is used in the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B  - Ambrisentan

  • In patients with class II (low risk) pulmonary hypertension and a negative vasoreactive test, the next step in management is the use of ambrisentan, an endothelin receptor antagonist.

Vasoreactivity Testing in PAH:

  • Indication: Vasoreactivity testing is primarily reserved for patients with idiopathic or hereditary PAH.
  • Preferred Vasodilators: Short-acting vasodilators such as inhaled nitric oxide (NO) or inhaled epoprostenol are preferred for the test.
  • Positive Response: A decrease in mean pulmonary arterial pressure (mPAP) by ≥10 mmHg to an absolute level of ≤40 mmHg without a decrease in cardiac output (CO) is considered a positive vasoreactivity response.
  • Treatment for Responders:
    • Patients with a positive vasoreactivity response are considered for long-term treatment with calcium channel blockers (nifedipine, diltiazem or amlodipine). (Option C)
  • Negative Vasoreactivity: Treatment approach depends on clinical risk.
    • Low- or Intermediate-Risk Patients (class II, III): Initial treatment includes combination oral therapy, typically involving an endothelin receptor antagonist (ambrisentan, sitaxsentan or bosentan) and a phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor (sildenafil or tadalafil).
    • High-Risk Patients (Class IV): Patients with advanced heart failure or syncope are treated with combination drug therapy, which includes intravenous prostacyclin therapy (epoprostenol, treprostinil or iloprost). (Option A & D)

Classification of PAH:

  • Group 1: Pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH)
  • Group 2: Pulmonary hypertension due to left heart disease
  • Group 3: Pulmonary hypertension due to lung disease or hypoxia
  • Group 4: Chronic thromboembolic pulmonary hypertension
  • Group 5: Pulmonary hypertension due to unclear and/multifactorial mechanisms

questions.text:
According to the 2010-2013 verbal autopsy report, please arrange the following causes of neonatal mortality in descending order, starting from the highest to the lowest.

1. Prematurity and low birth weight

2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia

3. Congenital anomalies

4. Sepsis
questions.solution:
orrect Option: A) 1 > 2 > 4 > 3

Explanation:

  1. Prematurity and low birth weight: Major contributors to neonatal mortality due to increased risk of complications.
  2. Birth injuries and birth asphyxia: Complications during labor and delivery leading to neonatal death.
  3. Sepsis: Severe infection in newborns, associated with high mortality if not promptly treated.
  4. Congenital anomalies: Structural or functional abnormalities at birth, less common but can still contribute to neonatal mortality.

 

Incorrect Options:

Options B, C and D are Incorrect.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C)Degeneracy

Explanation:

  • The wobble phenomenon is due to inosine's ability to form non-standard base pairs (with U, C, and A) at the third position of the codon, allowing a single tRNA to recognize multiple codons.

Wobble Phenomenon

  • Definition: Flexible/non-standard base-pairing between the third nucleotide of a codon (mRNA) and the corresponding nucleotide of the tRNA anticodon.
  • Function: Allows one tRNA molecule to bind to multiple codons coding for the same amino acid (Degenerate).
  • Inosine (I): A modified nucleotide in some tRNA anticodons, pairs with U, C, and A.
  • Non-standard pairing is more flexible than Watson-Crick base pairing, which is strict for the first two codon nucleotides.

 

Codon Position

Standard Base Pairing

Wobble Pairing

Example

1st and 2nd

Watson-Crick rules

Strict

AGA and AGG code for Arginine.

3rd

Non-standard pairing

Flexible

AGA/AGG with UCU, GGU/GGC/GGA with CCI

questions.text: Which one of the following is not a component of meta-analysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: C) Randomization

Explanation:

  • Meta-analysis is simply an analysis of results derived from multiple studies. It doesn't involve randomization because it synthesizes data from studies where randomization has already occurred, particularly in randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
  • It quantitatively and qualitatively analyses the results from various studies to reach a common conclusion. It differs from a systematic review in that the latter can be used to analyse the outcome of only a single study.
  • Meta-analysis takes the upper hand because the final outcome will always be reliable if multiple studies on the same topic are being analysed rather than a single study.

 

Incorrect Options:

Selection (Option A): Selection is a crucial step in meta-analysis. It involves identifying and selecting relevant studies that meet the inclusion criteria for the analysis.

Analysis (Option B): Analysis in meta-analysis involves extracting and synthesizing data from selected studies to obtain pooled estimates of treatment effects or associations through statistical methods.

Abstraction (Option D): In meta-analysis, abstraction involves extracting vital data from selected studies.

questions.text: A man with a fever of unknown origin has a job that requires traveling around the world. The histology of the bone marrow is shown below. Which of the following investigations would be the most appropriate in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) rk39 antigen test

Explanation:

  • The given histology image of bone marrow picture histology reveals Leishman Donovan bodies, suggesting typical Leishmaniasis. Leishman Donovan bodies are macrophages-laden amastigotes, which are ovoid or rounded cells, about 2-4 μm in size

Diagnosis of Kala-azar :

  • Depends upon direct and indirect evidences:

 

 

CFT: Complement Fixation Test; CIEP: Counter Immunoelectrophoresis; DAT: Direct Agglutination Test; DNA: Deoxyribonucleic Acid; ELISA: Enzyme Linked Immunosorbent Assay; ICT: Immunochromatographic Test; IFAT: Indirect Immunofluorescent Antibody Test; LD: Leishman-Donovan; NNN: Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle; PCR: Polymerase Chain Reaction; rK39: Recombinant Kinesin 39

Microscopy

Demonstration of amastigotes in smears of tissue aspirates is the gold standard for diagnosis of kala-azar / VL

Materials collected:

1. Peripheral blood smear: Peripheral blood contains the amastigotes present inside circulating monocytes. It is best to examine buffy coat smear, Buffy coat smears show a diurnal periodicity, more smears being positive when collected during the day than at night.

Blood smear test showing macrophages with amastigotes and extracellular Leishmania parasites (white arrows).

2. Bone marrow aspirate: Generally, the sternal marrow is aspirated by puncturing the sternum at the level of the 2nd or 3rd intercostal space, using a sternal puncture needle. Bone marrow samples can also be obtained by puncturing the Iliac crest.

Bone marrow aspirate showed Leishmania donovani bodies (LD bodies) in macrophages characterized by a kinetoplast and characteristic double dot appearance (Fig. A and B).

3. Splenic aspirate (most sensitive): Splenic aspirates are richer in parasites and, therefore, are more valuable for diagnosis. Splenic aspiration is contraindicated in patients with prolonged prothrombin time or if platelet count is less than 40,000/mm³

4. Lymph node aspirate: It is not useful in the diagnosis of Indian kala-azar

Culture

Media: NNN (Novy, MacNeal and Nicolle).

Serodiagnosis
  1. Detection of antigen: ELISA and PCR
  2. Detection of antibody:
    • rk39 test (Option A): A specific rapid immunochromatographic test (ICT) method for antibodies using a recombinant leishmanial antigen rk 39. The sensitivity of the test is 98% and specificity is 90%.
    • Complement fixation test
    • Indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT)
    • Counter immunoelectrophoresis (CIEP)
    • ELISA and DOT-ELISA
    • Direct agglutination test (DAT)

Non-specific serum tests
  1. Napier aldehyde test
  2. Chopra's antimony test

Skin test

  • Leishmanin skin test- Montenegro test: Delayed hypersensitivity test.
  • Positive result is indicated by induration and erythema of 5 mm or more after 48-72 hours.
  • Positive result indicates prior exposure to the leishmanial parasites. In active kala-azar, this test is negative and becomes positive usually 6-8 weeks after cure from the disease.

Image obtained after 48 hours after injection

Complete blood count
  • It shows normocytic normochromic anemia and thrombocytopenia.
  • Leukocyte count reveals leukopenia.
  • The ratio of leukocyte to erythrocyte is greatly altered and may be about 1:200 to 1:100 (normal 1:750).
  • The serum shows hypergammaglobulinemia and a reversal of the albumin: globulin (A: G) ratio.
  • Liver function tests show mild elevations of liver enzymes.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is elevated.
  • Liver biopsy is not a safe procedure and carries a risk of haemorrhage.

Incorrect Options:

pLDH (Option B) Plasmodium lactate dehydrogenase (pLDH) is a diagnostic test for malaria caused by Plasmodium species.

Galactose lectin antigen (Option C) is a diagnostic test for Entamoeba histolytica.

HRP-2 antigen (Option D) is a diagnostic criteria for malaria caused by Plasmodium falciparum.

questions.text: Identify the pelvic diaphragm in the given picture.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1

Explanation:

  • The pelvic diaphragm forms the muscular floor of the pelvis and provides support to pelvic organs. It primarily consists of the levator ani (pubococcygeus, puborectalis, iliococcygeus) and coccygeus muscles. The marked Option 1 correctly identifies the pelvic diaphragm.

Pelvic Diaphragm

Feature

Details

Components
  • Levator ani (pubococcygeus, puborectalis, iliococcygeus)
  • Coccygeus

Function
  • Supports pelvic organs
  • Aids in defecation, urination, and childbirth
  • Maintains continence

Openings
  • Urogenital hiatus (for urethra and vagina)
  • Anal hiatus (for rectum)

Clinical Relevance
  • Pelvic organ prolapse if weak
  • Urinary/fecal incontinence
  • Perineal tears in childbirth

 

2 (Option B): Incorrect – This marks the external anal sphincter, a voluntary muscle involved in anal continence but not part of the pelvic diaphragm.

3 (Option C): Incorrect – This marks the internal anal sphincter, an involuntary muscle that controls defecation, unrelated to the pelvic diaphragm.

4 (Option D): Incorrect – This marks the pudendal canal (Alcock’s canal), which transmits the pudendal nerve and vessels, but does not contribute to the pelvic diaphragm.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is preferred in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ocrelizumab

  • The preferred drug in the management of primary progressive multiple sclerosis is Ocrelizumab.

Multiple Sclerosis (MS):

  • MS is an autoimmune disease of the central nervous system (CNS) characterized by chronic inflammation, demyelination, gliosis (plaques or scarring) and neuronal loss.
  • Clinical Types of MS:
    • Relapsing or Bout-Onset MS (RMS)
    • Secondary Progressive MS (SPMS)
    • Primary Progressive MS (PPMS)
  • Management of MS:
    • Acute Attacks or Initial Demyelinating Episodes: Glucocorticoids are used to reduce the severity and duration of attacks:
      • Intravenous methylprednisolone: 500-1000 mg/day for 3-5 days.
      • Oral glucocorticoids (methylprednisolone, prednisone, dexamethasone) can replace IV therapy.
    • Disease-Modifying Therapies (DMTs):
      • Drugs used for treatment of Relapsing MS:

Highly Effective

Moderately Effective

Modestly Effective
  • Anti-CD20 Monoclonal Antibodies: Ocrelizumab, Ofatumumab, Rituximab
  • Anti-α4 Integrin Monoclonal Antibody: Natalizumab (Option A)
  • Mitoxantrone Hydrochloride
  • Anti-CD52 Antibody: Alemtuzumab (Option D)
  • S1P Receptor Modulators: Fingolimod, Ozanimod, Ponesimod (Option C)
  • Dimethyl Fumarate
  • Cladribine
  • Glatiramer acetate
  • Interferon beta
  • Teriflunomide

 

  • Drugs used for treatment of Progressive MS:
    • Siponimod:
      • Selective S1P1/S1P5 receptor modulator.
      • Reduces progression, relapse risk, and MRI burden in SPMS with active disease.
    • Ocrelizumab, cladribine, and ponesimod are approved for active SPMS.
  • Drugs used for treatment of Primary Progressive MS (PPMS):
    • Ocrelizumab:
      • Reduces disability progression by 24% in PPMS.
      • Improves clinical and MRI markers of disease activity.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses cannot integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) HAV

Explanation:

  • Hepatitis A virus (HAV) is an RNA virus that causes acute liver infection but does not integrate into the host genome or cause cancer. Unlike other hepatitis viruses (such as HBV and HCV), HAV does not have a chronic phase and is not associated with hepatocellular carcinoma.

Hepatitis Viruses and Their Features

Hepatitis A (HAV)

Hepatitis B (HBV)

Hepatitis C (HCV)

Hepatitis D (HDV)

Hepatitis E (HEV)

Picornaviridae

Primarily children

Mainly young adults

All ages

Transmission Route

Fecal-oral

None

Absent

Occasional (1-10%); higher in neonates

Common (85%)
