Cancer Risk

No (Option C)

Yes, linked to liver cancer (HCC)

Yes, linked to cirrhosis and liver cancer

Yes, increases risk of liver cancer and cirrhosis

No

Incorrect Options:

HPV (Option A) Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is a DNA virus that primarily presents with cutaneous and mucosal lesions. High-risk HPV types, such as HPV-16 and HPV-18, are strongly associated with the development of cervical, anal, vulvar, vaginal, penile, and oropharyngeal cancers.

SV 40 (Option B) Simian vacuolating virus 40 is a Polyomavirus associated with mesothelioma. Large T antigen and small T antigen are the two viral oncoproteins that are expressed by SV 40 and can inactivate p53, RB, and PP2A, leading to malignancy.

EBV (Option D) Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is a herpesvirus that infects B lymphocytes and epithelial cells. EBV is associated with the development of several malignancies, including Burkitt's lymphoma, Hodgkin's lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, and some gastric cancers.

questions.text: Which one of the options provided does not serve as a substrate for the synthesis of glucose?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Acetyl-CoA

Explanation: Acetyl-CoA is NOT a substrate for gluconeogenesis. Although acetyl-CoA is an important metabolic intermediate, it cannot be converted to glucose because the reaction catalysed by pyruvate dehydrogenase is irreversible.

Substrates for gluconeogenesis:

  • Lactate (Option D): Produced during anaerobic glycolysis in skeletal muscles and can be converted back to glucose in the liver through the Cori cycle.
  • Glycerol (Option B) is released from the breakdown of triglycerides in adipose tissue and can enter the gluconeogenesis pathway.
  • Alanine (Option C) and Glutamine: Released from the breakdown of proteins, primarily in muscle tissue.
  • Alanine is converted to pyruvate, which enters the gluconeogenesis pathway as part of the glucose-alanine (Cahill) cycle.
  • Propionate: Obtained from the metabolism of odd-chain fatty acids.

Cori’s cycle/ Glucose Lactate cycle and Cahill cycle/Glucose Alanine cycle

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy complains of cough and throat pain. On oral examination, a white pseudomembrane is observed. A swab from the lesion was collected and stained, as shown in the image below. What is the correct sequence for the staining procedure used?




	Albert’s stain – I
	Acid Alcohol
	Iodine
	Safranin
	Methylene blue
	Crystal violet
	Acetone
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 6, 3, 7, 4

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation and given picture show a gram-positive bacilli arranged in a V and L shape, giving a Chinese letter or cuneiform appearance, which is suggestive of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. It is stained using gram stain. Metachromatic granules are visualised through albert stain.

Steps of Gram staining:

  • Fixation: involved making the smear
  • Crystal Violet Staining: Flood the slide with crystal violet for 1 minute to stain all cells purple.
  • Iodine Treatment: Add iodine solution for 1 minute, which forms a complex with the crystal violet, helping it stick to the cells.
  • Decolorization: Rinse with alcohol or acetone to remove the stain from Gram-negative cells (while Gram-positive cells retain the dye).
  • Counterstaining: Flood the slide with safranin for 30 seconds to stain Gram-negative cells pink/red.

Other Options are incorrect.

questions.text: Identify the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Mitral stenosis:

  • The reduced area of the mitral valve with a "fish mouth" appearance is a hallmark feature of mitral stenosis.

Mitral Stenosis (MS):

  • Aetiology:
    • Primary Cause: Rheumatic fever is the leading cause of mitral stenosis, accounting for about 40% of cases in patients with a history of rheumatic heart disease.
    • Congenital abnormalities (e.g., parachute valve, cor triatriatum)
    • Mitral annular calcification with involvement of leaflets
    • Autoimmune diseases (e.g., systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis)
    • Left atrial myxoma
    • Infective endocarditis with large vegetation

  • Pathology: Chronic inflammation leads to thickening of the valve leaflets, fibrous tissue formation, calcific deposits, and fusion of the mitral commissures and chordae tendinae. This process results in a narrowed, funnel-shaped valve. (Fish-mouth Appearance)
    • Normal mitral valve area: 4-6 cm²; significant obstruction of <2 cm².
    • Hemodynamics: In severe MS (<1.5 cm²), a left atrial (LA) pressure of ~25 mmHg is needed to maintain normal cardiac output (CO).
    • Effects of Heart Rate: Increased heart rate diminishes diastolic filling time, raising the LA pressure and transvalvular gradient
  • Symptoms:
    • Exertional dyspnea, cough, and progressive limitation of daily activities.
    • Orthopnea and paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea can develop as MS worsens.
    • Atrial fibrillation (AF) often accelerates symptom progression.
  • Complications:
    • Pulmonary Hypertension (Leading to RVH & RHF)
    • Atrial Fibrillation (Due to Left atrial enlargement)
    • Thrombus Formation: Stasis of blood in the enlarged left atrium, increases the risk of thrombus formation, especially in patients with atrial fibrillation.
    • Hemoptysis (Elevated pulmonary venous pressure - rupture of small veins)
    • Infective Endocarditis
    • Pulmonary Infections
  • Findings:
    • Inspection: Malar flush, jugular venous distension, and right ventricular (RV) enlargement.
    • Auscultation: A loud S1, an opening snap (OS) after S2, and a low-pitched, rumbling mid-diastolic murmur with presystolic accentuation- heard best at the apex.
      • Characteristics of a murmur in severe MS:
        • Decreased interval between A2 & OS.
        • Wide splitting of S2.
        • Palpable systolic thrill.
        • The duration of the murmur increases.

  • Investigations:
    • ECG: Often shows LA enlargement, right axis deviation, and RV hypertrophy.
    • Echocardiogram: Measures mitral inflow velocity and transvalvular gradients and evaluates for associated mitral regurgitation (MR) or other valvular lesions.
    • Chest X-ray: Shows LA enlargement, pulmonary vein dilation, and Kerley B lines indicating pulmonary congestion.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient presented with a history of bilateral lower limb weakness which progressed to his upper limbs in a year. On examination, he had weakness in both lower limbs and wasting in the left upper limb. Babinski sign was positive and the deep tendon reflexes were absent. He has no sensory loss or any autonomic dysfunction. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - ALS

  • The patient's progressive bilateral limb weakness, muscle wasting, positive Babinski sign, absent deep tendon reflexes, and absence of sensory or autonomic dysfunction are consistent with Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS).

Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS):

  • ALS is the most common progressive motor neuron disease and a prime example of neurodegenerative disorders.
  • Genetic Causes:
    • Mutant Proteins: SOD1, ubiquilin-1/-2, and p62 mutations disrupt protein degradation.
    • RNA Processing: C9orf72, TDP43, and FUS mutations affect RNA transport/processing.
    • Axonal Transport: Mutations in dynactin and profilin-1 affect axonal transport.
  • Pathology:
    • The hallmark of ALS is the death of both lower motor neurons (anterior horn cells and brainstem motor neurons) and upper motor neurons (corticospinal neurons).
    • ALS involves both denervation and muscle atrophy, particularly in proximal muscles, and results in selective loss of motor neurons.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
    • Lower Motor Neuron Dysfunction: Asymmetric muscle weakness, muscle cramping, fasciculations, muscle atrophy and bulbar palsy.
    • Upper Motor Neuron Dysfunction: Reflex hyperactivity, muscle stiffness, spasticity and pseudobulbar palsy.
    • Corticobulbar Projection Degeneration: Results in dysarthria (speech difficulty) and pseudobulbar affect (excessive weeping or laughing).
    • Symmetric Muscle Involvement: Over time, more muscle groups become involved, leading to a symmetric distribution of the disorder in all regions.
    • Preserved Sensory and Cognitive Functions: Sensory, bowel and bladder, and cognitive functions are preserved even in the late stages.
    • Ocular Motility Sparing: Ocular motility remains unaffected until the very late stages of ALS.
  • Treatment:
    • No treatment halts the underlying ALS pathology.
    • Riluzole: Reduces excitotoxicity via decreased glutamate release.
    • Edaravone: Acts as an antioxidant and it modestly reduces disability progression.
    • Phenylbutyrate and Taurursodiol: Oral combination shown to slow disease progression and extend survival by improving mitochondrial and endoplasmic reticulum function.

Multiple sclerosis (Option A) typically presents with relapsing-remitting episodes, optic neuritis, and a combination of upper motor neuron (UMN) and sensory deficits, which are absent in this case, and the patient lacks the characteristic visual and brainstem symptoms like ataxia and nystagmus.

Guillain-barre syndrome (Option C) causes rapidly progressive ascending paralysis with areflexia, sensory involvement, and autonomic dysfunction, which this patient does not exhibit, as the weakness is bilateral and progressive over a longer period without sensory loss.

Tropical spastic paraparesis (Option D) is associated with spastic paraparesis, sensory deficits, and bladder disturbances but no lower motor neuron (LMN) involvement, which contrasts with this patient's presentation of muscle wasting (suggestive of LMN involvement) and absence of bladder dysfunction.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with cervical lymphadenopathy. As part of the evaluation, the Paul-Bunnell test was performed. What is the principle of this test?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Heterophile antibodies

Explanation:

Heterophile Antigens

  • Definition:
    • A type of hetero-antigen present in different species that share epitopes.
  • Cross-Reactivity:
    • Antibodies produced against an antigen from one species can react with the heterophile antigen from another species and vice versa
  • Diagnostic Applications:
    • Heterophile antigens are used in various serological tests to detect antibodies in patient serum.
    • Examples of Tests:
      • Weil-Felix Reaction: Used to diagnose certain infections, such as rickettsial infections.
      • Paul-Bunnell Test: Primarily used for diagnosing infectious mononucleosis.
      • Cold Agglutination Test: This test is used to detect specific antibodies that cause agglutination at low temperatures.
        • This test is primarily used to identify mycoplasma pneumonia.
      • Streptococcus MG Test: Used to detect antibodies associated with streptococcal infections.

Paul-Bunnell Test (Option C)

  • Purpose:
    • Diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus.
  • Method:
    • Utilizes sheep red blood cells (RBCs) as antigens to detect heterophile antibodies in the patient’s serum.
  • Principle:
    • In infectious mononucleosis, heterophile antibodies agglutinate sheep erythrocytes.
    • These antibodies can also occur after serum injections and in some normal individuals.
  • Procedure:
    • The inactivated serum is prepared by heating at 56°C for 30 minutes
    • The serum is mixed in doubling dilutions with an equal volume of a 1% sheep erythrocyte suspension.
    • Incubate at 37°C for 4 hours.
  • Interpretation:
    • Examine for agglutination.
    • An agglutination titer of 100 or above suggests infectious mononucleosis

Note: The Paul-Bunnell test uses sheep erythrocytes; the Monospot test, horse red cells.

Incorrect Options:

Complement fixation (Option A) is used to detect antigen-antibody reactions by assessing complement consumption. It is used in viral infections like influenza, syphilis, and fungal infections.

Superantigens (Option B) are proteins that cause excessive T-cell activation by bypassing normal antigen presentation. They are associated with toxic shock syndrome (Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes)

Haptens (Option D) are small molecules that can trigger an immune response only when attached to a larger carrier protein. They play a role in drug allergies and some immune reactions.

questions.text: Which of the following options is false in a patient with advanced liver disease?

choices.text: Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamine from alpha-ketoglutarate

questions.solution:
Correct Choice: C) Oxidative carboxylation of alpha-ketoglutarate

Explanation:

  • Transamination reaction is involved in the catabolism of amino acids. It is responsible for the generation and transport of ammonia from peripheral cells to the liver. The conversion of glutamate to alpha-ketoglutarate occurs only in the liver (oxidative decarboxylation). Hence, in the case of advanced liver disease, this will not be possible.
Transamination Process
  • Transfer of an α-amino group from an amino acid to one keto acid, producing a new α-keto acid and a new amino acid.
  • The first step is the catabolism of most amino acids.
  • All amino acids, except Proline, hydroxyproline, threonine, and lysine, participate in transamination.

Biological Importance

Amino Acid Interconversion: Maintains balance of non-essential amino acids by transferring amino groups to synthesise needed amino acids.

Ammonia Disposal: Detoxifies ammonia by funnelling amino groups into glutamate, which is deaminated in the liver for excretion.
Glutamate's Role

α-Ketoglutarate: Acts as an acceptor of amino groups from most amino acids, converting to glutamate.
Transamination occurs in the cytoplasm; the amino group is transported to the liver as glutamate.

Oxidative Deamination: Glutamate undergoes rapid oxidative deamination in the mitochondria to form α-ketoglutarate, which can accept another amino group.
Enzymes

Aminotransferases (Transaminases): Catalyse the transfer of amino groups between carbon skeletons. They are not coenzymes.

Alanine Aminotransferase (ALT): Transfers amino group from alanine to α-ketoglutarate, forming pyruvate and glutamate.

Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST): Transfers amino groups from glutamate to oxaloacetate, forming aspartate used in the urea cycle.
Coenzyme Pyridoxal Phosphate (PLP): Required by all aminotransferases, derived from vitamin B6.
Reversibility Transamination reactions are reversible, with equilibrium constants near 1.

 

Hyperammonemia (Option A) occur due to Depletion of alpha-ketoglutarate = TCA cycle is affected and ATP is not produced.

Decreased ATP synthesis (OptionB) As alpha-ketoglutarate is depleted, the Krebs cycle is affected and the amount of ATP produced decreases.

Increased synthesis of glutamine and glutamate from alpha-ketoglutarate (Option D) due to liver failure, the transamination reaction will not be able to occur

questions.text: Which one of these options is classified as a dematiaceous fungus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Cladosporium

Explanation:

  • The term dematiaceous refers to the presence of melanin, which gives these fungi characteristic dark coloration.
  • Cladosporium is melanin-producing fungi. Hence, it is a dematiaceous fungus.
  • Cladosporium is a common environmental mold found in soil, plants, and decaying organic matter. It is one of the recognized fungal agents that can cause chromoblastomycosis.
  • Other dematiaceous fungi are P. verrucosa, F. pedrosoi, Fonsecaea compacta, and Rhinocladiella aquaspersa.

Incorrect Options:

Mucor Species (Option A) belong to the group of zygomycetes; it is not dematiaceous fungi.

Aspergillus Niger (Option B) is an ascomycete fungus known to cause aspergillosis.

Blastomyces Dermatitidis (Option D) is a dimorphic fungus known to cause the disease blastomycosis.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Fixed central airway obstruction

  • The given image demonstrates flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory flow on the flow-volume loop, which is characteristic of fixed central or upper airway obstruction.

Types of Flow-Volume Loops:

Flow-Volume Loops and Their Examples:

Loop Type

Expiratory Curve

Inspiratory Curve

Example Conditions

Normal

Symmetrical, peaked

Symmetrical, rounded

Healthy lungs

Obstructive (Option A)

Scooped (concave)

Normal

COPD, asthma

Restrictive

Narrow, peaked

Narrow, peaked

Pulmonary fibrosis, pleural effusion

Fixed Upper Airway Obstruction

Flattened (box-like)

Flattened (box-like)

Tracheal stenosis, large goiter

Variable Extrathoracic Obstruction (Option D)

Normal

Flattened

Vocal cord dysfunction, laryngeal tumor

Variable Intrathoracic Obstruction (Option C)

Flattened

Normal

Tracheomalacia, bronchogenic tumor

questions.text:
Acid-base imbalance is suspected in a patient. Which of the following would you use to determine it?


	Arterial pH
	Venous pH
	Venous pO2
	Venous pCO2
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - 1,2

  • Acid-base imbalance can be determined using arterial and venous pH.
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is the gold standard for assessing acid-base imbalance; however, venous blood gas (VBG) analysis correlates well with ABG and is a safer, less invasive alternative.
  • The mean pH difference between ABG and VBG is minimal (ABG pH is higher by 0.03), making venous pH values acceptable for clinical use.

Venous pO2 (Option 3): Venous and arterial pO2 values are not comparable because arterial pO2 is typically 36.9 mmHg higher than venous pO₂, with significant variability.

Venous pCO2 (Option 4): Venous and arterial pCO2 are not directly comparable as the mean difference between them is approximately 4.8 mmHg, which limits its reliability in assessing acid-base imbalance.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms is considered a strict anaerobe?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prevotella

Explanation:

  • Numerous species of bacteria in the genus Prevotella are recognized as strict anaerobes.

Prevotella:

Classification

Gram-negative, Strict anaerobic, rod-shaped bacterium

Morphology

Small, pleomorphic Gram-negative rods

Habitat

Normal flora of the oral cavity, gastrointestinal tract, and female genital tract

Pathogenicity

Opportunistic pathogen, causes anaerobic infections

Clinical manifestation
  • Oral and dental infections (periodontal disease, abscesses)
  • Aspiration pneumonia
  • Lung abscess
  • Chronic sinusitis
  • Otitis media
  • Gynecological infections (bacterial vaginosis, pelvic inflammatory disease)

Diagnosis
  • Gram stain (Gram-negative rods)
  • Anaerobic culture
  • MALDI-TOF
  • PCR-based tests

Colony Morphology

Black-pigmented colonies on blood agar (some species)

Treatment

Metronidazole, β-lactam + β-lactamase inhibitors, Clindamycin

Resistance

Resistant to aminoglycosides

Incorrect Options:

Burkholderia cepacia (Option A) It is an obligate aerobe.

Yersinia enterocolitica (Option B) It is a facultative anaerobic bacteria, which means it can survive and grow in both the presence and absence of oxygen.

Stenotrophomonas maltophilia (Option C) is also a strictly aerobic organism.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male patient with heart failure is scheduled for a heart transplant. His renal function test is deranged, and haemoglobin is 6gm%. The physician ordered 2 units of whole blood. Four hours after transfusion, he developed severe respiratory distress. On examination, he is hypoxemic, has tachycardia and his mean arterial pressure is elevated. Which of the following are the best investigations for the above scenario?


	Chest X-ray
	Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) level
	Absolute neutrophil count
	Leucocyte antibodies
	Platelets
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 1 and 2

  • The clinical scenario of an elderly patient with heart failure, deranged renal function, and developing respiratory distress with hypoxia, tachycardia, and elevated mean arterial pressure following a blood transfusion points towards a diagnosis of transfusion- associated circulatory overload (TACO). The best investigations in the case of TACO are chest X-ray and BNP levels.

Transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO):

Features

  • Occur after transfusion of red blood cells or plasma products in 1% to 8.9% of transfusions.
  • Has become the leading cause of transfusion-related deaths

Causes/Risk Factors

  • Older age
  • Renal failure
  • Preexisting fluid overload
  • Cardiac dysfunction
  • Administration of a large volume of blood components
  • Excessive transfusion rate beyond the patient's hemodynamic tolerance.

Diagnosis

  • Hypoxia, dyspnea
  • Tachycardia
  • Systolic hypertension
  • Left heart failure
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Increased central venous pressure
  • Elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)
  • Chest X-ray: Bilateral alveolar infiltrates

Prevention

  • Identify at-risk patients.
  • Close monitoring and slow transfusion rates, 1 RBC concentrate over 3-4 hours.
  • Diuretics for hemodynamically stable patients with a history of TACO.

Treatment

  • Stopping the transfusion
  • Administering oxygen
  • Diuretics

Absolute neutrophil count (Option 3) (ANC) measures the number of neutrophils and is used to assess infection or inflammation. However, TACO is a condition caused by fluid overload and not by infection or inflammation, so ANC is not relevant in this case.

Leucocyte antibodies (Option 4) are typically used to identify immune reactions related to transfusions, such as Transfusion-Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI) or febrile non-hemolytic transfusion reactions, which are not the primary concern in TACO.

Platelets (Option 5): While platelet levels are useful for assessing bleeding or platelet-related disorders, they are not directly relevant in the diagnosis of TACO.

questions.text: Identify the virus given in the following replication cycle.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Herpes simplex virus

Explanation:

  • The virus shown in the picture is a DNA virus. In the above image, the virus first binds to the cell and enters inside the cell by uncoating.
  • After the entry of the virus inside the cell, three types of proteins, i.e., alpha, beta, and gamma, are formed via transcription and replication, which are pathognomonic of the herpes virus.
  • It has two cycles:
    • Lytic cycle: Immediate-early genes are expressed first, initiating the lytic life cycle of the virus, leading to the production of infectious virions and lysis of the host cell.
    • Latent cycle: There is limited gene expression and a lack of infectious virus particles.
  • Non- enveloped viruses

DNA

RNA
  • Parvovirus
  • Adenovirus
  • Polyoma virus
  • Papovavirus
  • Picornavirus
  • Astrovirus
  • Reovirus
  • Calicivirus
  • Hepatitis A
  • Hepatitis E
  • Enveloped viruses
    • All other viruses except from above have an envelope, few of which are:

DNA

RNA
  • Pox virus
  • Herpes virus
  • Hepadenovirus
  • Deltaviridae
  • Arena viridae
  • Bunyaviridae
  • Paramyxoviridae
  • Orthomyxoviridae
  • Filoviridae
  • Rhabdoviridae
  • Flaviviridae
  • Togaviridae
  • Matonaviridae
  • Coronaviridae
  • Retroviridae

Incorrect Options:

Human Immunodeficiency Virus (Option A) It belongs to Retroviridae, which is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses.

Hepatitis B Virus (Option C) replication cycle involves the following steps: attachment and entry into hepatocytes, the release of the viral genome into the nucleus, conversion of the viral DNA into a covalently closed circular DNA (cccDNA) form, transcription of viral genes, and replication of the viral genome, assembly of viral particles in the endoplasmic reticulum, and release through budding.

Coronavirus (Option D) It belongs to Coronaviridae, which is a family of single-stranded RNA viruses.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by:
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) High estrogen

Explanation: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by high estrogen.

Lactogenesis:

  • Refers to the initiation of milk secretion and encompasses the changes in the mammary epithelium that transform the undifferentiated mammary gland during early pregnancy into a fully functional lactating gland after childbirth.
  • Prolactin: Stimulates milk production by promoting mammary gland ductal growth, epithelial cell proliferation, and milk protein synthesis.
  • Inhibition of Milk Secretion During Pregnancy: High estrogen and progesterone levels prevent the breast tissues from responding to prolactin, despite high prolactin levels.
  • Following Delivery: Rapid drop in progesterone and estrogen levels triggers prolactin activity, leading to milk production in fully developed mammary glands.
  • Oxytocin: Involved in milk ejection, causing contraction of myoepithelial cells, and also supports maternal bonding and stress reduction.
  • Maintenance of Lactation: Regular milk removal and nipple stimulation trigger prolactin and oxytocin release.
  • Hormones involved in lactogenesis:
    • Insulin
    • Placental lactogen
    • Cortisol
    • Growth hormone
    • Thyroxine

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with shortness of breath, bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, jugular venous pulse was found to be elevated and liver was palpable 8 cm below the costal margin. An abnormality in which of the following structures is responsible for the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - 4

  • The clinical scenario of a patient with dyspnea, bilateral pitting pedal edema, abdominal distension, elevated jugular venous pulse (JVP), and a palpable liver strongly suggests right ventricular (RV) failure. Chronic smoking is a key risk factor for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which can lead to cor pulmonale, a condition where the right ventricle fails due to prolonged lung disease. Therefore, the abnormality lies in the right ventricle, as indicated in option D.

Cor Pulmonale:

  • Alteration in the structure and function of the right ventricle (RV) caused by a primary respiratory disorder leading to pulmonary hypertension.
  • Etiology:
    • Lung Diseases: COPD, interstitial lung disease, scleroderma, cystic fibrosis, obesity hypoventilation syndrome.
    • Vascular Disorders: Idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension.
    • Upper Airway: Obstructive sleep apnea.
    • Chest Wall Disorders: Kyphoscoliosis.
    • Massive Pulmonary Embolism: Leading cause of acute cor pulmonale, may mimic myocardial infarction with elevated troponins and chest pain.
    • COPD: Most common cause of chronic cor pulmonale.
  • Pathophysiology:
    • Chronic hypoxemia leads to pulmonary vasoconstriction and smooth muscle proliferation in small pulmonary arteries.
    • Increased pulmonary vascular resistance causes right ventricular enlargement (thickening, dilation).
  • Symptoms:
    • Dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, lethargy, exertional syncope, chest pain, abdominal edema, and lower extremity edema.
    • Clinical signs appear later, after pulmonary hypertension develops
  • Physical Findings:
    • Jugular Venous Distension: Prominent jugular V wave (tricuspid regurgitation).
    • Peripheral Edema: Non-specific but common in right heart failure.
    • Cardiovascular: Parasternal lift, loud S2, narrow S2 splitting, holosystolic murmur of tricuspid regurgitation, right-sided S4 heart sound.
    • Abdomen: Hepatomegaly, ascites.
  • Investigations:
    • Chest Radiograph: Pulmonary artery enlargement, right ventricular cardiomegaly.
    • ECG: Right ventricular hypertrophy/enlargement.
    • Chest CT Angiography: Rules out pulmonary embolism, pulmonary artery diameter >29 mm.
  • Management:
    • Oxygen Therapy: Improves oxygenation, reduces pulmonary vasoconstriction, enhances cardiac output.
    • Diuretics: Reduces RV filling volume in chronic cor pulmonale.

questions.text: Which class of ovarian tumor does clear cell carcinoma of the ovary belong to?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Epithelial cell tumor

Explanation: Clear cell carcinoma of the ovary is a type of epithelial cell tumor.

 

WHO Classification of Ovarian Tumours:

  • Common epithelial tumours: (Option A)
    • Serous tumours
    • Mucinous tumours
    • Endometrioid tumours
    • Clear cell (mesonephroid tumours)
    • Brenner tumours
    • Mixed epithelial tumours
    • Undifferentiated carcinoma
    • Unclassified epithelial tumours
  • Sex cord (gonadal stromal) tumours: (Option C)
    • Granulosa stromal cell tumours, theca cell tumours (Option D)
    • Androblastomas: Sertoli-Leydig cell tumours
    • Gynandroblastomas
    • Unclassified
  • Lipid (lipoid) cell tumours
  • Germ cell tumours: (Option B)
    • Dysgerminoma
    • Endodermal sinus tumour
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Polyembryoma
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma
    • Mixed forms
  • Gonadoblastoma:
    • Pure
    • Mixed with dysgerminoma or other germ cell tumours
  • Soft-tissue tumours not specific to the ovary
  • Unclassified tumours
  • Secondary (metastatic) tumours
  • Tumour-like conditions

questions.text: A boy with a history of a fall from a tree presents with a lurching gait and dragging of his feet. Which of the following structures are involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 1

Explanation:

  • The gluteus medius is essential for stabilizing the pelvis during walking. Injury to this muscle or its innervation (superior gluteal nerve) leads to a lurching gait (Trendelenburg gait) where the patient compensates by shifting weight toward the affected side to prevent pelvic drop.

Gluteus Muscles and Trendelenburg Gait

 

Tensor Fasciae Latae

Gluteus Medius

Gluteus Minimus

Attachments
  • Origin: Outer lip of the iliac crest extending from the anterior superior iliac spine to the tubercle of the crest.

 

  • Insertion: Iliotibial tract 3–5 cm below the level of the greater trochanter.
  • Origin: Gluteal surface of the ilium between anterior and posterior gluteal lines

 

  • Insertion: Oblique ridge on the lateral surface of the greater trochanter.

 
  • Origin: Gluteal surfaces of the ilium between anterior & inferior gluteal lines.

 

  • Insertion: Anterior aspect of the Greater trochanter

Relations
  • Between gluteus medius and sartorius
  • Covered by fascia lata
  • Covered by gluteus maximus (posterior third)
  • Deep to gluteus minimus
  • Deep to gluteus medius
  • Related to hip joint capsule

Vascular Supply
  • Mainly from lateral circumflex femoral artery
  • Supplied by superior gluteal artery
  • Deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis
  • Main trunk and deep branch of superior gluteal artery
  • Trochanteric anastomosis

Innervation
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)
  • Superior gluteal nerve (L4, L5, S1)

Actions
  • Hip flexor and abductor
  • Stabilizes pelvis
  • Helps maintain extended knee
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial & lateral rotation of thigh
  • Supports pelvis during single-leg stance
  • Abducts thigh
  • Medial and lateral rotation of thigh

Testing
  • Depression below anterior superior iliac spine
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance
  • Medial rotation against resistance
  • Abduction against resistance

Trendelenberg sign:

  • When the body's weight is balanced on one leg, the gluteal muscles on the supported side help elevate the opposite, unsupported side of the pelvis.
  • However, if there is a malfunction in the abductor mechanism, the Sound side sinks, which is referred to as a positive Trendelenburg sign (uncompensated).
  • This sign indicates issues with hip abductors, such as paralysis of the gluteus medius and minimus; problems with the fulcrum, including congenital or pathological hip dislocations; and concerns related to body weight, such as an unhealed fracture of the femoral neck.
  • When patients with the gluteus medius and minimus paralysis walk, they have a characteristic lurching gait i.e., during the single leg supporting phase of walking, there is leaning of the trunk to the affected side known as the compensated Trendelenburg sign.
  • Duck waddling gait is seen when both the sides are affected.

1 (Gluteus maximus) (Option A): Incorrect – Gluteus maximus is responsible for hip extension. Injury causes difficulty in rising from a seated position but does not cause a lurching gait.

3 (Piriformis) (Option C): Incorrect – Piriformis primarily functions in hip external rotation. Injury leads to piriformis syndrome, which causes sciatica-like pain but does not cause a lurching gait.

4 (Sciatic nerve) (Option D): Incorrect – Sciatic nerve injury causes foot drop and weakness in knee flexion rather than a Trendelenburg gait.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 2 (Lipid A)

Explanation:

Cell Wall of Gram-Negative Bacteria: 

  • Peptidoglycan layer:
    • It is thinner (1-2 layers, 2 nm) and more complex than the gram-positive cell wall.
    • Composed of a mucopeptide chain, with alternate NAM and NAG molecules.
    • The pentaglycine bridge is absent. The tetrapeptide chains are covalently linked between the D-alanine of one chain with meso-diaminopimelic acid of the adjacent chain.

  • Outer membrane (Option D ruled out):
    • It is a phospholipid layer, attached to the thin peptidoglycan layer by a membrane protein called Braun’s lipoprotein.
    • Contains outer membrane proteins (OMP), which help in transport of small molecules.
  • Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) : This layer is unique to gram-negative bacteria, consists of 3 parts (mnemonic - OPA):
    • O side chain (or O antigen or somatic antigen) (Option C ruled out): A polysaccharide chain which greatly varies in composition between bacterial strains and hence this is used for serotyping for bacteria (e.g., Salmonella typhi - widal test). It is also a major surface antigen, induces antibody formation.
    • Core polysaccharide: It is projected from lipid A region. It is composed of 10–12 sugar moieties.
    • Lipid A or the endotoxin (Option A): Responsible for endotoxic activities such as pyrogenicity, tissue necrosis, anti-tumor activity, etc.
  • Periplasmic Space: It is the space between the inner cell membrane and outer membrane. It encompasses the peptidoglycan layer.
  • Cell membrane (plasma membrane) (Option B ruled out):
    • The semipermeable membrane acts as an osmotic barrier and is composed of bilayered phospholipids.
    • Lacks sterols, such as cholesterol (except in Mycoplasma).
    • Site for metabolic processes like respiration and synthesis of lipids and cell walls.

Teichoic acids are polymers which are present only in gram-positive bacteria. These molecules help maintain the structure of the cell wall. They are of two types:

  1. Cell wall teichoic acid and
  2. Lipoteichoic acid

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy was brought to the casualty with seizures. The pediatrician tries to do CSF sampling. What are the structures punctured by the pediatrician while piercing through the marked structure?

choices.text: Scalp synchondral membrane, dura mater, arachnoid mater

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Scalp, dura mater, arachnoid mater

Explanation:

  • The anterior fontanelle is the largest fontanelle in an infant and remains open until around 18 months. It provides an accessible site for cranial ultrasound and CSF sampling in neonates.
  • During CSF sampling via the anterior fontanelle, the needle pierces:
    • Scalp (including skin and subcutaneous tissue)
    • Dura mater (outermost meningeal layer)
    • Arachnoid mater (middle meningeal layer)
  • The pia mater is not pierced as it remains intact while CSF is drawn from the subarachnoid space.

Anterior Fontanelle and CSF Sampling

Feature

Details

Location

Intersection of frontal and parietal bones

Closure

12-18 months

Clinical Uses

CSF sampling in neonates

Cranial ultrasound to assess hydrocephalus or hemorrhage

Structures Pierced

Scalp → Dura mater → Arachnoid mater → CSF space

Why Not Endocranium?

The endocranium is part of the bone, which is not yet ossified at the fontanelle.

 

Scalp, epicranium, dura mater (Option B): incorrect because the epicranium is a broad term for the scalp layers, but arachnoid mater is missing, which is an essential layer pierced in CSF sampling.

Scalp, synchondral membrane, dura mater, arachnoid mater (Option C): incorrect because there is no synchondral membrane at the fontanelle; it is composed of fibrous tissue, not cartilage.

Pericranium, dura mater, endocranium (Option D): incorrect because endocranium is the inner table of the skull, which is not yet ossified at the fontanelle. The arachnoid mater is also missing in this option.

questions.text: Identify the cranial nerve passing through the given structure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) IV

Explanation:

  • The marked structure is the dorsal aspect of the brainstem, specifically the region of the midbrain, near the inferior colliculus.
  • Cranial Nerve IV (Trochlear Nerve) is the only cranial nerve that emerges from the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.
  • The trochlear nerve decussates (crosses) before exiting, meaning a lesion in one trochlear nucleus affects the contralateral superior oblique muscle.
  • Function: It innervates the superior oblique muscle, aiding in intorsion and depression of the eye in adduction.

 

Trochlear Nerve (CN IV) and its Unique Features

Feature

Details

Origin

Dorsal midbrain, just below the inferior colliculus

Exit Point

Only cranial nerve to exit dorsally

Decussation

Crosses completely before exiting, affecting the contralateral superior oblique muscle

Function

Eye movement (intorsion & depression in adduction)

Lesion Effect

Vertical diplopia (trouble looking down, especially while reading or descending stairs)

 

Cranial Nerve III (Option A): Incorrect because CN III emerges from the ventral midbrain (interpeduncular fossa), not the dorsal brainstem.

Cranial Nerve V (Option B): Incorrect because CN V emerges from the pons, not the dorsal aspect of the brainstem.

Cranial Nerve VI (Option D): Incorrect because CN VI emerges from the pontomedullary junction (ventral side), not dorsally.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent?

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

Explanation:

Morphology of different Fungi

Fungi

Morphology 

Microscopy 

Aspergillus (Option D)

Acute angle dichotomous branching hyphae + septate h hi yphae

Mucor and Rhizopus species

(Option A and C)

Broad, aseptate hyphae branching at 90 degree or more

Candida

Single-cell with or without pseudohyphae


Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium (Option B) Fusarium is a filamentous characterized by hyaline septate hyphae bearing round microconidia, sickle-shaped large macroconidia, and chlamydospores fungi. It is more commonly associated with endophthalmitis and keratitis.

questions.text: A young man presented with hearing loss and tinnitus. Histology image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option B) Schwannoma

Explanation:

  • Schwannoma, also known as neurilemmomas, are benign nerve sheath tumors that arise from Schwann cells, which are the cells responsible for producing the myelin sheath that covers peripheral nerves. Histologically, the following findings are characteristic of Schwannoma.

Vestibular Schwannoma:

Description
  • Origin: Schwann cells; Site: CP angle

Pathology
  • Antoni A areas: These areas are composed of tightly packed spindle-shaped cells with elongated nuclei. The cells are arranged in palisades or whorls, forming Verocay bodies. The cells in Antoni A areas exhibit nuclear hyperchromasia (increased staining intensity) and cellular cohesion.
  • Antoni B areas: These areas are less cellular and show a looser arrangement of cells with a myxoid or microcystic appearance. The cells in Antoni B areas may have more irregular nuclei and a less distinct cytoplasmic organization compared to Antoni A areas.

Clinical presentation
  • 40-60 years, Males = Females
  • Unilateral sensorineural hearing loss associated with tinnitus

Radiology
  • Investigation of choice/Gold standard: MRI with Gadolinium contrast - ice cream cone appearance seen on CP angle.
  • Other investigations:
    • CT (with/without contrast): done when MRI is not feasible
    • Vertebral Angiography: though helps in localizing the tumor, it is not the investigation of choice.

Association
  • Neurofibromatosis type-2 (NF-2): Presents with bilateral Schwannomas and other tumors like Meningioma, ependymoma may also be associated.

Differential diagnoses

CP angle meningioma:

  • MRI: Dural tail sign seen

Glomus tumor: (Glomus jugulare)

  • Arises from the dome of Jugular bulb within the jugular fossa.
  • CT: Phelp sign (Bony erosion seen between carotid canal and jugular fossa)

Incorrect Options:

Neurofibromas (Option A): These are benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that arise from Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and other supporting cells. Histologically, neurofibromas typically show a mixture of cellular and myxoid areas. They are composed of a combination of Schwann cells, fibroblasts, and perineurial-like cells.

Leiomyoma (Option C): Leiomyomas are benign tumors that arise from smooth muscle cells. Histologically, leiomyomas exhibit bundles of spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with elongated nuclei arranged in a swirling pattern. Immunohistochemical staining for smooth muscle actin and desmin is positive in leiomyomas.

Rhabdomyoma (Option D): Rhabdomyomas are rare benign tumors that arise from skeletal muscle cells. They are most commonly seen in the heart (cardiac rhabdomyomas) and are often associated with tuberous sclerosis. Histologically, rhabdomyomas show sheets or clusters of polygonal cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm. The cells may have cross-striations, which are characteristic of skeletal muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemical staining for desmin and myogenin is positive in rhabdomyomas.

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with
questions.solution:
Correct answer: B) Hypomenorrhea

Explanation: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with hypomenorrhea.

  • Hypomenorrhoea refers to regularly timed but scanty episodes of bleeding.

 

Asherman Syndrome:

  • It is a condition characterized by intrauterine adhesions or synechiae caused by the formation of scar tissue within the uterus or cervix due to trauma to the uterine cavity or damage to the basal layer of the endometrium.
  • Pathophysiology: Trauma to the basal layer of the endometrium triggers inflammation, forming adhesive bands between opposing areas of the uterine cavity.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Uterine surgery or dilation and curettage.
    • Abnormal placentation, such as placenta increta, which invades below the basal layer of the endometrium.
  • Symptoms:
    • Hypomenorrhea or amenorrhea.
    • Severe dysmenorrhea, especially if menstrual flow is obstructed.
    • Recurrent miscarriages or infertility due to impaired endometrial vascularization.
  • Diagnosis: Saline sonography or hysterosalpingography to visualize adhesions.
  • Treatment: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis.

 

Oligomenorrhoea (Option A) denotes infrequent and irregularly timed episodes of bleeding, usually occurring at intervals of more than 35 days.

Dysmenorrhoea (Option C) means cramping pain accompanying menstruation.

Menorrhagia (Option D) denotes regularly timed episodes of bleeding that are excessive in amount (>80 mL) and/or duration of flow (>5 days).

questions.text: Identify the instrument given below.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Cusco’s speculum

Explanation: The instrument shown in the image is Cusco’s speculum.

 

Cusco's Self-Retaining Speculum:

  • A bivalve speculum that provides good exposure of the cervix when introduced into the vagina.
  • Uses:
    • Outpatient gynecological examinations.
    • Obtaining Pap smears.
    • Performing cervical biopsies.
    • Removal of small cervical polyps.
  • Advantage: Self-retaining design eliminates the need for an assistant.
  • Disadvantage: Covers both the anterior and posterior vaginal walls, which can lead to missed diagnoses of conditions like vaginal fistulas.

 

Sim’s speculum (Option B) is a single-bladed instrument used to hold the vaginal walls apart during examinations. Requires manual assistance and is commonly used for detailed gynecological procedures involving the cervix or endometrium.

 

Proctoscope (Option C) is designed for anorectal visualization. Used for conditions like hemorrhoids and rectal polyps, but unsuitable for gynecological examinations.

 

Doyen’s retractor (Option D) is a surgical instrument used to retract the abdominal wall and bladder to better view the lower uterine segment during gynecological surgeries.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a person who has facial swelling and orbital edema on the left side of their face after a minor trauma involving a piece of wood 20 days ago? The CT scan showed no abnormalities in the sinuses but revealed subcutaneous nodules. Microscopic examination of tissue sections showed positivity for PAS stain and Grocott's methenamine silver stain.
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Phycomycosis

Explanation:

  • Mucormycosis is a specific type of phycomycosis caused by fungi in the Mucorales.
  • It typically affects immunocompromised individuals and can manifest as rhinocerebral, pulmonary, gastrointestinal, or cutaneous infection.
  • The clinical presentation described in the question, with facial swelling, orbital edema, and subcutaneous nodules, along with the histological findings of PAS-positive and Grocott's methenamine silver-positive staining, is suggestive phycomycosis.

Mucormycosis

Description

A severe fungal infection primarily affects the nose and sinuses but can quickly spread to the orbit, cribriform plate, meninges, and brain. The fungus invades arteries, causing endothelial damage, thrombosis, and rapid tissue destruction.

Characteristic Findings

Black necrotic material in the nasal cavity, eroding the nasal septum, hard palate, and turbinates. Black turbinate sign is seen on contrast enhanced MRI.

Risk Factors
  • Uncontrolled diabetes, especially with ketoacidosis
  • Prolonged steroid use (common in COVID-19 treatment)
  • Conditions causing immunosuppression: Neutropenia, HIV/AIDS, chemotherapy, organ transplants, and kidney issues.

Diagnosis
  • Endoscopy: Shows pale mucosa early, progressing to black crusts and sloughing.
  • Biopsy: Multiple sites should be sampled for fungal identification; potassium hydroxide preparation is the gold standard for confirming invasive features.

Imaging
  • CT: Detects bony destruction and initial assessment of sinus involvement.
  • CECT: CECT provides better delineation of soft tissue structures, allowing for clearer identification of mucosal thickening, sinus opacification, and bony destruction.
  • MRI: Evaluates soft tissue invasion, assesses the extent of extra-sinus disease, and identifies complications, especially in the orbit and brain.

Treatment

Antifungal Therapy:

  • Amphotericin B: 0.6 to 1 mg/kg/day IV or liposomal Amphotericin B: 5 mg/kg/day.
  • Posaconazole: 300 mg twice daily orally on the first day, then 300 mg once daily.

Surgical Intervention:

  • Endoscopic debridement of necrotic tissues.
  • Severe cases: Total/Partial maxillectomy or orbital exenteration may be required.

Incorrect Options:

Midline lethal granuloma (Option B): Midline lethal granuloma, also known as polymorphic reticulosis or nasal T-cell lymphoma, is a rare malignant lymphoma that primarily affects the midline facial structures, such as the nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and nasopharynx. It typically presents with symptoms of nasal obstruction, facial swelling, and ulceration. The histological examination shows polymorphic lymphoid infiltrates.

 

Foreign body granuloma (Option C): A foreign body granuloma occurs when the body reacts to a foreign object that has been implanted or retained in the tissues. It typically presents as a localized inflammatory reaction with granulation tissue formation. However, the clinical presentation described in the question, with facial swelling, orbital edema, and subcutaneous nodules, is not consistent with a foreign body granuloma.


IgG4 granuloma (Option D): IgG4-related disease is a systemic fibro inflammatory condition characterized by the infiltration of affected tissues with IgG4-positive plasma cells. Often presents as tumefactive lesions or mass-like formations. However, the clinical presentation described in the question, along with the histological findings of PAS- positive and Grocott's methenamine silver-positive staining, is not indicative of IgG4 granuloma.

questions.text: For which procedure is the following set of instruments used?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Pap smear

Explanation: The given set of instruments is used for the collection of pap smears.

Pap smear

Site
  • Transformation zone of the cervix, where the squamous epithelium (ectocervix) and columnar epithelium (endocervix) meet.
  • This is the most common site for cervical cancer to develop.

Instruments
  • Ayre spatula collects cells from the ectocervix
  • Cervical broom (also called a cytobrush) from transition zone
  • Endocervical brush from endocervix

Procedure
  • Conventional Pap smear:
    • Step 1: Insert a posterior vaginal wall retractor or speculum to expose the cervix for clear visibility and access.
    • Step 2: Use a small brush or spatula to collect cervical cells by gently rotating the instrument.
    • Step 3: Smear the collected cells onto a microscope slide, ensuring preservation of cell structure.
    • Step 4: Fix the smear with a fixative to preserve the cells for subsequent lab analysis.
  • Liquid-based cytology: Cells are collected and then rinsed into a liquid fixative vial. This is considered more sensitive than the conventional Pap smear as it provides a more uniform distribution of cells.

Considerations
  • Sensitivity: A single Pap test has a sensitivity of 47-62% for detecting high-grade cervical lesions.
  • HPV co-testing: Combining the Pap smear with HPV DNA testing significantly improves screening accuracy.
  • Colposcopy: Colposcopy, with biopsy if indicated, is the gold standard for evaluating abnormal Pap results.

Indications
  • Cervical cancer screening: Routine screening for women aged 21-65 years, with the frequency and type of testing varying based on age and risk factors.
  • Evaluation of abnormal vaginal bleeding: While not a primary diagnostic tool, a Pap smear is performed as part of the workup, along with other tests.

Timing & Frequency
  • Age 21-29: Cytology (Pap smear) every 3 years.
  • Age 30-65: Co-testing (Pap smear + HPV testing) every 5 years.
  • >65: No further screening if they have had 3 consecutive negative cytology results or 2 consecutive negative co-test results and no history of high-grade precancerous lesions.
  • H/o of CIN 2 or higher: Annual screening for 20 years.
  • More frequent screening in HIV and Immunocompromised patients.

Contraindications

Avoided during menstruation. (Relative C/I)

Hysteroscopy (Option B) is a minimally invasive procedure that allows a gynecologist to visually inspect the uterine cavity using a hysteroscope, aiding in the diagnosis and treatment of uterine conditions.

Biopsy (Option C) is a procedure where a tissue sample is extracted for microscopic examination to diagnose diseases, often using Gellhorn's punch forceps for uterine biopsies.

Dilatation and Curettage (D&C) (Option D): A gynecological procedure involving the dilation of the cervix and scraping of the uterine lining with a curette, commonly used for conditions like heavy bleeding or to clear the uterus after a miscarriage. Instruments used include Sims' speculum, vulsellum forceps, anterior vaginal wall retractor, Hegar’s dilator, Simpson’s uterine sound, and Sim’s curette.

questions.text: Which of the following can be given for the long-term management of obesity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Liraglutide

  • Liraglutide is a GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) analogue used for the long-term management of obesity in type 2 diabetes mellitus.

GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1) analogues

MOA
  • Enhance insulin secretion in response to food intake, which helps manage postprandial blood glucose levels. (No hypoglycemia risk)
  • Suppress Glucagon Secretion
  • Slow Gastric Emptying leads to reduced food intake.
  • Promote satiety and help with weight loss.

Uses
  • Type-2 diabetes mellitus
  • Anti-obesity drug: Liraglutide and Semaglutide

Drugs:

Injectables:

  1. Exenatide: Shortest acting
  2. Lixisenatide: Albumin bound, longer acting
  3. Liraglutide
  4. Dulaglutide
  5. Albiglutide

Injectable and Oral Route:

  1. Semaglutide: Longest-acting

Side effects
  • Nausea and vomiting (most common)
  • Gallstones
  • Pancreatitis
  • Risk of Pancreatic and thyroid cancer (medullary carcinoma of the thyroid): contraindicated in MEN syndrome

Metformin (Option B) is a biguanide, which is the first-line oral hypoglycemic agent that acts by reducing hepatic glucose production. It may cause mild weight loss ,but it is not significant enough to be used to treat obesit.y

Sibutramine (Option C) is a medication that was previously used to manage obesity, but it has been discontinued due to safety concerns. It works by increasing the levels of certain neurotransmitters in the brain, which helps to reduce appetite and promote weight loss. Sibutramine was usually taken orally and was usually prescribed along with a healthy diet and exercise to manage obesity in the long term.

Fenfluramine (Option D) is a serotonergic anorectic agent that reduces food cravings due to increased serotonergic transmission in the hypothalamus. Due to severe side effects, it has now been banned by the US FDA.

questions.text: The third part of the vertebral artery is related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2

Explanation:

  • The third part of the vertebral artery (V3 segment) runs posterior to the lateral mass of the atlas (C1) and passes through the vertebral groove before turning medially to enter the foramen magnum.
  • Label 2 in the image represents the posterior arch of the atlas, which is where the vertebral artery runs before entering the cranial cavity.
  • Hence, the correct answer is Option C (2).

Vertebral Artery Course & Relations

Vertebral Artery Segment

Course & Relations

V1 (Pre-foraminal)

Arises from subclavian artery, enters C6 transverse foramen.

V2 (Foraminal)

Ascends through transverse foramina (C6 to C1).

V3 (Extracranial/Suboccipital)

Exits C1 transverse foramen, curves over posterior arch (Label 2), turns medially before piercing dura.

V4 (Intracranial)

Enters the skull via foramen magnum, joins contralateral vertebral artery to form basilar artery.

 

4 (Option A): Incorrect – Represents the anterior arch of atlas, which is unrelated to the vertebral artery.

3 (Option B): Incorrect – Identified as the superior articular facet, which articulates with the occipital condyles but is not related to the vertebral artery.

1 (Option D): Incorrect – Corresponds to the spinous process, which is posterior and not related to the vertebral artery course.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is not a long-acting reversible contraceptive method?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: C) Laparoscopic tubal ligation

Explanation: Laparoscopic Sterilization is an irreversible method of contraception.

Laparoscopic Sterilization:

  • An irreversible method of tubal sterilization involving laparoscopic access to the fallopian tubes, resulting in permanent contraception.
  • Procedure:
    • Performed under local or general anesthesia.
    • A small subumbilical incision is made, and CO₂ is used for pneumoperitoneum.
    • A trocar and cannula are inserted, and the operating laparoscope provides visualization.
    • The fallopian tubes are clipped, banded, or cauterized using a Filshie clip, Hulka clip, or silastic ring.
    • The procedure is completed with a subcuticular skin stitch.
  • Failure Rate: Between 0.2% and 1.5%, depending on the technique used.
  • Advantages:
    • Small, nearly invisible subumbilical scar.
    • Can be performed under local anesthesia as an outpatient.
    • Highly reversible, with a success rate of over 70%, although considered irreversible after the procedure.
  • Disadvantages:
    • Expensive equipment and maintenance.
    • Requires skilled personnel.
    • Mortality (1-2 per 100,000).
  • Complications:
    • Rare but serious, including abdominal wall emphysema, bleeding, uterine perforation, and incorrect ring placement.
    • Ectopic pregnancy (0.2%-0.3%) and hydrosalpinx may occur.
  • Contraindications:
    • Cardiac or pulmonary disease
    • Previous abdominal surgery
    • Extreme obesity
    • PID

Copper T (Option A) is a long-acting reversible contraceptive method, an intrauterine device (IUD). It is effective for up to 10 years and is reversible as it can be removed at any time, and fertility generally returns quickly after removal.

Implanon (Option B) is a subdermal implant that provides contraception for up to 3 years. It is a reversible method, as fertility typically returns within 1 month of removal.

Combined oral contraceptive pills (Option D) contain a mixture of estrogen (ethinylestradiol) and progestogen. They are a reversible method of contraception, with 90% of women returning to normal ovulatory cycles within 3 months after discontinuing the pills.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents with right-sided nasal obstruction and occasional blood-stained nasal discharge. His CT and endoscopy findings are shown in the below image. What could be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Inverted papilloma

Explanation:

  • The image shows Inverted papilloma causing erosion or remodeling of adjacent bony structures, such as the nasal septum or the walls of the sinuses.
  • Inverted papilloma is a benign sinonasal tumor that arises from the lining of the nasal cavity or paranasal sinuses.
  • It often presents with unilateral nasal obstruction, recurrent nosebleeds, and the potential for locally aggressive behavior.

Inverted Papilloma

Origin

Arises from the non-olfactory mucosa (Schneiderian membrane) of the nasal cavity and paranasal sinuses

Other Names

Transitional cell papilloma, Ringertz tumor, Schneiderian papilloma

Most Common Site

Lateral wall of the nose, particularly in the middle meatus.

Growth Pattern

Inward growth of hyperplastic tissue toward the stroma.

Association with HPV

Linked to Human Papillomavirus (HPV) infection (particularly types 6 and 11)

Risk of Malignancy

Associated with squamous cell carcinoma in 10-15% of cases.

Symptoms

Unilateral nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), and possible recurrent sinus infections.

Diagnosis

Endoscopic examination and biopsy for histopathological confirmation.

Treatment

Primary treatment is complete endoscopic surgical excision to minimize the risk of recurrence and malignant transformation.

Incorrect Options:

Carcinoma maxilla (Option B): Carcinoma of the maxillary sinus refers to malignant tumors that arise from the lining of the maxillary sinus. Symptoms may include nasal congestion, nasal discharge (sometimes blood-stained), facial pain, and swelling.

Esthesioneuroblastoma (Option C): Esthesioneuroblastoma, also known as olfactory neuroblastoma, is a rare malignant tumor originating from the olfactory epithelium in the upper part of the nasal cavity. It can present with nasal obstruction, epistaxis (nosebleeds), anosmia (loss of smell), and facial pain or swelling.

Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma (Option D): Nasopharyngeal angiofibroma is a vascular tumor that primarily affects adolescent males. It arises from the back of the nasal cavity and can cause nasal obstruction, epistaxis, and sometimes facial swelling.

questions.text: Which of the following devices can be used in a patient with bilateral external auditory atresia?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) 1

Explanation:

  • In a patient with bilateral external auditory atresia we use hearing devices. The first image shows such device known as BAHA. BAHA stands for Bone Anchored Hearing Aid.
  • Bone-anchored hearing aid (BAHA) captures the sound and transmits vibrations to the skull, stimulating the cochlea directly and bypassing the external auditory canal and middle ear. It is used when the air conduction method of rehabilitation cannot be used.

Components:

  • Titanium Fixture: Surgically embedded in the skull. It bonds with the surrounding skin (osseointegration)
  • Titanium Abutment: Connects the sound processor.
  • Sound Processor: Attached after osseointegration (2 to 6 months after implantation).

Indication:

  • Chronic ear discharge.
  • Single-sided hearing loss.
  • Children with microtia, anotia, canal atresia.
  • Conductive or mixed hearing loss (e.g., otosclerosis, tympanosclerosis) with contraindications for surgery.
  • Following MRM (large mastoid cavity).
  • Excessive feedback or discomfort from AC hearing aids.
  • Age of implantation: >5yrs

Surgical Procedure:

  • Adults typically have a single-stage surgery with a 3-month osseointegration wait.
  • Children usually undergo a two-stage procedure, with the fixture placed first and the abutment connected after 6 months.

Incorrect Options:

The second image shows a cochlear implant (Option B): A cochlear implant is a medical device that is used to restore hearing in individuals with severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss. Unlike traditional hearing aids, which amplify sound, cochlear implants bypass the damaged parts of the inner ear (cochlea) and directly stimulate the auditory nerve to provide a sense of sound.

The Platinum K piston is a type of middle ear prosthesis (Option C): The Platinum K piston is designed to replace or bypass the damaged or malfunctioning ossicles in the middle ear, specifically the incus. The piston is attached to the incus on one end and to the tympanic membrane on the other end.

Ossicular prosthesis (Option D): Also known as middle ear prosthesis or ossicular replacement prosthesis, is a device used in otologic surgery to restore or improve hearing in patients with middle ear conditions that affect the function of the ossicles. The ossicles are the three small bones in the middle ear: the malleus, incus, and stapes.

Drugs:

Side effects

Metformin (Option B) is a biguanide, which is the first-line oral hypoglycemic agent that acts by reducing hepatic glucose production. It may cause mild weight loss ,but it is not significant enough to be used to treat obesit.y

Sibutramine (Option C) is a medication that was previously used to manage obesity, but it has been discontinued due to safety concerns. questions.text: Which of the following is a centrally acting opioid antitussive?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Levopropoxyphene

  • Levopropoxyphene is a centrally acting opioid antitussive drug that is used to suppress the cough reflex in the brain.
  • Dose - 50-100 mg every 4 hours.
  • It has no analgesic property ,but it may cause sedation
  • It has a high abuse potential thus it was withdrawn from the market in several countries.
  • It may lead to respiratory depression and cardiac arrhythmias.

Ambroxol (Option A) is a mucolytic medication that is used to treat respiratory diseases such as bronchitis, asthma, and COPD. It works by breaking down and thinning mucus in the respiratory tract, making it easier to cough up.

Diphenoxylate (Option B) is used to treat diarrhoea. It works by slowing down the movement of the intestines, reducing the number of bowel movements and making the stool more solid. It is an opioid medication and can be abused, leading to addiction. It is usually combined with atropine to discourage its abuse due to its unpleasant side effects.

Levorphanol (Option D) is a potent synthetic opioid that is used to treat severe pain. It works by binding to opioid receptors in the brain and spinal cord along with inhibition of reuptake of 5HT/Norepinephrine and antagonism at the NMDA receptor, reducing the perception of pain. It has a higher potency than morphine and is used when other opioid medications are not effective or have intolerable side effects.

questions.text: What will be the gestational age of the fetus if the crown rump length is 21 cm and the length of the lower limb is 10 cm?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 6 to 7 months

Explanation:

To estimate gestational age using crown rump length (CRL) and the Rule of Hasse:

Rule of Hasse:

  • In the first 5 months, the fetal length in centimeters is roughly equal to the square of the month (Length = month²).

  • After 5 months, the length in cm divided by 5 gives the gestational age in months.

Given Data:

  • Crown rump length (CRL): 21 cm

  • Lower limb length: 10 cm

Calculation Using Rule of Hasse:

  • For fetuses older than 5 months, the total length (crown-heel) in cm ≈ 5 × month.

  • However, CRL is used for up to ~5 months; after that, crown-heel length is used.

  • At 6 months, the crown-heel length is about 30 cm (so CRL is typically about 2/3 of crown-heel, i.e., ~20 cm).

  • At 7 months, crown-heel length is about 35 cm (CRL ~23 cm).

  • At 8 months, crown-heel length is about 40 cm (CRL ~26–27 cm).

A CRL of 21 cm corresponds to a gestational age of 6 to 7 months.

Supporting Evidence:

  • NCBI and standard charts show that a CRL of 21 cm is consistent with a fetus of 6–7 months gestation.

  • The lower limb length of 10 cm also supports this age range, as limb lengths increase proportionally with gestational age.

4 to 5 months (option A): At 4 months, the fetal length is ~16 cm; CRL would be significantly less than 21 cm.

5 to 6 months (option B): A CRL of 21 cm is beyond the 5–6 month range, where CRL would typically be ~17–19 cm.

8 to 9 months (option D): At this stage, crown-heel length is ~40–45 cm, and CRL would be ~27–30 cm, exceeding the given value.

questions.text: What could be the likely cause for shifting the initial treatment plan of starting on ampicillin to ceftriaxone in a 14-month-old diagnosed with Haemophilus influenza meningitis?

choices.text: Haemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin.
Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin
Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, butthe patient is allergic to sulfa drugs
Hemophilus produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hemophilus produces beta-lactamase, hence resistant to ampicillin.

  • The antibiotic was most likely changed from Ampicillin to Ceftriaxone.
  • Haemophilus produces beta-lactamas,e which renders Ampicillin, a beta-lactam antibiotic, ineffective.
  • Haemophilus is sensitive to second and third-generation cephalosporins such as Ceftriaxone, which has a very long half-life allowing once-daily dosing.
    • Dose of Ceftriaxone - 50mg/kg/dose given 12 hourly
  • Vancomycin + Ceftriaxone is used as empirical therapy for suspected cases of meningitis beyond the neonatal period.

Cell wall synthesis inhibitors

Hemophilus alters penicillin-binding protein sites, hence resistant to ampicillin (Option A). This statement is false as Hemophilus produces beta-lactamases which makes them resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics.

Easier to administer IV ceftriaxone than IV ampicillin (Option B ) as a single dose administration of ceftriaxone may be more convenient than the multiple daily doses required for ampicillin, but ease of administration is not the primary reason for switching from Ampicillin to Ceftriaxone.

Cotrimoxazole is the drug of choice, but the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs (Option C) Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is an antibiotic that is often used to treat Hemophilus influenzae infections. However, if the patient is allergic to sulfa drugs, cotrimoxazole may not be a suitable treatment option but in this patient, this is not the reason forthe change of ampicillin to ceftriaxone as there is no history of allergy to sulfa drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs would enhance the bioavailability of saquinavir?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Ritonavir

  • Ritonavir, when used in combination with saquinavir, increases the levels of saquinavir in the blood, thus enhancingthe bioavailability of saquinavir.
  • Ritonavir is a protease inhibitor that is used to treat HIV.
  • It inhibits the activity of an enzyme called cytochrome P450 (CYP3A4) which is responsible for breaking down saquinavir in the liver.
    • By inhibiting the activity of this enzyme, ritonavir can increase the bioavailability of saquinavir, leading to higher levels of the medication in the blood and improved antiviral activity.
    • This phenomenon is known as boosting of protease inhibitors by CYP inhibitors (Ritonavir, Cobicistat)
    • All protease inhibitors except Nelfinavir are metabolised by CYP3A4 thus, their activity can be boosted.
  • Saquinavir is also an HIV protease inhibitor that inhibits replication of both HIV-1 and HIV-2.

Co-administration of Ritonavir and Saquinavir results in:

  • Enhanced bioavailability of Saquinavir
  • Inhibition of systemic clearance of Saquinavir
  • Longer half-life of the protease inhibitor
  • Reduction of drug dose and dosing frequency of Saquinavir

Protease inhibitors (PI)

MOA
  • Inhibits the assembly/packaging of viral proteins
  • Competitively inhibits the action of HIV aspartyl protease

Pharmacokinetics

All are CYP3A4 inhibitors: Except Nelfinavir (CYP2C9)

  • Increases toxicity of other drugs
  • Simvastatin: Risk of myopathy
  • Midazolam: Causes respiratory depression

Uses

HIV treatment and 2nd line Post-exposure prophylaxis

Drugs
  • Ritonavir
    • Maximum CYP inhibition → inhibits metabolism of other PI
    • Low-dose ritonavir boosts other protease inhibitors (Lopinavir)
  • Amprenavir
  • Fos-amprenavir
  • Tipranavir
  • Indinavir
  • Saquinavir (least CYP inhibitor)
  • Lopinavir
  • Atazanavir (no dyslipidemia)
  • Nelfinavir
  • Darunavir (maximum bioavailability, taken with food)

Resistance
  • P-glycoprotein efflux transporter
  • Cross-resistance with other protease inhibitors.

Vitamin C (Option B) is an essential nutrient that is involved in many important functions in the body, including immune function, collagen production, and wound healing. However, it is not known to have any significant effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir.

Cimetidine (Option C) is a medication that is used to reduce stomach acid production and is sometimes used to treat acid reflux and ulcers. It can also inhibit the activity of cytochrome P450, which is involved in the metabolism of many medications, including saquinavir. However, current evidence suggests that cimetidine has only a modest effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir and may not be a reliable method for increasing saquinavir levels.

Ganciclovir (Option D) is an antiviral medication that is used to treat herpes viruses and cytomegalovirus (CMV) infections. It is not known to have any significant effect on the bioavailability of saquinavir, as it works through a different mechanism of action compared to saquinavir.

questions.text: Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Hodgkin’s lymphoma

  • Nivolumab is a checkpoint inhibitor that targets the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor on T cells, which can help to overcome the tumour's ability to evade the immune system thu,s it is used in Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Nivolumab
  • Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the programmed cell death protein 1 (PD-1) receptor on T cells.

MOA
  • PD-1 is a checkpoint protein that is expressed on the surface of T cells
  • It helps to regulate the immune response by inhibiting T-cell activation and proliferation.
  • It has two ligands, PD-L1 and PD-L2, and when PD-1 binds to these ligands, it sends a signal to the T cell to "turn off" and stop attacking the cancer cell.
  • By blocking the PD-1 checkpoint, nivolumab enhances the anti-tumour activity of T cells and promotes an immune response against cancer cells.

 

  • It is different from traditional chemotherapy and radiation therapy, and it is considered a type of immunotherapy that harnesses the immune system to fight cancer.

Uses

  • Replasped classical Hodgkin’s lymphoma
  • Advanced melanoma
  • Advanced non-small cell lung cancer (that was previously treated)
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • Head and neck cancer

Side effects

  • Rash
  • Fatigue, muscle pain
  • Reduced appetite
  • Constipation
  • Pneumonitis
  • Colitis
  • Nephritis
  • Hepatitis

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly matched?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer D - Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

  • Ciraparantag is a reversal agent for all several anticoagulants such as direct factor Xa inhibitors (rivaroxaban, apixaban and edoxaban), dabigatran, and heparins
  • Fondaparinux is an indirect factor Xa inhibitor that is used to prevent blood clots in patients undergoing surgery, those with acute coronary syndromes, and those at risk for deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism.

Andexanet alfa (Option A and B) is a recombinant modified human factor Xa protein that acts as a decoy molecule to bind and sequester factor Xa inhibitors such as edoxaban and rivaroxaban. This effectively reverses their anticoagulant effect and restores normal blood clotting in patients who are experiencing bleeding or require urgent surgery.

Idarucizumab (Option C) is a monoclonal antibody fragment that specifically binds to dabigatran, a direct thrombin inhibitor, and neutralises its anticoagulant effect. It was approved by the FDA in 2015 for the reversal of dabigatran in emergency situations such as life-threatening bleeding or the need for urgent surgery.

questions.text: A girl was allegedly kidnapped by a man. In court, she says that she is a major and is married to the man, X-ray images of her elbow, wrist and pelvis are given. What is the approximate age of the girl?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) 21 to 22 years

Explanation:

Based on the fusion timelines of the upper limb (elbow, wrist) and lower limb (pelvis) bones, the skeletal maturity aligns most closely with the 21 to 22 years age range, as the bones in these regions are generally fully fused at this age.

  • Elbow: In a 21-22 year old female, the epiphyseal plates in the elbow region should be closed, indicating the completion of growth and fusion. The bones of the elbow joint, including the humerus, radius, and ulna, should appear fully developed and fused. The joint space should be minimal, and the bony contours should be well-defined.
  • Wrist: At this age, the growth plates in the wrist region should also be closed, indicating the completion of growth. The carpal bones of the wrist, including the scaphoid, lunate, triquetrum, pisiform, trapezium, trapezoid, capitate, and hamate, should be well-formed and have fused together. The bony architecture of the wrist should be well-defined.
  • Pelvis: In a 21-22 year old female, the pelvis should have completed its growth and reached its adult form. The ilium, ischium, and pubis bones of the pelvis should be fully developed and fused. The sacroiliac joints should be stable, and the symphysis pubis should be fused with minimal or no joint space.

questions.text: An HIV-positive woman on ART was prescribed ergotamine for a migraine attack four days ago. She presented with complaints that she has been unable to feel her legs, from the mid-thigh to her toes, for the past two days. The angiographic image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Ergotism

  • Based on the clinical features and CT angiography, which shows diffuse symmetrical luminal narrowing of the lower limb vessel, the patient most likely has ergotism.
  • Ergotism is a condition caused by the ingestion of ergot-contaminated grains or the use of ergot-derived medications such as ergotamine.
  • In patients who are HIV positive and are currently on ART may have Han IV protease inhibitors in their ART regimen, thus resulting in the inhibition of CYP3A4, which is also responsible for the metabolism of ergotamine.
  • This results in the accumulation of toxic levels of ergotamine in the patient, causing ergotism.

Ergotamine

  • Partial agonist and antagonist at alpha-adrenergic, 5HT1 and 5HT2 receptors.
  • Produces sustained vasoconstriction, vasomotor centre depression and visceral smooth muscle contraction
  • Side effects of Ergotamine
    • Coronary vasoconstriction
    • Gangrene of the extremities
    • Hypertension
    • Arrhythmias
    • Sweating
    • Bradycardia
  • Contraindications
    • Ischaemic heart disease
    • Hypertension
    • Epilepsy
    • Hepatic or renal impairment
    • Pregnancy

 

Atherosclerosis (Option A) involves chronic plaque formation leading to arterial narrowing. While ischemia may occur, the acute onset of symptoms in this case is more consistent with drug-induced vasospasm.

Polyradicular Neuropathy (Option C) would present with gradual, symmetric sensory or motor loss, not acute ischemic changes or angiographic findings of vasospasm.

Herniated disc (Option D) typically causes radicular pain and motor weakness, not ischemic limb findings or angiographic evidence of vasoconstriction.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective drug in smoking cessation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Varenicline

  • Varenicline is a medication that is used to help people quit smoking.
  • Mechanism of action:
    • Binds to alpha-4, beta-2 nicotinic receptors in the brain and also inhibits dopaminergic activation via partial agonism, reducing cravings and withdrawal symptoms.
    • Prevents nicotine stimulation of the mesolimbic dopamine system ,which is associated with nicotine addictio,n and blocks the ‘reward’ effect of smoking.
  • More effective than other smoking cessation medications, including nicotine replacement therapy and bupropion
  • Dosing - per oral
    • 0.5 mg once daily from day 1 to 3
    • 0.5 mg twice daily from day 4 to 7
    • 1 mg twice daily after day 8 for 11 weeks.
  • Side effects include nausea, headache, sleep disturbances, renal stones and some serious conditions such as Stevens-Johnson syndrome, erythema multiforme, photosensitivity and renal failure
