Buspirone SR (Option B) is anxiolytic that has been studied as an off-label treatment for smoking cessation due to its ability to reduce anxiety and stress, which can be triggers for smoking. Buspirone hydrochloride extended-release tablets (SR) are formulations of the drug that are designed to be released into the bloodstream slowly over time, allowing for once-daily dosing. This can be more convenient for patients who have difficulty adhering to multiple daily dosing regimens.

Nicotine gum (Option C) is a form of nicotine replacement therapy that is designed to help people quit smoking by reducing the intensity of nicotine withdrawal symptoms. The gum allows for the absorption of nicotine through the lining of the mouth, which can help to reduce cravings and withdrawal symptoms. While nicotine replacement therapy can be effective in smoking cessation, it is usually less effective than varenicline. Nicotine gum may also have side effects, including mouth irritation and hiccups, and should not be used by people who have dental problems or jaw pain.

Rimonabant (Option D) is a medication that was developed as an anti-obesity drug and was also studied for its potential in smoking cessation. It works by acting as an inverse agonist and blocking the CB1 receptor in the brain, which is involved in regulating appetite and addictive behaviors.

questions.text: Which of the following thiazide diuretics is appropriate for a 34-year-old man with hypertension and stage 4 chronic kidney disease, characterized by an estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) below 30?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - Metolazone

  • Metolazone can be used to treat hypertension in patients with chronic kidney disease.
  • In patients with chronic renal failure, thiazide diuretic is not effective, but Metolazone is an exception as it is effective as aan ntihypertensive medication in patients with chronic renal failure.
  • It works by inhibiting the reabsorption of sodium and water in the kidneys, which leads to increased urine production and decreased blood volume.
  • It also has an additional action in the PCT, as thiazides mainly act on the DCT.
  • It is less likely to cause electrolyte imbalances compared to other thiazide diuretics.

Chlorothiazide (Option A), Chlorthalidone (Option B) and Hydrochlorothiazide (Option D) are a thiazide diuretic that works by increasing the excretion of sodium and water in the urine, which leads to a decrease in blood volume and blood pressure. However, in patients with severe CKD, such as stage 4, thiazide diuretics may be less effective as the kidneys are not able to excrete sodium and water as efficiently, and the risk of electrolyte imbalances may also be higher.

questions.text: Paradoxical bronchoconstriction is seen with ipratropium bromide due to all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hypertonic saline:

  • Paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide is not seen with hypertonic saline; rather, it occurs with hypotonic saline nebulization.
  • Paradoxical bronchoconstriction refers to a situation where instead of dilating the airways, the medication actually causes the airways to constrict.
  • Adverse effects associated with the use of Ipratropium bromide, an anticholinergic medication used for the treatment of bronchospasm in conditions such as asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
  • It may occur due to:
  • Hypotonic nebulizer solution
  • Antibacterial additives - Benzalkonium chloride and ETDA (Option B and C)
  • Prejunctional M2 receptor blockade on the cholinergic nerves present in the airway, causes increased release of acetylcholine, leading to bronchoconstriction (Option D)
  • Not seen with Tiotropium bromide, as it is selective for M1 and M3 receptors and does not cause prejunctional M2 receptor blockade.

questions.text: Category A, B, C, D, and X in drug classification are indicative of which of the following?

choices.text: Cost ratio from cheap to expensive
As per the safety or therapeutic index

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Safety in pregnancy:

  • Category A, B, C, D, X in drug classification are indicative of the safety of a drug during pregnancy, with category A being the safest and category X being the most unsafe.

 

Category A

Adequate and well-controlled studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in the first trimester of pregnancy, and there is no evidence of risk in later trimesters.

Examples - Doxylamine, Folate and Levothyroxine

Category B

Animal reproduction studies have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus, but there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women. Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, but adequate and well-controlled studies in pregnant women have failed to demonstrate a risk to the fetus in any trimester.

Examples - Amoxicillin and Ondansetron

Category C

Animal reproduction studies have shown an adverse effect on the fetus, and there are no adequate and well-controlled studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Examples - Metoprolol and fluconazole

Category D

There is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience or studies in humans, but potential benefits may warrant the use of the drug in pregnant women despite potential risks.

Examples - ACE inhibitors, Lithium and Phenytoin

Category X

Studies in animals or humans have demonstrated fetal abnormalities, and there is positive evidence of human fetal risk based on adverse reaction data from investigational or marketing experience.

Risks involved inthe use of the drug in pregnant women clearly outweigh the potential benefit.s

Examples - Methotrexate, Warfarin and Statins

 

 

Schedules of drugs as per the Drugs and Cosmetics Act of India:

Schedule

Description

Schedule C

Biological and Special Products: Includes sera, vaccines, toxins, antitoxins, insulin, etc.

Schedule D

Drugs: Extends to diagnostic kits and reagents, including various biotechnological products.

Schedule E

Substances: These include toxic substances such as poisonous plants and their preparations.

Schedule F

Vaccines and Sera: Specifies standards for blood products and diagnostic antigens.

Schedule G

Prescription Drugs: Drugs that should be taken under medical supervision only and must carry a warning.

Schedule H

Prescription Only Drugs: Sale is restricted to prescriptions from a registered medical practitioner.

Schedule J

Diseases: List of diseases for which medicines cannot be claimed to cure or treat, such as cancer, AIDS, etc.

Schedule O

Disinfectants and Insecticides

Schedule R

Standards for Cosmetics: Specifies standards for soaps, shampoos, creams, etc.

Schedule W

Drugs marketed under generic names.

Schedule X

Narcotic and Psychotropic Substances

Schedule Y

Requirement and guidelines for import/manufacture or Clinical trials in India

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Inhibition of calcineurin

  • Cyclosporine is an immunosuppressive medication that inhibits the activity of calcineurin, which is a phosphatase enzyme that is involved in T-cell activation.

Cyclosporine

MOA

  • Binds to cyclophilin, a protein that is expressed in T-cells, and this complex then binds to and inhibits calcineurin
  • It results in a reduced transcription of cytokine genes for IL-2, TNF-alpha, IL-3, IL-4, CD40L and Granulocyte-macrophage colony-stimulating factors and interferon-gamma
  • Ultimately, this results in a reduction in T-cell proliferation - Immunosuppression and immunomodulation

Uses

  • Post-solid organ transplantation - to avoid organ rejection
  • Rheumatoid arthritis, which has not responded to methotrexate
  • Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis
  • Steroid resistant Foca segental glomerulosclerosis
  • Psoriasis

Adverse effect

  • Reduced GFR
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Dyslipidemia
  • Gynecomastia
  • Hypertrichosis
  • Neurotoxicity - convulsion

 

AMP kinase (AMPK) (Option B) is an enzyme that plays a key role in regulating cellular energy metabolism. It is activated when cellular energy levels are low, and it promotes the production of ATP, the primary energy source for cells. It is not known to stimulate the activity of AMP kinase. In fact, some research suggests that cyclosporine may inhibit the activity of AMPK, although the mechanisms underlying this effect are not well understood.

Inosine monophosphate dehydrogenase (IMPDH) (Option C) is an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of guanosine nucleotides, which are building blocks of DNA and RNA. Cyclosporine is not known to inhibit the activity of IMPDH. However, another immunosuppressive medication called mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) does inhibit IMPDH, and it is often used in combination with cyclosporine to treat transplant rejection.

Dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase inhibition (Option D) is an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of pyrimidine nucleotides, which are also building blocks of DNA and RNA. Cyclosporine is not known to inhibit the activity of DHODH.

questions.text: What is the half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 per hour?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer C - 13.8 hours

  • The half-life of the given drug is 13.8 hours.
  • Half-life is the time taken by a drug for the drug plasma concentration to decrease by 50%, and the elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug removed from the body per unitof time.
  • The formula for calculating the half-life of a drug is:
    • t1/2 = 0.693 / K
    • Putting in the given elimination rate constant of 0.05/hr, we get:
    • Half-life = 0.693 / 0.05 = 13.86 hours

questions.text: Topiramate is used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome

  • Topiramate is used to treat Lennox-Gastaut syndrome.
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a rare and severe form of epilepsy that typically begins in early childhood and is characterized by seizures that are difficult to control.
  • There is no cure for LGS, and management focuses on controlling seizures and improving quality of life using Topiramate as an anti-epileptic.

Topiramate

MOA
  • Reduces voltage-gated sodium currents in cerebellar granule cells.
  • Activated hyperpolarising potassium current, which enhances GABA-A receptor
  • Limits the activation of AMPA-kainate subtype of glutamate receptors.
  • Modulationof the activity of GABA and glutamate

Uses

  • Focal and primary generalized epilepsy
  • Refractory focal epilepsy
  • Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS)
  • Prophylaxis of migraine
  • Obesity

Pharmacokinetics

  • 20% is bound to plasma proteins
  • Excreted in urine unchanged with a t1/2 of 24 hours
  • Enzyme activation occurs

Adverse effects

  • Somnolence, weight loss, fatigue, nervousness
  • Renal calculi formation
  • Cognitive impairment

Treatment of acute migraine (Option A) is done using Triptans (sumatriptan, rizatriptan, and eletriptan) and NSAIDs (ibuprofen, naproxen sodium, and aspirin), while Topiramate is used as prophylaxis for migraine headaches.

Prophylaxis of ADHD (Option C) is done using stimulant drugs such as Methylphenidate and amphetamine salts. While Topiramate may have some use in ADHD treatment, it is not a first-line treatment for ADHD prophylaxis.

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for the treatment of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Pulmonary hypertension

  • Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of Pulmonary hypertension.
  • In pulmonary hypertension, the pulmonary arteries become narrowed or blocked.
  • Making it harder for blood to flow through them thus increasing the blood pressure within the pulmonary arterial circulation
  • The only FDA-approved medical therapeutic indication of Nitric Oxide is persistent pulmonary hypertension in newborns.

Nitric Oxide

Inhaled nitric oxide is a gas that is used to treat pulmonary hypertension because it acts as a potent vasodilator, meaning it relaxes the smooth muscle in the walls of the pulmonary arteries and improves blood flow.

MOA

Activation of guanylate cyclase, which converts guanosine triphosphate (GTP) to cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP)

cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle cells in the pulmonary arteries, leading to vasodilation of the vessels

Uses

Therapeutic indication

  • Pulmonary arterial hypertension
  • Rescue therapy for severely hypoxemic patients

 

Diagnostic indication

  • To evaluate pulmonary reactivity during cardiac catheterisation.
  • To determine diffusion capacity across the alveolar-capillary unit.

Adverse effects

  • Headache, nausea and vomiting
  • Methemoglobinemia
  • It may worsen left ventricular performance in those with impaired ventricular function.

questions.text: What is Remdesivir's mechanism of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - RNA-dependent RNA polymerase inhibition

  • Remdesivir acts by inhibiting RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It is an adenosine nucleotide prodrug.
  • It is metabolized into Remdesivir triphosphate (RDV-TP), which binds to viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase.
  • It inhibits viral replication via premature termination of RNA transcription.
  • Remdesivir is used to treat COVID-19 and may be considered in those patients who require supplemental oxygen within 10 days of the onset of illnes.s
  • Dose: 200 mg IV injection on day 1 followed by 100 mg IV daily for the next 4 days
  • Adverse effects
    • Hepatic enzyme elevation
    • Increased prothrombin time
    • Hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Contraindications of Remdesivir:
    • Renal impairment (eGRF <30ml/min/m2)
    • Hepatic impairment (AST/ALT > 5 times the upper normal limit)
    • Pregnancy or lactating women
    • Less than 12 years of age
    • Patients who are not on supplementary oxygen

RNA-dependent DNA polymerase inhibition (Option A) is associated with anti-retroviral drugs such as Zidovudine and Lamivudine that target retroviruses like HIV, which use reverse transcriptase to synthesise DNA from RNA.

Fusion inhibition (Option C), such as enfuvirtide, blocks the virus from entering host cells by preventing membrane fusion. Remdesivir acts after viral entry during the replication phase, not at the fusion step.

Entry inhibitors (Option D) such as Maraviroc block the virus's entry into host cells by targeting cellular receptors or viral proteins. Remdesivir works after the virus has entered the cell.

questions.text: The image given below is characteristically seen in which of the following types of leprosy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Borderline leprosy

Explanation:

Borderline leprosy is part of the spectrum of Hansen’s disease (leprosy) and is characterised by:

  • Variable number of hypopigmented or hyperpigmented lesions that are asymmetrically distributed.
  • Patchy partial loss of sensation within the lesions, a key diagnostic clue.
  • Borderline forms are unstable, and patients may shift toward either the lepromatous or tuberculoid pole.
  • Scalp involvement is uncommon in most forms of leprosy but can be seen in borderline cases.

Ridley-Jopling Classification of Leprosy:

  1. Tuberculoid leprosy (TT) – Few well-demarcated hypopigmented patches with complete loss of sensation. Strong cell-mediated immunity (CMI).
  2. Borderline tuberculoid (BT) – Multiple asymmetrical lesions, less well-defined than TT, with some sensory loss.
  3. Borderline leprosy (BB) – Intermediate form, variable lesions with partial sensory loss, and patchy nerve involvement.
  4. Borderline lepromatous (BL) – Numerous lesions resembling LL but with some sensory impairment.
  5. Lepromatous leprosy (LL) – Diffuse, symmetrical lesions with loss of eyebrows, leonine facies, and late nerve damage. Poor CMI response.

 

Borderline lepromatous leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because it shows more numerous lesions that resemble lepromatous leprosy but still have some sensory impairment. However, they are not as widespread as in full lepromatous leprosy.

Lepromatous leprosy (Option B) is incorrect because it presents with numerous, symmetrical macules, papules, or nodules with a loss of sensation late in the disease due to nerve involvement. Lesions lack the clear borders seen in borderline cases.

Histoid leprosy (Option D) is incorrect because it is a variant of lepromatous leprosy with shiny, smooth, well-demarcated nodules or plaques, commonly on the back, extremities, and face. It is seen in patients with dapsone resistance or relapsed leprosy.

questions.text: Which of the following will be the outcome of Leprosy , if left untreated.

choices.text: Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure
Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults
Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Indeterminate leprosy have more remission than tuberculoid

Explanation:

  • Indeterminate leprosy is the earliest form of leprosy, presenting with a single or few ill-defined hypopigmented macules and minimal sensory loss.
  • In many cases, spontaneous remission occurs, particularly in individuals with a strong cell-mediated immune (CMI) response.
  • Tuberculoid leprosy, while having a strong immune response, tends to be chronic and persistent, with less likelihood of spontaneous remission.

Indeterminate Leprosy:

  • Early, undifferentiated form of leprosy.
  • Few hypopigmented macules with slight sensory impairment.
  • Histopathology: Mild inflammation, sparse acid-fast bacilli (AFB).
  • Fate:
    • Can resolve spontaneously (~25–75% of cases).
    • May progress to tuberculoid or lepromatous forms, depending on immune response.

Tuberculoid Leprosy:

  • Well-demarcated plaques with sensory loss, few lesions.
  • Strong CMI response, granuloma formation.
  • Less likely to remit spontaneously, tends to persist unless treated.

Outcomes if Untreated:

  • Indeterminate leprosy has a higher chance of spontaneous remission compared to tuberculoid leprosy.
  • If it does not resolve, it may progress toward the tuberculoid or lepromatous spectrum based on immune status.

 

No spontaneous remission is seen (Option A) is incorrect because spontaneous remission does occur, particularly in indeterminate and early tuberculoid leprosy, especially in individuals with good immunity.

Half of the cases resolve spontaneously after bacilli exposure (Option B) is incorrect because while some individuals clear the infection, the proportion is variable and not as high as 50% in all populations.

Spontaneous remission is more common in children than in adults (Option C) is incorrect because although children may have a higher rate of spontaneous resolution, the likelihood of remission is more dependent on the type of leprosy (indeterminate vs tuberculoid) rather than age alone.

questions.text:
Inferior thyroid artery supplies which of the following structures?

1. Thyroid

2. Parathyroid

3. Esophagus

4. Thymus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1,2,3, and 4

Explanation:

The inferior thyroid artery, a branch of the thyrocervical trunk (from the subclavian artery), supplies multiple structures in the neck and thorax:

  • Thyroid gland (Primary blood supply to the posterior-inferior part).
  • Parathyroid glands (Main arterial supply).
  • Esophagus (Via esophageal branches).
  • Thymus (Via small branches extending into the upper thorax).

Since all four structures receive blood from the inferior thyroid artery, the correct answer is Option A (1,2,3, and 4).

 

Inferior Thyroid Artery

Feature

Details

Origin

Thyrocervical trunk (branch of subclavian artery)

Course

Ascends posterior to the carotid sheath, loops medially toward the thyroid

Branches

Ascending cervical artery (supplies prevertebral muscles)

Esophageal branches (to upper esophagus)

Tracheal branches (to trachea)

Inferior laryngeal artery (to larynx via recurrent laryngeal nerve)

Supplies

Thyroid gland (posterior part)

Parathyroid glands

Esophagus

Thymus

1,2, and 3 (Option B): Incorrect – Excludes thymus, which receives supply from the inferior thyroid artery.

1 and 2 only (Option C): Incorrect – Excludes esophagus and thymus, both of which receive supply from the inferior thyroid artery.

1,2, and 4 only (Option D): Incorrect – Excludes esophagus, which is supplied by esophageal branches of the inferior thyroid artery.

questions.text: Which of the following options should be excluded as a possible cause for the lesion seen in the image, developed by a forest officer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) KFD

Explanation:

  • The lesion described by a forest officer suggests an eschar-like lesion, which is commonly seen in scrub typhus, cutaneous anthrax, and brown recluse spider bites.
  • KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease) is a viral hemorrhagic fever caused by a Flavivirus, transmitted by ticks. It primarily affects forest workers but does not cause eschar formation. Instead, it presents with fever, myalgia, haemorrhagic manifestations, and meningoencephalitis.
  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a tick-borne viral disease (Flavivirus) endemic to forests in South India.
  • Transmission: By Haemaphysalis ticks from infected rodents, monkeys, and livestock.

 

Monkey fever/Kyasanur forest disease:

General features:

  • Virus Characteristics: Enveloped virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae; contains single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • Vector: Hard ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera)
  • Hosts: Monkeys, rodents, and squirrels are common hosts; monkeys act as amplifier hosts where the virus multiplies exponentially.
  • Seasonality: KFD cases peak during dry months (November to June), coinciding with increased human activity in forests.

 

 

The life cycle of Kyasanur forest disease

Clinical features:

  • Incubation Period: 3-8 days.
  • First Stage (Hemorrhagic Fever):
    • Acute high fever with malaise and frontal headaches.
    • Hemorrhagic symptoms: bleeding from the nasal cavity, throat, gums, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Second Stage: Meningoencephalitis may occur 7–21 days after the first stage.

 

Lab diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis Methods:
    • Virus isolation from blood.
    • IgM antibody detection by ELISA.
    • RT-PCR.

 

Vaccination:

  • Vaccine Type: Killed KFD vaccine (formalin-inactivated chick embryo) developed at Haffkine Institute, Mumbai.
  • Vaccination Schedule:
    • Initial two doses at 2-month intervals.
    • Booster doses at 6–9 months, then every 5 years.
  • Target Area: Recommended for endemic areas of Karnataka.

 

Vector

Diseases transmitted

Sandfly

Kala-azar

Oriental sore

Sandfly fever (Papatasi fever)

Flea

Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis nana

Bubonic plague

Endemic typhus

Louse

Epidemic relapsing fever

Epidemic typhus

Trench fever

Hard tick

Babesiosis

Kyasanur Forest disease virus (Option B)

Colorado tick fever virus

Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus

Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever virus

Tularemia

Lyme disease

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Indian tick typhus

Ehrlichiosis

Soft tick

Endemic relapsing fever

Reduvid bug

Chagas’ disease

 

 

Scrub typhus (Option A) is incorrect because it is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and commonly presents with an eschar at the site of a chigger bite. This is a hallmark of the disease.

Cutaneous anthrax (Option C) is incorrect because Bacillus anthracis causes painless black eschars with surrounding oedema. It is common in individuals handling animal products or exposed to spores in the environment.

Healing brown recluse spider bite (Option D) is incorrect because brown recluse spider bites can cause necrotic ulcers that heal over time, mimicking an eschar.

questions.text: The marked structure develops from which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Supracardinal vein

Explanation:

The marked structure is the azygos vein, which develops primarily from the right supracardinal vein during embryogenesis.

  • The supracardinal veins appear in the embryo as part of the venous system and contribute to the formation of azygos and hemiazygos veins.
  • The right supracardinal vein persists to form the azygos vein, which drains blood from the posterior thoracic wall.
  • The left supracardinal vein contributes to the hemiazygos vein, which drains into the azygos system.

Thus, the correct answer is Option C (Supracardinal vein).

Venous System Development

Embryonic Vein

Adult Derivative

Common cardinal vein

Contributes to superior vena cava (SVC)

Anterior cardinal vein

Forms jugular veins and part of SVC

Supracardinal vein

Azygos and hemiazygos veins

Subcardinal vein

Renal veins, gonadal veins, and part of IVC

 

Common cardinal vein (Option A): Incorrect – Contributes to the formation of the superior vena cava (SVC) but not the azygos vein.

Anterior cardinal vein (Option B): Incorrect – Develops into internal jugular veins and part of the SVC, not the azygos system.

Subcardinal vein (Option D): Incorrect – Primarily forms renal veins and parts of the inferior vena cava (IVC), not the azygos vein.

questions.text: A patient after a road traffic accident presents to the emergency room with difficulty in swallowing and slurred speech. Investigations reveal fractures in the occipitotemporal region. Which of the following areas should be tested in order to find the nerve which is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 2

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) and dysarthria (slurred speech) after a road traffic accident with fractures in the occipitotemporal region.
  • These symptoms suggest injury to the vagus nerve (CN X), which controls motor function of the larynx and pharynx.
  • Option B (2) is correct because this area corresponds to the oropharynx, where CN IX (Glossopharyngeal) and CN X (Vagus) can be tested.
  • Injury to the jugular foramen (through which CN IX, X, and XI pass) can lead to loss of gag reflex, hoarseness, and swallowing difficulty.

Cranial Nerve Involvement in Dysphagia & Dysarthria

Cranial Nerve

Function

Clinical Signs of Injury

Glossopharyngeal (IX)

Sensory to oropharynx, motor to stylopharyngeus

Loss of gag reflex, impaired swallowing

Vagus (X)

Motor to larynx, pharynx, soft palate

Hoarseness, dysphagia, absent gag reflex

Hypoglossal (XII)

Motor to tongue muscles

Tongue deviation to lesion side, slurred speech
  • Testing the oropharynx (Option 2) helps assess Glossopharyngeal and Vagus nerve function since both are responsible for swallowing and speech.

 

1 (Option A) – Incorrect: The cribriform plate is associated with CN I (Olfactory nerve), involved in smell, not speech or swallowing.

3 (Option C) – Incorrect: The tongue is controlled mainly by CN XII (Hypoglossal), which affects tongue movements but not swallowing reflex.

4 (Option D) – Incorrect: The larynx is controlled by CN X, but primary motor function testing for swallowing is done at the oropharynx (Option 2).

questions.text: What is the appropriate course of action following the observation of cigarette burn marks on the forearm of a 14-year-old girl who presents to a doctor with a fractured forearm, claiming to have fallen and hit her hand?

choices.text: To do a complete physical examination
To tell or discuss with colleagues that she is a case of abuse
To call local social worker for help

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) To do a complete physical examination

Explanation:

  • The discovery of cigarette burns suggests the possibility of abuse. A complete physical examination is essential to assess all injuries and document any signs of abuse. This is the first step in ensuring the child's safety and gathering evidence for further investigation.

questions.text: A young woman has presented to the OPD with facial symptoms (acne or pimple-like lesions). Which of the following options will not be effective for treating these symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical fluocinolone

Explanation:

  • Fluocinolone is a topical corticosteroid, which is not recommended for acne.
  • Corticosteroids can worsen acne by promoting follicular occlusion, increasing sebum production, and causing steroid-induced acne.
  • Acne treatment focuses on reducing inflammation, controlling bacterial overgrowth, and regulating keratinisation, which fluocinolone does not address.
  • Acne vulgaris is a chronic inflammatory condition affecting the pilosebaceous units.

Pathophysiology:

  1. Increased sebum production (hormonal influence).
  2. Follicular hyperkeratinisation (plug formation).
  3. Bacterial colonisation (Cutibacterium acnes proliferation).
  4. Inflammation (leading to papules, pustules, nodules).

Treatment Approach:

Type of Acne

Treatment

Comedonal acne

Topical retinoids (tretinoin, adapalene, tazarotene)

Mild inflammatory acne

Topical benzoyl peroxide, topical antibiotics (clindamycin, erythromycin)

Moderate-severe acne

Oral antibiotics (doxycycline, minocycline), combination therapy

Severe nodulocystic acne

Oral isotretinoin (vitamin A derivative)

 

Why Steroids Are Not Recommended:

  • Topical corticosteroids (like fluocinolone) can lead to:
    • Steroid-induced acne (monomorphic papules, no comedones).
    • Skin atrophy and telangiectasia with long-term use.
    • Rebound flare-ups upon discontinuation.

 

Topical benzoyl peroxide (Option A) is incorrect because benzoyl peroxide is an effective first-line treatment for acne. It has antibacterial properties (against Cutibacterium acnes), reduces inflammation, and prevents antibiotic resistance when used with topical antibiotics.

Topical tazarotene (Option C) is incorrect because tazarotene is a topical retinoid that promotes keratinocyte turnover, prevents comedone formation, and reduces acne lesions. It is highly effective in treating acne.

Topical antibiotics (Option D) is incorrect because antibiotics like clindamycin and erythromycin reduce C. acnes growth and inflammation. They are commonly used in combination with benzoyl peroxide to prevent resistance.

questions.text: Through which of the following marked sites does COVID 19 spread to the brain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) A

Explanation:

  • COVID-19 can spread to the brain through the cribriform plate of the ethmoid bone (marked as A in the image).
  • The olfactory nerve (CN I) passes through this region, providing a direct route for SARS-CoV-2 to reach the brain.
  • This explains why anosmia (loss of smell) is one of the early neurological symptoms in COVID-19 patients.
  • The virus can travel along the olfactory nerve fibers to the olfactory bulb, leading to further neurological symptoms.

COVID-19 Neuroinvasion

Route

Mechanism

Clinical Implications

Olfactory Route

Virus enters via nasal mucosa, travels through cribriform plate to the olfactory bulb

Anosmia, encephalopathy

Hematogenous Route

Viral entry through blood-brain barrier via infected endothelial cells

Stroke, brain inflammation

Lymphatic Route

Virus spreads via lymphatics from the nasopharynx

Meningitis-like symptoms

 

D- Foramen Ovale (Option A) – Incorrect: Transmits mandibular nerve (V3) and does not provide a route for viral spread.

C- Clinoid Process (Option B) – Incorrect: Bony projection of the sphenoid bone, not associated with olfactory transmission.

B- Optic Canal (Option C) – Incorrect: Located near the optic canal, which is not the primary route for SARS-CoV-2 entry.

questions.text: What is the cause of death in smoke inhalation ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Anemic hypoxia

Explanation:

  • The primary cause of death in smoke inhalation is anemic hypoxia, which occurs due to the inability of hemoglobin to effectively transport oxygen to tissues. This condition can arise from carbon monoxide (CO) poisoning, a common consequence of smoke inhalation. CO has a much higher affinity for hemoglobin than oxygen, which leads to reduced oxygen delivery to vital organs, ultimately causing systemic hypoxia and potential organ failure.

Incorrect Options:

Histotoxic hypoxia (Option A) occurs when cells are unable to effectively use oxygen, often due to the presence of toxic substances, such as cyanide. While cyanide can be released during combustion, histotoxic hypoxia is not the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation. The main mechanism of death in smoke inhalation is related to the impaired ability of hemoglobin to carry oxygen, as seen in anemic hypoxia.

Ischemic hypoxia (Option B) results from inadequate blood flow to tissues, which can lead to a shortage of oxygen supply. In severe cases of smoke inhalation, respiratory failure could reduce oxygen perfusion to tissues, but this is not the primary cause of death in most cases of smoke inhalation. The main issue is the impaired oxygen binding by hemoglobin due to carbon monoxide (CO), leading to anemic hypoxia.

All of the above (Option D): While histotoxic hypoxia and ischemic hypoxia can be involved in some cases of smoke inhalation (especially if toxic gases like cyanide are present), anemic hypoxia is the primary cause of death in smoke inhalation due to the carbon monoxide (CO) binding to hemoglobin. Therefore, "All of the above" is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A patient presents with the following lesions on the genitals. Scrapings from the lesion would show?

choices.text: Cells with clear halo around the nucleus

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tzanck cells

Explanation:

  • Tzanck cells are multinucleated giant cells seen in herpes simplex virus (HSV) and varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infections.
  • Genital lesions caused by HSV-1 or HSV-2 typically present as painful vesicles that rupture to form ulcers.
  • Tzanck smear from lesion scrapings shows multinucleated giant cells with acantholysis, confirming HSV infection.
  • HSV-1 and HSV-2 cause genital and orolabial herpes, with HSV-2 being more commonly associated with genital lesions.

Clinical Features of Genital Herpes:

  • Painful grouped vesicles on an erythematous base
  • Vesicles rupture to form shallow ulcers
  • Pain, burning, dysuria
  • Recurrent episodes (especially in immunocompromised individuals)

Diagnosis of HSV:

  • Tzanck smear: Shows multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells) but cannot differentiate between HSV-1 and HSV-2.
  • PCR: Most sensitive and specific test for HSV.
  • DFA (Direct Fluorescent Antibody test): Detects viral antigens.

Management of HSV:

  • First-line therapy: Oral antivirals (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir).
  • Supportive care: Pain relief, hydration, avoiding triggers for recurrence.

 

Cells with clear halo around the nucleus (Option B) is incorrect because this refers to koilocytes, which are seen in human papillomavirus (HPV) infections (genital warts).

Molluscum bodies (Option C) is incorrect because these are Henderson-Patterson bodies, seen in molluscum contagiosum. They appear as intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions in affected keratinocytes.

HP bodies (Option D) is incorrect because HP (Hailey-Penrose) bodies are associated with Hailey-Hailey disease, a rare genetic blistering disorder, and are not found in genital lesions.

questions.text: In a 17-year-old patient, the most distinctive and characteristic indicator of juvenile dermatomyositis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Gottron’s papules

Explanation:

  • Gottron’s papules are the most distinctive and characteristic feature of juvenile dermatomyositis (JDM).
  • They appear as violaceous, scaly papules symmetrically distributed over bony prominences, especially the knuckles, elbows, and knees.
  • This is a hallmark finding in both juvenile and adult dermatomyositis and helps distinguish it from other connective tissue diseases.
  • JDM is a rare autoimmune inflammatory myopathy affecting children, characterised by proximal muscle weakness and distinctive skin rashes.

Clinical Features:

  • Muscle involvement:
    • Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness (difficulty climbing stairs, rising from a chair).
    • Gower’s sign may be positive in severe cases.
  • Cutaneous manifestations:
    • Gottron’s papules (violaceous papules over knuckles, elbows, knees).
    • Heliotrope rash (violaceous discolouration around eyelids).
    • Nailfold capillary abnormalities (dilated capillary loops, dropout).
    • Photosensitivity and facial erythema.
  • Systemic involvement:
    • Dysphagia, interstitial lung disease, calcinosis cutis (in chronic cases).

Diagnosis:

  • Raised muscle enzymes: CK, aldolase.
  • MRI (muscle oedema), EMG (myopathic changes).
  • Muscle biopsy: Perifascicular atrophy, inflammatory infiltrates.
  • ANA, anti-Mi-2, anti-MDA5 antibodies (useful in subtypes).

Management:

  • First-line: Corticosteroids (prednisolone) with methotrexate or azathioprine.
  • IVIG, rituximab in refractory cases.
  • Physiotherapy to prevent contractures.

 

Photosensitive skin rash (Option A) is incorrect because while photosensitivity is common in JDM, it is not specific and can be seen in other autoimmune conditions like lupus erythematosus.

Nail bed capillary changes (Option B) is incorrect because abnormal nailfold capillaries (dilated capillary loops, dropout) occur in JDM but are not as distinctive as Gottron’s papules. They are also seen in systemic sclerosis.

Malar rash (Option D) is incorrect because a malar rash is more characteristic of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE), not JDM. Although JDM can have facial erythema, it does not spare the nasolabial folds, unlike the butterfly rash in lupus.

questions.text: Bullet fingerprinting involve:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Both

Explanation:

  • Primary markings on bullets include the number, diameter, and width of lands and grooves (striations) and the degree of rifling twist.
  • Surface irregularities serve as secondary markings.
  • These markings allow forensic experts to connect bullets from a crime scene to a specific firearm, aiding in criminal investigations.

Primary Markings (Class characteristics)

Secondary Markings (Individual or accidental characteristics)
  • Determined by manufacturing specifications, design, and dimensions are most useful for identifying the make and model of the firearm involved.
  • It consists of:
    • Number, diameter and width of lands and grooves
    • Depth of grooves
    • Direction and degree of rifling twist

Surface irregularities on the bullet result from imperfections in the barrel and the adhesion of bullet particles to the bore during firing (Metallic Fouling).

It may be identical for bullets fired by two different weapons.

These are different for bullets fired by two different weapons, reflecting each firearm's distinct barrel characteristics.

It's more pronounced for jacketed bullets.

It is more pronounced when the grooves deeply mark the lead bullet.


The bullet found in the body, called the crime bullet, is compared under a Comparison Microscope with a test bullet fired from a suspected weapon (using the same brand and type of ammunition).

questions.text: A patient who has taken the first COVID vaccine comes for the second dose. An astute nurse noticed that the shoulder was flabby, flat, and was asymmetrical. There was an associated loss of contour of the shoulder joint. Injury to which of the structures might have resulted and was avoidable?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Axillary nerve

Explanation:

  • The axillary nerve (C5-C6) is vulnerable to injury during intramuscular injections in the deltoid muscle, especially if injected too low or too deep.
  • Injury results in:
    • Flattening of the shoulder (loss of deltoid muscle bulk).
    • Loss of shoulder contour (due to deltoid atrophy).
    • Weakness in abduction beyond 15° (deltoid function loss).
    • Sensory loss over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area).
  • Prevention: Intramuscular injections should be given in the upper lateral quadrant of the deltoid to avoid axillary nerve injury.

Axillary Nerve Injury

Aspect

Details

Origin

Arises from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5-C6).

Course

Passes through quadrangular space with the posterior circumflex humeral artery.

Motor Supply

Deltoid muscle (shoulder abduction) and teres minor (external rotation).

Sensory Supply

Skin over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area) via the superior lateral cutaneous nerve of the arm.

Common Causes of Injury

Improper intramuscular injection, shoulder dislocation, humeral surgical neck fracture.

Clinical Features

Shoulder atrophy, loss of contour, weakness in abduction, and sensory loss over the deltoid region.

 

 

Rotator cuff (Option A) - Incorrect: Involved in shoulder stability but does not cause loss of shoulder contour when injured.

Posterior circumflex artery (Option B) - Incorrect: Runs with the axillary nerve but its injury would cause vascular compromise, not motor weakness.

Lateral cutaneous nerve of arm (Option C) - Incorrect: Only provides sensory innervation; it does not affect shoulder shape or movement.

questions.text: Which organization is related to the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Child and welfare committees

Explanation:

  • Under the Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act, Child and Welfare Committees play a key role in addressing and responding to cases of child sexual abuse. They are responsible for ensuring the safety and protection of children and ensuring that appropriate actions are taken when cases of abuse are reported. The committees work with various authorities to ensure the welfare of the child victim and provide necessary support services.

Protection of Children from Sexual Offences (POCSO) Act

  • Enacted in 2012, it is law in India designed to protect children under the age of 18 from sexual abuse, sexual harassment, and pornography.

Key Features of the POCSO Act:

  • Gender-neutral law
  • It covers penetrative and non-penetrative assault, sexual harassment, and use of children for pornography
  • Burden of proof is on the accused, unlike many other criminal laws where the burden is on the prosecution
  • Mandatory reporting by adults and failure to do so can be punishable
  • Special courts for the trial of offenses to ensure a child-friendly environment
  • Identity of the victim is to be protected, and the proceedings are to be conducted in camera to prevent exposure

Recent Changes and Developments in the POCSO Act:

  • 2019 Amendment
    • Stricter Punishments: Death penalty for aggravated sexual assault against children
    • The minimum punishment for penetrative sexual assault increased to 10 years, and for aggravated penetrative sexual assault increased to 20 years, with the possibility of life imprisonment or death in extreme cases.
  • Fast-track Courts to ensure swift disposal of POCSO cases, given the backlog of pending cases.
  • Clarifications on ‘Touch’ and Sexual Intent:
    • The intent behind physical contact is crucial in determining whether it qualifies as an offense under POCSO.
  • Digital Crimes Against Children:
    • Provisions related to the use of children for pornographic and online exploitation purposes have been emphasized with stricter penalties.

Incorrect Options:

Women and child safety department (Option B): While this department focuses on general safety measures, it does not directly implement the POCSO Act.

Children rights protection committee (Option C): This committee works on children's rights but is not specifically responsible for the enforcement of the POCSO Act.

All of the above (Option D): Not all these organizations are directly linked to the POCSO Act, so this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A woman with right-sided loss of sensations of both the upper and lower limb complains of shooting pain from her fingers to the right shoulder and a burning sensation when touching cold water. Motor functions are normal. Which of the following structures is likely to be involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) B

Explanation:

The lateral spinothalamic tract carries pain and temperature sensations. The patient has loss of sensation in both upper and lower limbs, shooting pain, and a burning sensation when touching cold water, indicating damage to this pathway. Motor function is intact, ruling out motor tract involvement.

Lateral Spinothalamic Tract

Feature

Description

Function

Transmits pain and temperature sensations

Decussation (Crossing)

Crosses to the opposite side at the level of entry in the spinal cord

Pathway

Ascends in the spinal cord → synapses in the thalamus → projects to the sensory cortex

Lesion Effects

Contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion

 

Dorsal Horn (Option A) - Incorrect: It processes sensory information but does not transmit pain and temperature to higher centers. Lesion here would cause segmental sensory loss, not widespread involvement.

Ventral Horn (Option C) - Incorrect: Contains lower motor neurons, so a lesion here would cause motor weakness or paralysis, which is absent in this case.

Dorsal Root Ganglion (Option D) - Incorrect: Damage would result in dermatomal sensory loss, not the widespread sensory deficit seen in this patient.

questions.text: If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they must provide the patient's records promptly upon request, within:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 72 hours

Explanation:

  • If a healthcare professional is found guilty of professional misconduct, they are required to provide the patient’s records within 72 hours upon request. This timeframe is mandated to ensure that patients have timely access to their medical information when needed.
  • If a healthcare professional fails to maintain medical records of indoor patients for 3 years and refuses to provide them within 72 hours upon the patient's request, it constitutes a violation of professional conduct and legal requirements.


48 hours (Option B), 24 hours (Option C), & 7 days (Option D) are all incorrect options. A 72-hour period is the correct legal limit for healthcare professionals to submit the records following misconduct allegations.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about the given condition except:

choices.text: Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water
It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines
There are fewer chances of bacterial infections

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) There are fewer chances of bacterial infections

Explanation:

  • Human bites are actually prone to bacterial infections, often due to the mouth's normal flora, which includes bacteria like Streptococcus, Staphylococcus, and Eikenella corrodens. These bacteria can easily be transferred during a bite, leading to a higher risk of infection.

The other statements are true:

  • Swabs should be taken immediately after moistening with sterile water (Option A): This helps in proper wound care to prevent infection.
  • It is most commonly caused by incisors and canines (Option B): Human bites are most often inflicted by the sharp teeth in the mouth.
  • Tetanus vaccination should be given (Option D): If the bite is severe or if the person hasn't had a tetanus booster in the last 10 years, a tetanus shot is advised.

questions.text: Below is an image of the coagulation cascade activation following closed endothelial injury. Identify the factor ‘L’, which combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Factor VII

Explanation:

Factor VII (Proconvertin) combines with tissue factor to activate factor IX in the Coagulation Cascade following closed endothelial injury.

  • When tissue factor is exposed due to endothelial injury, it forms a complex with Factor VII. This complex activates Factor IX by cleaving it to Factor IXa, which then participates in the coagulation cascade.

 

Factor XII (Hageman factor) (Option A) is involved in the initiation of the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. It is not directly responsible for activating factor IX in response to closed endothelial injury.

Factor VIII (antihemophilic factor A) (Option C) plays a crucial role in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade. However, it is not involved in the direct activation of factor IX in response to closed endothelial injury.

vWF (von Willebrand factor) (Option D) is a glycoprotein that plays a vital role in platelet adhesion and aggregation. It is not directly involved in activating factor IX in the coagulation cascade following closed endothelial injury.

questions.text: When an individual commences employment with a second employer, the new employer assumes responsibility for the individual's actions, under which doctrine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Borrowed servant doctrine

Explanation:

  • The Borrowed Servant Doctrine refers to a situation where an employee is temporarily transferred from one employer to work under the direction and control of another employer.
  • In this case, the new employer assumes responsibility for the employee’s actions while they are under their supervision.
  • Essentially, even though the employee remains on the payroll of the original employer, the new employer has control over the employee’s work and, therefore, is liable for the employee's actions while they are working for them.

Vicarious Liability/ Respondeat Superior

  • Employers are liable for the negligent acts of their employees under certain conditions. Also called the Master-Servant rule.
  • Conditions:
    1. Employer-employee relationship.
    2. Conduct occurs within the scope of employment.
    3. Incident occurs while on the job.
  • Principal doctors can be held responsible for the negligence of their assistants.
  • Temporary Relationships: Surgeons assisting each other may create an employer-employee relationship thus being liable for each other's actions.
  • Borrowed Servant Doctrine: An employee can serve multiple employers (e.g., a nurse assisting a surgeon is a "borrowed servant" during surgery). Negligence occurring due to borrowing of temporary staff from another department.
  • Hospital Liability: Hospitals are liable for the acts of employees under their supervision, but not for senior staff if due care in hiring is proven.
  • Direct Supervision: Physicians are responsible for the acts of interns and residents they supervise.
  • Defense Against Liability: Employers can avoid liability by proving the employee was not negligent or was acting outside the scope of employment.

Incorrect Options:

Vicarious liability (Option A): While this doctrine does involve holding an employer responsible for the actions of an employee, it generally refers to the principal employer's responsibility for their own employees' actions, rather than the responsibility when an employee is temporarily working for another employer.

Doctrine of negligent choice (Option B): This refers to the liability of an employer for hiring an individual who is unfit or negligent in their duties, leading to harm or injury. It does not relate to the responsibility of the new employer for the employee's actions once employed.

Contributory negligence (Option C): This is a defense in tort law where the injured party’s own negligence contributes to their injury. It does not pertain to the responsibility of an employer for an employee’s actions.

questions.text: What type of MRI image is given below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Susceptibility weighted image

Explanation:

This MRI sequence is highly sensitive to magnetic susceptibility differences between tissues. It exploits differences in the magnetic properties of tissues or substances, such as blood products, calcium, or iron deposition. SWI is particularly useful for detecting microbleeds, haemorrhage, venous malformations, and calcifications.

  • Susceptibility-weighted imaging (SWI) is an advanced MRI technique that enhances the visibility of tissues based on magnetic susceptibility differences.
  • It is highly sensitive for detecting microbleeds (common in hypertension), iron deposits (seen in neurodegenerative diseases and hemorrhagic lesions), and calcifications.
  • Black dots on SWI indicate areas of Microbleeds/Iron deposition/Calcification.
  • CSF appears dark, not bright.

 

 

Proton density image (option A): This is incorrect because proton density imaging emphasises the number of hydrogen nuclei per tissue volume and is not sensitive to susceptibility differences.

Gradient echo image (option C): This is incorrect because while gradient echo sequences are somewhat sensitive to magnetic susceptibility, they lack the resolution and phase-processing techniques of SWI.

Inversion recovery image (option D): This is incorrect because inversion recovery sequences are used for suppressing specific tissue signals (e.g., fat or fluid) and are not focused on magnetic susceptibility differences.

questions.text: Identify the given condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Pemphigus Vulgaris

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image shows Pemphigus Vulgaris (PV), with intraepidermal cleavage and acantholysis in the suprabasal layer, along with a "row of tombstones" appearance due to the separation of basal keratinocytes at the basement membrane zone.
  • It is the most common chronic autoimmune blistering disease caused by antibodies against desmosomal adhesion proteins.
  • The target antigens for PV are most commonly Desmoglein 3 and sometimes Desmoglein 1.
  • Clinical features:
    • Flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid present on normal skin or an erythematous base.
    • The blisters rupture, producing painful erosion.
  • Mucosal involvement is a very important and one of the distinguishing features of PV.
  • Histopathology:
    • Intraepidermal cleavage with acantholysis (detached keratinocytes) primarily localized to the suprabasal region.
    • Separation of basal keratinocytes along the basement membrane zone, resulting in an appearance that resembles a "row of tombstones".

Leprosy (Option B), also known as Hansen's disease, is a chronic infection caused by Mycobacterium leprae, affecting the skin, peripheral nerves, and mucous membranes. Tuberculous leprosy shows granulomatous lesions similar to tuberculosis, while lepromatous leprosy features lipid-laden macrophages (lepra cells) containing "globi" of acid-fast bacilli.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C) is the most common type of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma. It presents with a variety of skin lesions, including patches, plaques, and tumours. Histologically, the epidermis and upper dermis are infiltrated by neoplastic T cells, which often have a cerebriform appearance due to marked infolding of the nuclear membrane.

Visceral leishmaniasis (Option D), also known as kala-azar, is a systemic parasitic infection caused by Leishmania species. It is characterized by granulomatous inflammation, phagocytosed parasites, hyperplasia of the reticuloendothelial system, necrosis with fibrosis, and hemophagocytosis, where macrophages engulf red blood cells, white blood cells, or platelets.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male was brought to the emergency room after being involved in a car accident. During the examination, his Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score was E2M2V3. There were no fractures, hydrocephalus, or increased pressure within the skull. A non-contrast CT scan was conducted and revealed no abnormalities. The suspected diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Diffuse axonal injury

Explanation:

  • The patient’s Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of E2M2V3 indicates a severe alteration in consciousness, likely due to diffuse brain injury. Non-contrast CT may show no abnormalities, especially in the early stages of diffuse axonal injury, which primarily affects the white matter of the brain. This injury is commonly seen in traumatic brain injury (TBI), especially in high-velocity accidents like car crashes. Clinical signs such as altered consciousness, coma, and normal CT findings are suggestive of diffuse axonal injury.

Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)

  • A form of primary brain injury caused by widespread damage to axons due to rotational acceleration and deceleration forces, often associated with high-energy trauma.

Causes:

  • Rotational forces: High-energy accidents involving rapid acceleration and deceleration (e.g., motor vehicle collisions).
  • Trauma: Blunt force impacts that cause the brain to rotate within the skull.

Clinical Features:

  • Impaired arousal: Often presents as coma or reduced consciousness due to damage in critical brain areas (e.g., pontine reticular activating system, bilateral thalami).
  • Neurological deficits: Poor neurological examination, despite the absence of obvious radiographic global brain injury.
  • Irreversible consequences: DAI is often associated with severe and lasting neurological impairment.

Investigations:

  • CT scan: May show hemorrhagic foci in the corpus callosum and dorsolateral rostral brainstem in severe cases.
  • MRI:
    • More sensitive than CT.
    • It shows small haemorrhages and diffuse axonal injury, particularly in patients who fail to improve neurologically.
  • Postmortem examination: Confirms the diagnosis with axonal disruption and formation of axon balls.

Prognosis: Very poor due to high risk of severe disability or death due to extensive brain damage.

 

Post-concussion syndrome (option B): This is incorrect because post-concussion syndrome typically develops days to weeks after a mild traumatic brain injury and usually presents with headaches, dizziness, and cognitive issues. The acute severe presentation in this case, especially the GCS of 7 (severe impairment), is more consistent with a diffuse axonal injury.

Extradural haemorrhage (option C): This is incorrect because an extradural haemorrhage usually appears on CT as a lens-shaped, hyperdense collection of blood and typically presents with a history of skull fracture. In this case, the CT scan was normal.

Herniation of brain (option D): This is incorrect because herniation typically results in changes on CT, such as midline shift or loss of brain structures, which were not observed in the scan. Additionally, herniation would likely present with clinical signs such as pupillary dilation or abnormal posturing, none of which are described here.

questions.text: Which imaging technique is preferred for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism in a woman who presented with confusion, constipation, and headache, and has elevated serum calcium (13.1 mg/dL) and ALP levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sestamibi scan

Explanation:

  • This is the preferred imaging technique for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism, especially when the patient is suspected to have a parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia. The sestamibi scan uses a radiotracer that is taken up by the parathyroid glands, particularly in the presence of adenomas or hyperplasia. It is highly sensitive and specific for detecting parathyroid pathology. Elevated calcium levels and ALP, along with the clinical symptoms, suggest primary hyperparathyroidism, making a sestamibi scan the most appropriate next step.

 

Radiological features of Primary Hyperparathyroidism:

Features

Image

Subperiosteal erosions and terminal resorption in the phalanges (usually starts in the middle phalanx of the index finger's radial side) along with bone demineralisation.

The "salt and pepper" appearance, or pepper pot skull (lytic lesions in the skull).

 

 

Brown tumour or osteitis fibrosa cystica: Cystic lesions in bone from excessive osteoclastic resorption appear as low-density, multiloculated cysts that can lead to bone expansion, accompanied by bleeding and granulation tissue.

Sestamibi scan (Tc-99): Localize the tumour.

 

MRI (option A): This is not typically used for the initial diagnosis of primary hyperparathyroidism. MRI may be used for further evaluation if other imaging modalities are inconclusive.

FDG PET (option B): This is primarily used for oncology, such as detecting malignancies or metastases, and is not routinely used for diagnosing primary hyperparathyroidism.

CT (option C): CT can be used in some cases to localize parathyroid adenomas, but it is less sensitive than a sestamibi scan and is not the first-line imaging modality for primary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is accurate concerning CORADS? CORADS: COVID-19 Reporting and Data System

choices.text: Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19
Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) CORADS-5 is typical of COVID- 19

Explanation:

  • The COVID-19 Reporting and Data System (CORADS) is a standardized system for assessing the probability of COVID-19 pneumonia based on CT findings. CORADS-5 indicates a very high level of suspicion for COVID-19, with features such as bilateral ground-glass opacities, crazy paving patterns, and subpleural involvement—typical imaging findings in COVID-19 pneumonia.

 

CO-RADS (COVID-19 Reporting and Data System):

Aspect

Details

Purpose

Categorical assessment of chest CT scans for suspected COVID-19 cases

Scale

CO-RADS 1 (very low suspicion) to CO-RADS 5 (very high suspicion)

Interobserver Agreement

Moderate to substantial agreement among radiologists

Discriminatory Power

High accuracy in diagnosing COVID-19

Utility & Reliability

Effective and standardized reporting tool

CO-RADS-AI

AI-based tool that automates CO-RADS scoring and CT severity assessment

Accuracy

Effective in high-prevalence areas

Combination with Other Findings

AUC value of 0.89 when used with RT-PCR and clinical findings

 

CORADS-0 indicates normal lung (option A): This is incorrect because CORADS-0 is used when the scan is technically insufficient or of poor quality, and not for a normal lung.\

Pleural thickening is typical of COVID-19 (option C): This is incorrect because pleural thickening is not a typical finding in COVID-19 pneumonia; it is more common in chronic lung diseases or other infections.

Lobar consolidation is typical of COVID-19 (option D): This is incorrect because lobar consolidation is more typical of bacterial pneumonia, whereas COVID-19 pneumonia usually shows patchy ground-glass opacities and consolidation.

questions.text: A person was brought to the emergency department with facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting. The mentioned clinical features are due to an increase in which immunoglobulin?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) IgE

Explanation:

  • The clinical features of facial swelling, itching, and hypotension following a bee sting are due to an Allergic Reaction (Type 1 Hypersensitivity Reaction) mediated by the immune system, particularly through IgE (Immunoglobulin E) antibodies.
  • IgE plays a key role in allergic responses by binding to receptors on mast cells and basophils after exposure to an allergen, like bee venom.
  • Upon re-exposure to the allergen, it binds to IgE on mast cells and basophils, triggering the release of histamine, leukotrienes, and prostaglandins, which cause the symptoms.
  • Symptoms: Characteristic symptoms of an allergic reaction are:
    • Facial swelling (angioedema)
    • Itching, and
    • Hypotension.
  • Histamine causes blood vessel dilation and increased permeability, leading to facial swelling and itching. In severe cases, it can induce hypotension and trigger anaphylaxis.

 

IgA (Option A) is primarily involved in mucosal immunity, protecting the mucous membranes of the respiratory, digestive, and genitourinary tracts. It is not typically associated with immediate hypersensitivity reactions like those seen in response to bee stings.

IgM (Option C) is the first antibody produced during an immune response. It is involved in the primary immune response and is not specifically associated with allergic reactions or the symptoms described in the scenario.

IgG (Option D) is the most abundant antibody in the bloodstream and is involved in long-term immunity. While IgG can play a role in some types of allergic reactions, it is not the primary immunoglobulin responsible for the immediate hypersensitivity reactions seen in response to a bee sting.

questions.text: Which phase of the cell cycle displays the highest resistance to radiation among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) S phase

Explanation:

  • The S phase of the cell cycle is the most radioresistant phase. During this phase, the DNA is actively being replicated, and mechanisms for DNA repair are highly active, providing protection against radiation-induced damage.

 

M phase (option B): This is incorrect because the M phase (mitosis) is the most radiosensitive phase due to the condensed state of chromosomes and limited time for DNA repair mechanisms to function.

G1 phase (option C): This is incorrect because cells in the G1 phase are moderately sensitive to radiation. However, their sensitivity depends on whether they are preparing for DNA synthesis.

G2 phase (option D): This is incorrect because the G2 phase is also a radiosensitive phase, as the cell prepares for mitosis and DNA repair capacity is lower than in the S phase.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with scrotal swelling and ataxia. Which among the following could likely be a cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

Explanation:

  • The case scenario of a 60-year-old man with scrotal swelling and ataxia is likely diagnosed as Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma (NHL), where lymphatic obstruction causes scrotal swelling, and CNS involvement leads to ataxia.
  • It is a type of cancer originating from lymphocytes and is characterized by the growth of lymphoid tissue.
  • Clinical features:
    • Asymptomatic Palpable Lymphadenopathy is the hallmark (neck, armpits, or groin).
    • Lymphadenopathy is not rapidly progressive.
    • B Symptoms (Fever, Night sweats, and Weight loss)
    • Extranodal involvement
      • Ileocecal region (abdominal pain or changes in bowel habits).
      • Lymphomatoid polyposis.
      • The oropharynx, especially Waldeyer's ring (sore throat or difficulty swallowing).
    • Bone marrow involvement (cytopenias-anemia, leukopenia, and thrombocytopenia).
    • Splenomegaly (abdominal discomfort and a sensation of fullness).

 

Hodgkin lymphoma

(Option B ruled out)

Non-Hodgkin lymphoma

(Option C)

Age of presentation

Bimodal distribution peaks in young adults (15-35 years) and older adults (over 55).

More common in older adults but can occur at any age.

Localization

More often localised to a single axial group of nodes (cervical, mediastinal, para-aortic)

More frequent involvement of multiple peripheral nodes

Malignant cells

 

Reed-Sternberg cells (owl eye cells) - B cells - induce inflammation and fibrosis

Lymphoid cells - many subtypes - most are B cells than T cells

Mass composition

Inflammatory cells and fibrosis (reactive cells)

Lymphoid cells

Clinical

  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • B symptoms
  • Painless lymphadenopathy
  • Mesenteric nodes and Waldeyer ring are involved.

Spread

Contiguous (touching); rarely extranodal

Diffuse; often extranodal

Staging

  • Guides therapy
  • Radiation mainstay treatment

Limited importance

Leukemic phase

Doesn't occur

Occurs

 

Glioblastoma multiforme (Option A) is a type of brain tumour that arises from glial cells. It typically does not cause scrotal swelling or ataxia. The symptoms associated with glioblastoma multiforme are typically related to the location of the tumour within the brain.

Non-seminomatous germ cell tumours (Option D) are a type of testicular cancer that arise from germ cells in the testicles. While they can cause scrotal swelling, ataxia is not a typical presentation of this type of tumour.

questions.text: What is the most appropriate treatment for a patient who frequently experiences a sense of contamination in their hands and compulsively washes them, leading to distress and impaired performance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Exposure and response prevention

Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms suggest Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD), characterized by intrusive thoughts (obsessions) like contamination and repetitive behaviours (compulsions) like excessive handwashing.
  • The most effective treatment for OCD is Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP), a specialized form of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT).
  • ERP works by exposing the patient to anxiety-provoking situations (e.g., touching a surface perceived as contaminated) and preventing the compulsive response (e.g., washing hands), helping the patient habituate to the anxiety and reducing the compulsions over time.

Obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD)

Obsessions

Compulsions
  • Intrusive and unwanted repetitive thoughts, urges, or impulses.
  • Most common: Contamination
  • Repetitive actions or thoughts carried out in a strict, regulation-bound manner or reaction to obsessions
  • Performed to relieve anxiety or fear.
  • Most common: Checking

Clinical Presentation of OCD:

  • Contamination and Cleansing (Most Common):
    • Obsession with contamination followed by compulsive washing and avoidance of presumed contaminants.
  • Pathological Doubt and Checking (Second Most Common):
    • Persistent doubt leading to repeated checking.
  • Intrusive or Forbidden Thoughts (Third Most Common):
    • ​​​​​​​Obsessive thoughts of aggressive or sexual acts, typically without accompanying compulsions.
  • Symmetry and Ordering (Fourth Most Common):
    • ​​​​​​​Preoccupation with symmetry or precision, resulting in compulsions like slow and deliberate actions.
  • Other Symptoms:
    • ​​​​​​​Includes religious obsessions and compulsive hoarding.

Management of OCD:

  • Pharmacotherapy:
    • First-line Treatment: SSRIs and Clomipramine, continued for 1–2 years.
    • Augmentation Options:
      • Antipsychotics: Risperidone, Aripiprazole.
      • Others: Memantine, Riluzole, Ketamine, Lamotrigine, N-acetylcysteine (NAC).
  • Psychotherapy:
    • Exposure and Response Prevention (ERP): Patients face feared situations while refraining from compulsive responses.
    • Additional Therapies: Desensitization, thought-stopping, flooding, aversive conditioning, psychodynamic psychotherapy, and family therapy.
    • Severe Symptoms or Comorbid Depression: Begin with pharmacotherapy.
  • Somatic Therapies:
    • Anterior cingulotomy or capsulotomy.
    • Deep brain stimulation with electrode implantation.


Incorrect Options:

DBT (Option A) Dialectical behavioural therapy is not considered the first management line in OCD. It is commonly used for individuals diagnosed with borderline personality disorder or mood disorders.

Systematic desensitization (Option C), thought-stopping, flooding, and aversive conditioning are also used to treat OCD. However, exposure and response prevention is the best way of managing this condition.

CBT (Option D) Exposure and response prevention is a kind of CBT that helps reduce anxiety and distress associated with repeated exposure to thoughts or objects triggering the condition.

questions.text: What is a true statement about nicotine substitution therapy?

choices.text: Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death
There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption
Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives 25% higher blood level than lozenges

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) There should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption

Explanation:

  • When a patient is using nicotine gum for nicotine substitution therapy, there should be a 15-minute gap between nicotine gum and coffee/soda/acidic food as they decrease its absorption.

Treatment of Nicotine addiction

Therapy

Description

Nicotine gum
  • Smokers can use 1-2 gums per hour and a maximum of 24 gums per day.
  • It releases nicotine by chewing and buccal absorption.
  • Beverages like coffee, tea, soda, and juice should not be used during gum use because they decrease absorption.
  • Poor compliance is a drawback.

Nicotine lozenges
  • Users must suck the lozenges until it is completely dissolved and must not swallow it.
  • Useful for people who smoke immediately after awakening.
  • It provides the highest level of nicotine compared to other nicotine replacement therapies.

﻿﻿Nicotine patches
  • Attached to the skin
  • Continuous delivery of nicotine and is available as 16 or 24-hour tapering preparations.
  • It has good compliance.

﻿﻿Nicotine nasal spray
  • Provides nicotine concentration in the blood similar to
    Smoking.
  • Major adverse effects are rhinitis, watering eyes, and coughing

﻿﻿Nicotine inhaler
  • Nicotine absorption occurs in the upper throat, not the lungs

Non-nicotine medications
  • ﻿﻿Bupropion (an antidepressant): It has dopaminergic and adrenergic actions.
  • ﻿﻿Varenicline is a partial agonist of alpha-4 beta-2 nicotinic receptors.
    • It blocks nicotine from binding to the receptor and decreases the rewarding aspects of cigarette smoking.
    • It also stimulates the receptor and reduces withdrawal and cravings.
    • Comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.
  • ﻿﻿Nortriptyline (Second-line drug)
  • ﻿﻿Clonidine: It decreases the sympathetic activity from locus ceruleus and is useful in controlling withdrawal symptoms.

Incorrect Options:

Preferably given by gastrointestinal route (Option A). It is not true, as nicotine replacement therapy is administered through transdermal patches, lozenges, inhalers, nicotine gums, and nasal sprays.

Varenicline comes with a black box warning of cardiovascular death (Option B): Varenicline helps reduce craving and withdrawal symptoms associated with smoking cessation. It comes with a black box warning of serious neuropsychiatric events like agitation, mood changes, and suicidal thoughts.

Nicotine chewing gum is better for constant use as it gives a 25% higher blood level than lozenges (Option D): It is not valid, as nicotine gums and lozenges are equally effective, and one does not show a 25% higher blood level.

questions.text: According to ICD 11, which of the options below is not categorised as Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder (OCD)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PTSD

Explanation:

  • Trichotillomania (Option A), body dysmorphic disorder (Option B), and hypochondriac disorders (Option C) are classified as OCD as per ICD 11, while PTSD is a separate entity.
  • Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) is marked by excessive stress and anxiety following exposure to a traumatic/ stressful event like an accident/ military combat/ assault/kidnapping/ sexual abuse.

Obsessive-compulsive or related disorders as per ICD 11

Refers to a group of disorders that are characterised by repetitive thoughts and behaviours that are similar in etiology

Features

Obsessions, intrusive thoughts and preoccupations

Disorders

  • Obsessive-compulsive disorders
  • Body dysmorphic disorders
  • Hypochondriasis
  • Olfactory reference disorders
  • Hoarding disorders
  • Body-focused repetitive behaviour disorders
    • Skin pricking
    • Hair pulling - Trichotillomania

Incorrect Options:

Trichotillomania (Option A) is the irresistible and repeated urge to pull hair and the inability to stop. It is classified under obsessive-compulsive disorder as per ICD-11.

Body dysmorphic disorder (Option B) is a preoccupation with an imagined defect/slight anomaly in physical appearance characterised by repetitive behaviour like mirror checking and mental acts like comparing oneself with others. It is classified as an obsessive-compulsive disorder as per ICD-11.

Hypochondriac disorder (Option C) is a preoccupation with fear of a serious physical illness despite investigations and medical reassurance. It is classified as OCD as per ICD-11.

questions.text: Under the Mental Health Care Act 2017, a patient has the right to choose his or her caretaker and future course of action in treatment. What is this provision known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Advance directive

Explanation:

  • The provision mentioned in the question is known as an "advance directive."

Provisions

Description

Advance directive

It is a legal document that allows individuals to specify their preferences regarding:

  • Medical or mental health treatment in the future
  • Particularly if they become incapable of making decisions at that time.
  • Empower individuals to express their wishes regarding treatment, including choosing a caretaker or outlining their desired course of action.
 

Advance directives are meant to ensure that an individual's autonomy and preferences are respected and followed in the event of incapacity.

Treatment directive

(Option A)

It is a legal document that outlines a person's preferences for medical treatment if they cannot make decisions for themselves.

Mental will

(Option B)

It is not a commonly used term or provision in the context of mental health legislation; however, it is an advance directive for mental health care or the exercise of autonomy in mental health treatment decisions.

Future directive

(Option C)

It is a general term that could refer to various legal documents or provisions related to specifying preferences or instructions for future medical or mental health treatment.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has a history of urinating in public without having any remorse for it. She also has difficulty in getting motivated and has mild memory deficits. Which of the following lobes may be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Frontal

Explanation:

  • Based on the given history of patients, behaviour, such as urinating in public without remorse and difficulty in getting motivated, are more consistent with frontal lobe dysfunction.

A damaged part of the brain

Description

Frontal lobe

  • It plays a crucial role in executive functions, which include decision-making, motivation, impulse control, emotional regulation, and social behaviour.
  • Dysfunction or lesions in the frontal lobe can lead to changes in behaviour, impulsivity, disinhibition, impaired judgment, and difficulties in motivation.

Parietal lobe
  • It is primarily involved in processing sensory information and spatial awareness.
  • It plays a role in integrating sensory input, perception of touch, spatial orientation, and body awareness.

Occipital lobe
  • It is primarily responsible for processing visual information.
  • It is involved in visual perception, object recognition, and visual memory.

Temporal lobe
  • It involves various functions: memory, language processing, auditory perception, and emotional regulation.

questions.text: A person working in an industry for a long time develops progressive breathlessness. The histopathological image of his lung biopsy is given below. What industry was the person most likely working in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Asbestos

Explanation:
