The histopathological image shows ferruginous bodies, suggestive of Asbestosis, indicating the person likely worked in the asbestos industry.

  • It is a chronic lung condition caused by the inhalation of asbestos fibres over a prolonged period.
  • These fibres accumulate in the lung tissue, leading to inflammation, fibrosis, and scarring.
  • Symptoms: Includes shortness of breath, coughing, and chest tightness
  • The histopathological features seen in asbestosis include:
    • Interstitial fibrosis:
      • Asbestos fibres cause injury to the lung parenchyma, resulting in the deposition of collagen and fibrous tissue in the interstitium.
      • This fibrosis leads to thickening of the alveolar walls and restrictive lung function.
    • Ferruginous bodies:
      • Asbestos fibres can be recognized in the lung tissue as long, golden-brown, rod-shaped structures called ferruginous bodies.
      • These bodies are composed of asbestos fibre coated with iron and protein.

Silica (Option A) exposure is associated with a lung disease called silicosis. Histopathological features of silicosis include nodular lesions with silica particles, collagenous fibrosis, and concentric silicotic nodules featuring central collagen and a peripheral zone of dust-laden macrophages.

 

Coal dust (Option C) exposure is associated with coal worker's pneumoconiosis (CWP). Histopathological features of CWP include the presence of coal macules (collections of carbon-laden macrophages) and coal nodules (fibrotic lesions with central cores of coal dust).

 

Cotton (Option D) exposure can lead to a lung disease known as byssinosis, also called brown lung disease. Histopathological findings in byssinosis include bronchiolitis and chronic bronchitis with peribronchiolar fibrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following adverse effects is the least probable in a patient prescribed with escitalopram?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Sialorrhea

Explanation:

  • Sialorrhea, which refers to excessive salivation or drooling, is not associated with the use of Escitalopram.

Escitalopram

Selective Serotonin Reuptake Inhibitors (SSRIs) increase serotonin levels in the brain, which helps regulate mood, emotion, and sleep.

Side Effects

Gastrointestinal

  • Nausea (most common) (Option A)
  • Diarrhea
  • Anorexia
  • Dry mouth
  • Weight gain
  • Constipation (especially with paroxetine)

CNS

  • Anxiety
  • Insomnia
  • Sedation
  • Vivid dreams (Option B)
  • Emotional blunting
  • Seizures (rare)
  • Extrapyramidal symptoms

Sexual Dysfunction

  • Decreased libido
  • Delayed ejaculation
  • Inhibited orgasm - Anorgasmia (Option C)

Hematological

  • Impaired platelet aggregation
  • Increased risk of GI bleeding (especially with NSAIDs)

Miscellaneous

  • Hyponatremia
  • Allergic rashes
  • Hyperprolactinemia (leading to galactorrhea or menstrual irregularities)

questions.text:
Arrange the following cellular events of inflammation in the correct sequence:


	Rolling
	Cytokine-mediated integrin activation
	Adhesion
	Migration
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

The correct sequence of cellular events of inflammation is as follows:

  • Rolling:
    • It involves the interaction between selectins on endothelial cells and their ligands on leukocytes.
    • This interaction causes leukocytes to roll along the endothelial surface.
  • Cytokine-mediated integrin activation:
    • Inflammatory cytokines, such as TNF-alpha and IL-1, are released at the site of inflammation.
    • These cytokines induce the activation of integrins in leukocytes.
    • Integrins are cell adhesion molecules that bind to their ligands on endothelial cells, promoting stronger adhesion.
  • Adhesion:
    • Activated integrins on leukocytes bind to their ligands on endothelial cells, such as ICAM-1 and VCAM-1.
    • This adhesion stabilizes the interaction between leukocytes and endothelial cells, allowing leukocytes to adhere firmly to the endothelial surface.
  • Migration:
    • Leukocytes undergo diapedesis, or transmigration, after firmly adhering to the endothelial cells.
    • They migrate through the endothelial junctions and move towards tissue injury or infection sites, guided by chemotactic signals.

 

Leukocyte migration involves multiple steps: neutrophils first roll, then activate and adhere to the endothelium, transmigrate across it, pierce the basement membrane, and migrate toward chemoattractants from the injury site.

questions.text: Which medication should be avoided in a 30-year-old female presenting with redness, pain, increased intraocular pressure, keratic precipitates, and aqueous flare?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Prostaglandin analogues

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of redness, pain, keratic precipitates, aqueous flare, and increased intraocular pressure is suggestive of anterior uveitis induced glaucoma. Prostaglandin analogues are contraindicated in cases of Uveitis as it may aggravate the inflammation.

 

Anti-Glaucoma drugs:

Prostaglandin Analogues:

Latanoprost, Bimatoprost, Travoprost, Tafluprost

Mechanism:

Increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Sandy eyes, orbital fat atrophy, anterior uveitis, cystoid macular edema, heterochromia iridis, hypertrichosis

Contraindications:

Cystoid macular edema, diabetes mellitus, Anterior Uveitis (Option D)

Beta Blockers: (Option A)

  • Non-Selective: Timolol, Levobunolol, Carteolol, Metipranolol
  • Selective: Betaxolol, Levobetaxolol

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Allergic blepharoconjunctivitis, dry eyes, corneal hypoesthesia

Alpha-2 Agonists:

Brimonidine (long-term use), Apraclonidine (IOP spikes)

Mechanism:

Reduces aqueous production, increases uveoscleral outflow

Adverse effects:

Lid retraction, respiratory depression (Brimonidine), allergic blepharoconjunctivitis

Contraindications:

Children <2 years

Additional:

Brimonidine: Safest during pregnancy (Category B)

Miotics:

Pilocarpine, Physostigmine, Echothiophate

Mechanism:

Stimulates M3 receptors, increasing trabecular outflow

Adverse effects:

Brow pain, miosis, cataract (Echothiophate), retinal tears

Carbonic Anhydrase Inhibitors: (Option C)

Acetazolamide (systemic), Brinzolamide, Dorzolamide (topical)

Mechanism:

Inhibits aqueous secretion

Adverse effects:

Ciliary edema, secondary angle-closure glaucoma

Osmotic agents: (Option B)

Mannitol (IV), Glycerol (oral)

Mechanism:

Lowers IOP by creating an osmotic gradient

Adverse effects:

Cardiac overload, urinary retention

 

Newer Drugs:

  • Netarsudil (Rho kinase inhibitor): Increases trabecular outflow; Side effect - vortex keratopathy
  • Omidenepag (PGE2 agonist): Increases both trabecular and uveoscleral outflow

questions.text: What is the term used to refer to the provision in the Mental Health Care Act 2017, which grants a patient the right to select their caregiver and determine their future treatment plan?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Advance directive

Explanation:

  • The Mental Health Care Act 2017 in India allows patients to create an advance directive, which enables them to select their caregiver and outline their treatment preferences for the future, especially in situations where they may be unable to make decisions due to their mental health condition.

Advance directives of the Mental Health Care Act, 2017:

  • Every person who is not a minor can create an advance directive.
  • Individuals can specify how they wish to be treated for a mental illness.
  • Individuals can specify how they do not want to be treated for a mental illness.
  • Individuals can appoint a nominated representative.
  • The nominated representative's role is activated only when the individual loses the capacity to make decisions.
  • The psychiatrist or medical officer in charge of treatment is responsible for ensuring that care aligns with the patient's advance directive.
  • The patient, caregiver, or nominated representative is responsible for providing access to the advance directive for the psychiatrist or medical officer in charge.
  • The doctor cannot be held liable if unforeseen consequences arise from following a valid advance directive.
  • Advance directives are not applicable in emergency treatment situations.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who presented with proptosis of one of the eyes was found to have a desmin-positive tumour. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Embryonal Rhabdomyosarcoma

Explanation:

  • The clinical presentation of a 5-year-old child with proptosis and a desmin-positive tumour suggests embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS).
  • Desmin is a marker for muscle differentiation, and rhabdomyosarcoma, a malignant tumour of skeletal muscle origin, is common in children and can present with proptosis if it involves the orbit.

Rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS)

Origin

A malignant tumour arising from skeletal muscle progenitors

Types

  • Embryonal rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Alveolar rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Pleomorphic rhabdomyosarcoma.
  • Spindle cell/sclerosing rhabdomyosarcoma

Clinical features
  • It is the most common soft tissue sarcoma in children and adolescents.
  • It commonly presents in the extremities.
  • Pediatric rhabdomyosarcomas mostly arise in the sinuses, head and neck, and genitourinary tract.

IHC Positive Markers
  • Desmin
  • Myogenin
  • MyoD1
  • Muscle-specific actin

Gross appearance
  • The tumours are often large, soft, and infiltrative, with areas of necrosis and haemorrhage.

Microscopy

  • Small, round to spindle-shaped cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and scant cytoplasm, sometimes with a myxoid stroma, are also seen.

 

Ewing’s sarcoma (Option A) is a malignant tumour typically affecting bones or soft tissues, often seen in children and adolescents. It is characterized by a specific genetic translocation (t(11;22)) and is usually not associated with desmin positivity, which is more typical of rhabdomyosarcoma. Ewing's sarcoma may cause localized swelling or pain but rarely presents with proptosis unless it involves the orbit or surrounding tissues. It is composed of sheets of uniform, small, round cells with scant cytoplasm that may be clear due to abundant glycogen.

Leukaemia (Option C) is a type of cancer that affects the blood and bone marrow, leading to the uncontrolled production of abnormal white blood cells. It typically doesn't present with localized tumours or proptosis. However, in cases of leukemic infiltration of the orbit, proptosis may occur, though it's relatively rare.

Retinoblastoma (Option D) is a malignant eye tumour that primarily affects young children, often before the age of 5. While it can cause proptosis due to orbital involvement, it is typically not associated with a desmin-positive tumour. Retinoblastoma usually presents with a white reflex in the pupil (leukocoria) and can cause vision problems or strabismus.

questions.text: Which statement most accurately characterizes paradoxical suicide?

choices.text: Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover
Suicide after taking a low dose of a drug

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Suicide occurring at the time when the patient starts to recover

Explanation:

  • Paradoxical suicide refers to suicide occurring when the patient begins to show signs of recovery from a depressive or psychiatric episode.
  • It is believed that during recovery, the patient may have gained enough energy or motivation to carry out the act that they were previously too lethargic or hopeless to perform.
  • It is called paradoxical, as one might expect that the risk of suicide reduces as the patient recovers, but actually, the risk of suicide is increased.

questions.text: What is the primary mode of dissemination of retinoblastoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Direct invasion

Explanation:

  • Retinoblastoma primarily disseminates by Direct extension to the Optic nerve. Though optic nerve invasion is the primary mode of dissemination, it occurs via Direct invasion. Hence Direct invasion would be the most appropriate answer.

 

Staging and Treatment of Retinoblastoma: (International Classification of Retinoblastoma)

ICRB Stage

Features

Treatment

A
  • Small intraretinal tumors (<3mm)
  • Located >3 mm from the foveola and >1.5 mm from the optic disc

 
  • Laser photocoagulation: Posterior to equator
  • Cryotherapy: Anterior to equator
  • Thermotherapy
  • Chemoreduction (Etoposide, Vincristine and Carboplatin)

B
  • Large tumors >3 mm in dimension
  • Any size tumors located <3 mm from fovea, and <1.5 mm from the optic disc margin
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Plaque radiotherapy

C
  • Subretinal seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds ≤ 3 mm from tumor
  • Chemoreduction + focal consolidation
  • Possible intravitreal chemotherapy for vitreous seeding

D
  • Subretinal seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Vitreous seeds > 3 mm from tumor
  • Both subretinal and vitreous seeds > 3 mm from retinoblastoma
  • Chemoreduction + possible intravitreal chemotherapy
  • External beam radiotherapy in some cases
  • Enucleation if poor response to other treatments

E

Extensive retinoblastoma occupying > 50% of the globe with or without:

  • Neovascular glaucoma
  • Hemorrhage
  • Extension of tumor to optic nerve or anterior chamber
  • Enucleation
  • Possible adjuvant chemotherapy if high-risk features

questions.text:
Which of the following is true?


	BRCA1 is an oncogene
	HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer
	EGFR+ is seen in non-small cell lung cancer
	N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 2, 3

Explanation:

HER2/neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer:

  • In breast cancer, amplification of the HER2 gene and overexpression of the HER2 protein can occur.
  • HER2 amplification is not observed in all breast cancers but only in a fraction of cases. (Statement 2)
  • Breast cancers that show HER2 amplification are referred to as HER2-positive breast cancers and can be targeted with specific therapies like trastuzumab.

EGFR is seen in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC):

  • In non-small cell lung cancer, mutations or overexpression of the EGFR gene can occur. (Statement 3)
  • EGFR-targeted therapies, such as tyrosine kinase inhibitors, are used in the treatment of EGFR-positive NSCLC.

BRCA1 (Breast Cancer 1)

  • It is classified as a tumour suppressor gene. (Statement 1 ruled out)
  • Mutations increase the risk of cancers such as breast, ovarian, prostate, and pancreatic cancers and are inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.

N-MYC

  • It is an oncogene. (Statement 4 ruled out)
  • It is associated with neuroblastoma (most common), small-cell lung cancer, and medulloblastoma.

questions.text: A karyotyping image is given below. What are the clinical features most likely to be expected in such patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Gynecomastia and long limbs

Explanation:

The karyotype image reveals an additional X chromosome, confirming the presence of Klinefelter Syndrome (47, XXY), a condition often associated with features like gynecomastia and longer limbs.

  • It is male hypogonadism resulting from two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y chromosomes.
  • It is an important genetic cause of reduced spermatogenesis and male infertility.
  • Karyotype: The most common is 47, XXY, from meiotic nondisjunction; some have mosaic patterns (e.g., 46, XY/47, XXY).
  • X chromosome genes: Some genes escape inactivation, leading to uneven dosage compensation and overexpression.
  • Clinical features of Klinefelter syndrome:
    • Gynecomastia (breast development)
    • Long limbs
    • Infertility (most common cause of male hypogonadism and infertility).

 

Flat occiput (Option B) is a feature of Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), a genetic condition caused by an extra chromosome 21, leading to intellectual disability, developmental delays, and physical traits like a flat face and almond-shaped eyes. It’s linked to heart defects, hearing loss, and other health issues.

Webbing of the neck and lymphedema (Option C) are features of Turner’s syndrome, a genetic condition that occurs when a female is born with only one full X chromosome (45, X instead of the usual 46, XX). It leads to short stature, infertility, and sometimes heart defects, kidney problems, and hearing loss. Individuals may also have learning difficulties, particularly with spatial reasoning.

Cleft lip and polydactyly (Option D) are features of Patau syndrome (Trisomy 13), a genetic disorder caused by an extra copy of chromosome 13. It leads to severe intellectual disability, cleft lip and palate, polydactyly (extra fingers or toes), heart defects, and brain abnormalities. Most affected infants have a short life expectancy, often not surviving beyond the first year.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the SAFE strategy for trachoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Evaluation of control program

Explanation:

  • Evaluation of control program is NOT included in the SAFE strategy for Trachoma.

 

Diagnosis and Management of Trachoma:

Investigations

  • Micro-immunofluorescence (micro-IF): Using pooled antigens; For routine diagnostic purposes
  • Culture of C. trachomatis: In irradiated McCoy cells; Expensive
  • Monoclonal antibody direct tests: IgA-IPA light microscopy tests are the best combination for diagnosis

Management (SAFE strategy)

 

SAFE is a WHO-recommended combination of interventions to treat trachoma and prevent it from leading to blindness

  • Surgery for cicatricial entropion and trichiasis (Tertiary prevention)
  • Antibiotics to eliminate the organism (Secondary prevention)
  • Facial cleanliness to avoid infection (Primary prevention)
  • Environmental improvement with better hygiene and sanitation (Primordial prevention)

Surgery (Tertiary prevention) (Option B)

Epilation/ Bilamellar tarsal rotation

Antibiotics (Secondary prevention) (Option A)
  • For areas with 10% or more prevalence of active trachoma (TF in children 1-9 yrs): Azithromycin single oral dose 20 mg/kg to all community members
  • 5% to 10% prevalence: Antibiotic therapy targeted in the family and close contact only
  • Less than 5% prevalence: Only patients are treated

Facial cleanliness (Primary prevention) (Option D)

Frequent face wash with clean water, Avoid common towels, handkerchiefs, Surma rods, etc

Environmental improvement (Primordial prevention) (Option C)

Water latrines and good water supply to reduce flies, Sprays to control flies, Health education

questions.text: Which of the following can be prevented by transfusing irradiated RBCs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Graft versus host disease

Explanation:

Transfusion of irradiated red blood cells (RBCs) can prevent graft versus host disease (GVHD).

Steps for Production of Red Blood Cell Concentrates (RBCC) from Whole Blood

1

Whole Blood Collection

  • Blood is drawn into sterile bags with anticoagulants to prevent clotting. Each unit contains 450-500 mL. (First 20-30 ml is discarded due to skin flora contamination)

2

Slow Speed Centrifugation (Soft Spin)

  • Separates Red Blood Cell Concentrate (RBCC) at the bottom and Platelet-Rich Plasma (PRP) at the top, with the buffy coat (white blood cells) in between.

3

RBCC Processing and Additive Solutions

  • After removing plasma and buffy coat, additive solutions like SAGM (Saline, Adenine, Glucose, Mannitol) or CPD are added to preserve cell viability and extend shelf life.

4

Leukoreduction/ Deleucocytation

Achieved by filtering RBCC to remove >99.9% of white blood cells.

Purpose:

  • Nonhemolytic Febrile Transfusion Reactions (NHFTRs). (Option D ruled out)
  • Alloimmunization and platelet transfusion refractoriness. (Option B ruled out)
  • Transfusion-transmitted infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV).
  • Immunomodulation risks from transfusions (Option C ruled out)

 

Post-reduction leukocyte content: <1–5 x 10⁶ leukocytes/unit.

5

Irradiation (Optional)

  • RBCC is irradiated with X-rays or gamma rays (25–35 Gy).
  • Purpose: Prevents graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) by inactivating donor lymphocytes.(Option A)
  • Use: RBCC must be transfused within 24 hours post-irradiation.

6

Plasma Reduction (Optional)

  • Plasma proteins are removed to prevent allergic or anaphylactic reactions.

Purpose: Useful for patients with a history of allergic transfusion reactions, reducing post-transfusion anaphylaxis risk.

7

Cryopreservation (Optional)

  • RBCC is cryopreserved at -80°C, mainly for rare blood types.

Purpose: Extends shelf life up to 30 years, increasing availability of rare blood groups.

questions.text:
Identify the surgical step shown in the image given below:

[
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Capsulorrhexis

Explanation:

  • The surgical procedure where tryphan blue dye is being injected in the image is Continuous curvilinear Capsulorrhexis. It refers to the creation of a circular tear in the anterior capsule of the lens.

 

Surgical Steps of Conventional ECCE:

  • Eye Stabilization: Superior rectus suture for downward gaze(known as bridle suture)
  • Conjunctival Flap Creation: A fornix-based flap will be used to expose the limbus.
  • Limbal Incision: Partial-thickness groove across the limbus.
  • Anterior Chamber Access: Entry with a razor blade knife or keratome.
  • Viscoelastic Injection: Maintains chamber depth and protects the cornea.
  • Anterior Capsulotomy/ Capsulorrhexis: Methods include can-opener, linear capsulotomy, envelope, or CCC. Tryphan blue dye is usually injected. (Option B)
  • Capsule Removal: Using forceps remove the cut capsule.
  • Corneoscleral Section Completion: Extending the incision.
  • Hydrodissection: Separates the lens from the capsule. (Option A)
  • Nucleus Removal: Methods include pressure/counter pressure or irrigating wire vectis.
  • Lens Cortex Aspiration: Using a two-way cannula. (I/A) (Option D)
  • IOL Implantation: Posterior chamber IOL into the capsular bag. (Option C)
  • Incision Closure: With sutures.
  • Viscoelastic Removal: Followed by refilling the anterior chamber with irrigating fluid.
  • Conjunctival Flap Repositioning: Secured in place.
  • Subconjunctival Injections: Dexamethasone and gentamicin.
  • Eye Patching: Final step.

questions.text: Which congenital heart disease exhibits equivalent saturation levels across all heart chambers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation

  • The congenital heart disease that exhibits equivalent saturation levels across all heart chambers is total anomalous pulmonary venous circulation.
  • This is because, in this condition, the systemic and pulmonary venous blood mixes in the heart (right atrium) and then is distributed into all chambers of the heart leading to an equivalent saturation across all heart chambers.

Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection:

  • Pulmonary veins drain into the right atrium directly or indirectly via an abnormal venous connection.

Sites of venous connection:

  • Supracardiac- superior vena cava
  • Cardiac-coronary sinus, right atrium
  • Infracardiac
  • Mixed

Clinical presentation:

  • Cyanosis and congestive cardiac failure

Diagnosis:

  • Chest X-ray:
    • Snowman or figure-8 configuration.
    • Cardiomegaly and increased pulmonary vascularity are evident
  • ECG: Right axis deviation and right ventricular hypertrophy.
  • Others: Echocardiography, CT, MRI.

Treatment:

  • Supplemental oxygen
  • Ionotropic support
  • Mechanical ventilation if necessary
  • Balloon Atrial Septostomy: This may be required in rare cases with a restricted patent foramen ovale.
  • Cardiac catheterization: Stents may be placed to stabilize the neonate in cases of obstructive TAPVC.

In Tetralogy of Fallot (Option A), there is a ventricular septal defect, overriding aorta, pulmonary stenosis and right ventricular hypertrophy. Thus, the failure in the closure of the foramen ovale, right to left results in mixed blood in the left heart and unoxygenated blood in the right heart. Hence all four chambers don't have the same oxygen concentration.

Tricuspid atresia (Option C) is a congenital condition characterised by the absence of the tricuspid valve, leading to a hypoplastic (underdeveloped) right ventricle. Here, blood flows through an atrial septal defect (ASD) into the left atrium (LA) and then to the left ventricle (LV). The saturation cannot be equal across all chambers since the left ventricle is hypoplastic.

In transposition of great arteries (Option D), the right ventricle ends at the right aorta, which carries deoxygenated blood from the right ventricle to the tissue while the left ventricle drains into the pulmonary artery. Hence two separate systems are created. Deoxygenated blood is circulated in systemic circulation and oxygenated in the pulmonary circulation.

questions.text: Can you determine the observation indicated by the arrow in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Vossius ring

Explanation:

  • The given image is suggestive of Vossius ring, a condition that is typically detected during an ophthalmological examination following a blunt trauma to the eye. The Vossius ring itself is identified by the presence of pigment dispersion in a circular shape on the anterior surface of the lens following blunt trauma to the eye.

 

 

Blunt trauma to the eye:

Damage Mechanisms
  • Direct Impact: Greatest damage at impact site.
  • Compression Wave Force: Distant damage ("contrecoup").
  • Indirect Force: Damage from impact against orbital walls.

Specific Injuries
  • Cornea: Descemet's membrane tears
  • Conjunctiva: Subconjunctival haemorrhage
  • Anterior Chamber: Hyphema (most common sign), exudates.
  • Iris, Pupil, Ciliary Body: Iridodialysis,Iridodonesis.
  • Lens: Rosette shaped cataract, ectopia lentis, Vossius ring
  • Vitreous: Liquefaction, opacities, detachment.
  • Choroid: choroidal rupture(bucket handle type)
  • Retina: Commotio retinae, Rhegmatogenous retinal detachment, Gray white retina due to Berlin's edema.
  • Intraocular Pressure: Traumatic glaucoma, hypotony, ghost cell glaucoma, angle recession glaucoma
  • Traumatic optic neuropathy-RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect)

 

Incorrect Options:

Weiss Ring (Option B): This is an opacified ring-shaped structure that can be seen floating within the vitreous humor of the eye, often signifying a posterior vitreous detachment, a condition in which the vitreous gel separates from the retina.

 

Fleischer's Ring (Option C): This refers to a pigmented, circular line found at the edge of the cornea in keratoconus patients due to iron deposition in the corneal epithelial layer. It's composed of iron deposits and signifies corneal thinning and protrusion.

 

Kayser-Fleischer Ring (Option D): This is a brown-colored ring found at the periphery of the cornea, most commonly seen in patients with Wilson's disease, a rare genetic disorder leading to excessive copper deposition in the body.

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Endo-myocardial biopsy

Explanation:

  • Endo-myocardial biopsy is considered the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis of myocarditis.
  • It involves obtaining a small tissue sample from the endocardium or the myocardium to examine it under a microscope.
  • This biopsy allows for direct visualization of the cardiac tissue and assessment of cellular inflammation, the presence of viral particles, and other histopathological changes characteristic of myocarditis.

Myocarditis

It is a diverse group of pathologic entities in which infectious microorganisms and/or a primary inflammatory process cause myocardial injury.

Pathogenesis

Infections:

  • Viruses (e.g., Coxsackievirus, Echovirus, Influenza, HIV, Cytomegalovirus)
  • Chlamydiae (e.g., Chlamydophila psittaci)
  • Rickettsiae (e.g., Rickettsia typhi, Typhus fever)
  • Bacteria (e.g., Corynebacterium diphtheriae, Neisseria meningococcus, Borrelia)
  • Fungi (e.g., Candida) Protozoa (e.g., Trypanosoma cruzi [Chagas disease], toxoplasmosis) Helminths (e.g., Trichinosis)

 

Immune-Mediated Reactions

  • Postviral
  • Poststreptococcal (Rheumatic fever)
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Drug hypersensitivity (e.g., methyldopa, sulfonamides)
  • Transplant rejection
  • Immune checkpoint inhibitor therapies

 

Unknown

  • Sarcoidosis
  • Giant cell myocarditis

Clinical features
  • It can be asymptomatic (recovery without sequelae)
  • Heart failure
  • Arrhythmias
  • Sudden death
  • Symptoms include fatigue, dyspnea, palpitations, precordial discomfort, and fever.

 

Magnetic Resonance Imaging (Option B) can offer valuable supportive evidence for diagnosing myocarditis, but it is not regarded as the gold standard. Cardiac MRI can reveal myocardial oedema, inflammation, and tissue characterization through specific sequences like T2-weighted imaging and late gadolinium enhancement.

Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) (Option C) is a hormone secreted by the heart in response to increased stretching of the cardiac chambers, commonly observed in conditions like heart failure. Although BNP levels can be elevated in myocarditis due to associated cardiac dysfunction, it is not a specific test for diagnosing myocarditis.

LDH1 to LDH2 ratio (Option D) is not a specific diagnostic marker for myocarditis. Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) is an enzyme present in various tissues, including the heart. In myocarditis, LDH levels may be elevated due to myocardial injury.

questions.text: Which of the following are components of kangaroo mother care?

choices.text: Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, prevent infection
Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding
Skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection
Early discharge, exclusive breastfeeding, prevent infection

questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, exclusive breastfeeding

  • Kangaroo mother care involves early discharge, skin-to-skin contact, and exclusive breastfeeding.

Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC):

  • KMC was first suggested in 1978 by Dr Edgar Rey in Bogota, Colombia, for the prevention of neonatal hypothermia in low birth weight/ premature newborns.
  • The mother or any other caregiver can carry out Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC).
  • Components:
    • Kangaroo positioning: Skin-to-skin positioning of the newborn on the mother's chest.
    • Kangaroo nutrition: Adequate nutrition through breastfeeding.
    • Early discharge and ambulatory care.
  • Studies suggest:
    • It is as good as incubators, in terms of safety and thermal protection.
    • Reduces severe morbidity.
    • Promoted bonding between mother and child.
  • It is indicated for all hemodynamically stable low birth weight babies.
  • Short sessions of KMC can be initiated in babies on medical treatment like IV fluids or oxygen therapy.
  • The initialization of KMC can vary depending on the birth weight of the baby.
  • Positioning for KMC: The baby is placed between the mother's breasts in an upright position. The hips are abducted and flexed in the frog position, and the arms are also flexed. The abdomen of the baby should be at the level of the mother's epigastrium. In this position, the mother's breathing would stimulate the baby and prevent the development of apnea.

  • The duration of KMC should be gradually increased from short sessions of more than one hour to 24 hours a day.
  • KMC is not necessary once the baby attains 2500 g of weight or 37 weeks of gestation.

Options A, C, and D are incorrect, as preventing infection is not a part of kangaroo mother care.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Left occipital lobe

Explanation:

  • The visual field defect shown is Right Homonymous Hemianopia, which occurs due to a defect in the Left Occipital lobe.

 

 

Visual Pathway: Temporal fibers carry impulses from the Nasal field, and Nasal fibres carry the Temporal field.

 

 

Components of Visual Pathway

Retina
  • First-order Neurons: Bipolar cells in the inner nuclear layer of the retina.
  • Second-order Neurons: Ganglion cells in the retina; their axons form the optic nerve.

Optic Nerve
  • Carries visual information from the retina to the optic chiasm.
  • Temporal and Nasal fibres of the same eye.

Optic Chiasma
  • Partial decussation occurs
  • Nasal fibres cross to the opposite side, while temporal fibres remain ipsilateral.

Optic Tract
  • Carries visual information from the optic chiasma to the Lateral Geniculate body (LGB).
  • Temporal fibres of the same eye and Nasal fibres of the opposite eye.

Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)
  • Third Order Neurons: Relay visual information to the visual cortex.

Optic Radiations
  • Meyer's Loop: Carries information from lower retinal quadrants to the inferior part of the visual cortex.
  • Baum’s Loop (Dorsal): Carries information from upper retinal quadrants to the superior part of the visual cortex.

Occipital Cortex
  • The primary visual cortex (V1), corresponding to Brodmann area 17, is situated on the medial side of the occipital lobe, particularly along the borders of the calcarine fissure.

 

Visual Pathway Lesions and Defects

Site of Lesion

Fibers Affected

Field Defect

Optic Nerve

Ipsilateral Temporal + Nasal Fibers

Anopia

Optic Chiasma

Bilateral Nasal Fibers

Bitemporal Hemianopia

(Heteronymous Hemianopia) (Option D)

Optic Tract/ Lateral Geniculate Body (LGB)/ Optic Radiation

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers

Homonymous Hemianopia (Option C)

Visual Cortex without the involvement of tip

(Posterior Cerebral Artery)

Ipsilateral Temporal Fibers + Contralateral Nasal Fibers except macular representation

Homonymous Hemianopia with Macular Sparing (Option A)

Tip of Visual Cortex

(Middle Cerebral Artery)

Macular Representation of Ipsilateral Temporal and Contralateral Nasal Fibers.

Macular Homonymous Hemianopia

 

Incorrect options:

Right occipital lobe (Option A) and Right optic tract (Option C): Lesion at right occipital lobe/right optic tract will result in Left sided Homonymous hemianopia.

Optic Chiasma(Option D): Lesion at optic chiasma will result in Bitemporal hemianopia

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a major diagnostic criterion for allergic fungal sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: Option A) Fungal culture

Explanation:

  • Based on the Bent and Kuhn criteria for diagnosing allergic fungal sinusitis, fungal culture is a minor criterion.

Allergic Fungal Rhinosinusitis (AFRS):

  • Non-invasive fungal disease commonly affects younger individuals, especially those in warm, humid climates and lower socio-economic conditions.
  • Common causative organism: Aspergillus.
  • Atopic individuals are more prone to AFRS.
  • Symptoms: Unilateral or bilateral nasal congestion, post-nasal drip, and thick, dark nasal discharge.
  • CT Scan: Shows pansinusitis, hyper attenuated intrasinus contents (allergic mucin), and potential erosion of sinus walls due to inflammation.

Bent and Kuhn Diagnostic Criteria for AFRS:

Major Criteria (must meet all)

Minor Criteria (supportive)
  • Type I hypersensitivity (history, skin test, or in vitro testing)
  • Nasal polyposis (Option A)
  • Characteristic CT findings (Option C ruled out)
  • Eosinophilic mucin without fungal invasion (Option B ruled out)
  • Positive fungal stain (Option D ruled out)
  • Asthma
  • Unilateral disease
  • Radiological bone erosion
  • Fungal cultures (Option A)
  • Serum eosinophilia
  • Charcot-Leyden crystals

questions.text: What is a characteristic feature observed in physiological jaundice?

choices.text: Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased indirect bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine
Increased direct bilirubin, absent urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Increased indirect bilirubin, increased urobilinogen, absent bilirubin in urine

  • In physiological jaundice, indirect bilirubin and urobilinogen are raised, and there is no bilirubin in urine.
  • Increased indirect bilirubin:
    • Physiological jaundice is associated with increased levels of indirect (unconjugated) bilirubin in the blood.
    • This occurs because newborns have an immature liver that is still developing its ability to process bilirubin efficiently.
  • Increased urobilinogen:
    • Physiological jaundice often leads to increased urobilinogen in the urine.
    • Urobilinogen is a breakdown product of bilirubin and is usually elevated in cases of increased bilirubin production, as seen in jaundice.
  • Absent bilirubin in urine: Bilirubin is usually present in the urine in cases of pathological jaundice.

Feature

Physiological Jaundice

Pathological Jaundice

Timing

Appears 24-72 hours after birth; peaks at 3-5 days; resolves by 1-2 weeks

Appears within 24 hours of birth or persists beyond the expected timeframe

Cause

Elevated unconjugated bilirubin due to increased production and immature liver function

Blood group incompatibility, infections, metabolic disorders, genetic conditions

Clinical Presentation

Yellowing of skin and sclera, starting from the face, progressing to the trunk and extremities

Similar to physiological jaundice, but potentially more severe and may include other symptoms

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed (Option D)

Depends on the underlying cause; may include phototherapy, exchange transfusion, or specific treatments

Treatment

Usually self-resolving; observation and reassurance; phototherapy may be used if needed

questions.text: Which cell is the origin of chronic lymphocytic leukaemia / small lymphocytic lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Naive B cells

Explanation:

  • The cells of origin of Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL) and Small Lymphocytic Lymphoma (SLL) are mature B cells.

Genetics:

  • Trisomy 12, deletion 13q14, and others

Origin:

  • Post–germinal centre memory B cell or naive B Cells in the mantle zone of the lymph node (Option A)

Etiopathogenesis

  • Antiapoptotic protein BCL2 overexpression.
  • CLL cell growth depends on Bruton Tyrosine kinase (BTK) activity.
  • No association with radiation exposure

Clinical Presentation

  • Most common Leukemia in the elderly.
  • Frequently asymptomatic at diagnosis.
  • May present with fatigue, lymphadenopathy, hepatosplenomegaly, or infection due to immunosuppression.
  • Associated with autoimmune hemolytic anaemia- Spherocytes can be seen on peripheral smear
  • It can lead to hypogammaglobulinemia due to abnormal B cells, which impair normal antibody production.
  • Infection is the M/C/C of death in CLL

Laboratory diagnosis:

  • Absolute lymphocyte count (ALC) > 5000/mm3
  • Bone marrow lymphocytes >30%
  • Surface markers using flow cytometry were positive for CD5, CD23, CD19 CD20. CLL co-expresses both T cell ( CD5 ) and B cell ( CD20, CD19) markers

 

Mature T cells (Option B) can give rise to several cancers, including Peripheral T-cell lymphoma (PTCL), Cutaneous T-cell lymphoma (CTCL), Adult T-cell leukaemia/lymphoma (ATLL) (associated with HTLV-1), Anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), and T-cell prolymphocytic leukaemia (T-PLL).

Progenitor T cells (Option C) can give rise to cancers such as T-cell acute lymphoblastic leukaemia (T-ALL) and T-cell lymphoblastic lymphoma (T-LBL). Both of these are aggressive hematologic malignancies that involve the malignant transformation of immature T cells (or T-cell precursors), characterized by rapid proliferation of immature T lymphocytes.

Granulocytes (Option D) can give rise to acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML), where immature myeloid cells, including granulocyte precursors, proliferate rapidly, and chronic myelogenous leukaemia (CML), characterized by uncontrolled production of mature granulocytes due to the Philadelphia chromosome. Both cancers stem from the malignant transformation of myeloid progenitor cells.

questions.text: A patient with lytic lesions on the skull is suspected of a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis. Which of the following is a characteristic finding of electron microscopy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Birbeck granules

Explanation:

  • A characteristic finding on electron microscopy in Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is the presence of Birbeck Granules.
  • These are rod-shaped, tennis racket-like structures that have a central linear striation.
  • They are considered to be specific ultrastructural markers for Langerhans cells.
  • These are thought to be derived from the endosomal compartment and are composed of a protein called langerin (CD207), a unique marker for Langerhans cells and is involved in antigen presentation and immune response regulation.

 

Histiocytes (Option A) are a type of immune cell that plays a key role in the body's defence mechanisms. They are specialized macrophages or dendritic cells found in tissues, where they function to engulf pathogens, dead cells, and foreign substances. Histiocytic disorders can give rise to cancers such as histiocytic sarcoma and Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

Eosinophils (Option C) are a type of white blood cell involved in immune responses, particularly in allergic reactions and parasitic infections. They can give rise to cancers such as eosinophilic leukaemia and eosinophilic lymphoma, which are rare disorders characterized by the uncontrolled proliferation of eosinophils, leading to symptoms like organ infiltration, tissue damage, and inflammation.

Giant cells (Option D) are large, multinucleated cells that can arise in response to chronic inflammation or certain infections. They can be found in various cancers, such as giant cell tumours of bone (a benign but locally aggressive tumour) and osteoclast-like giant cell tumours in soft tissues. Additionally, giant cells are often seen in granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis and sarcoidosis, where they form part of the immune response.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy came with bilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. What is the probable diagnosis, cell, and virus associated with the image given below?


	RS cell: Reed Stemberg cell
	HIV: Human immunodeficiency virus
	CMV: Cytomegalovirus
	EBV: Epstein–Barr virus
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hodgkin’s lymphoma, RS cell, EBV

Explanation:

  • The histopathological image reveals Reed-Sternberg cells, indicating Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL), which is associated with EBV (Epstein-Barr virus).

Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Etiology
  • M ore common in whites & Males.
  • Bimodal age distribution with peaks in the 20s and 80s.
  • It is not a part of AIDS-defining lymphoma.
  • Risk Factors:
    •  HIV infection is a major risk factor.
    • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV). (Option C)

Reed-Sternberg (HRS) Cells

(Option C)
  • HRS cells are derived from the germinal centre or post-germinal centre B cells (mature B cells in peripheral lymph nodes).
  • Diagnostic of HL.
  • Large, with abundant cytoplasm, bilobed or multinucleated.
  • Typically positive for PAX-5, CD15, and CD30.

NF-κB Activation
  • Common in cHL, promoting RS cell growth and survival.
  • EBV+ Tumors: Express latent membrane protein-1 (LMP-1), which activates NF-κB.
  • EBV− Tumors: NF-κB activation may result from loss-of-function mutations in IκB or loss-of-function mutation of TNF-α–induced protein 3, both of which normally inhibit NF-κB.
  • NF-κB activation may rescue "crippled" B cells that can't express Ig, preventing apoptosis and enabling further mutations that form RS cells.

Immune Evasion
  • Genetic abnormalities at the PD-L1 locus on chromosome 9p24.1 lead to PD-L1 overexpression, which helps the tumour evade immune detection.

Non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma, RS cell, EBV (Option A): Non-Hodgkin's lymphoma (NHL) is a diverse group of hematologic cancers marked by lymphoid tissue proliferation, often linked to HIV but not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells or EBV.

Kaposi sarcoma, Giant cell, HIV (Option B): Kaposi sarcoma is marked by the proliferation of spindle-shaped cells that express markers of both endothelial (vascular or lymphatic) and smooth muscle cells, and is linked to human herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), but is not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells or EBV.

Infectious mononucleosis, RS cell, CMV (Option D): Infectious mononucleosis, a benign and self-limited lymphoproliferative disorder caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), is characterized histopathologically by atypical lymphocytes—large, irregularly shaped cells with abundant cytoplasm and prominent nuclei. It is not typically associated with Reed-Sternberg cells.

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures is damaged in respiratory distress syndrome in newborns?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - 2

  • In respiratory distress syndrome, there is a lack of surfactants due to damaged type II pneumocytes, which is marked as 2.

Respiratory Distress Syndrome

  • Pathophysiology:
    • Surfactant, a lipoprotein produced by type II alveolar cells, lowers surface tension to prevent alveolar collapse at the end of expiration.
    • Its production begins around 20 weeks of gestation and peaks at 35 weeks, so infants born before 35 weeks are at higher risk for RDS due to insufficient surfactant.
    • Without adequate surfactant, alveoli collapse during expiration, impairing gas exchange and causing tissue hypoxia. This results in increased pulmonary pressure, ischemic damage, and the formation of a hyaline membrane from protein transudation.

  • Clinical Features: Respiratory distress within the first 6 hours of life is characterised by tachypnea, retractions, grunting, cyanosis, and decreased air entry.
  • Management
    • Neonates with this condition require admission to the neonatal intensive care unit, IV fluids, and appropriate respiratory support.
    • Further management details are depicted in the table below

1 (Option A) is labelled as type I alveolar epithelial cells, which are responsible for gaseous exchange.

3 (Option C) is labelled as blood vessels.

4 (Option D) is labelled as RBC inside the blood vessel.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient presents with a cough, a low-grade fever, and hemoptysis. Investigations reveal a cavitary lesion on her right lung apex, which, on biopsy, reveals caseous necrosis. The underlying pathophysiology is:

choices.text: Sudden cut off of blood supply

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Type-4 hypersensitivity reaction

Explanation:

  • The given scenario of cough, fever, hemoptysis, and a cavitary lesion with caseous necrosis at the right lung apex strongly suggests Pulmonary Tuberculosis, which involves a type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.
  • CD4+ T cells activate macrophages, but Mycobacterium tuberculosis survives within them, causing granuloma formation with caseous necrosis, driven by a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction and resulting in tissue damage.

It is a bacterial infection caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and can be classified into the following types:

1. Primary tuberculosis

  • It develops in a previously unexposed and, therefore, unsensitized person.
  • The primary organ involved is mostly the lungs.
  • Location:
    • Sub-pleural region.
    • Lower part of the upper lobe & upper part of the lower lobe.
  • Ghon’s focus: Grey-white area of inflammation with consolidation.
  • Ghon’s complex: Ghon’s focus + inflamed regional lymph nodes.
  • Histology: Granulomatous inflammatory reaction with both caseating and non-caseating tubercles.
  • Simon’s focus: Occult hematogenous dissemination to the apex of the lung.
  • Fate:
    • 95% of the cases are controlled by immunity, calcified, healed lesions and hilar lymph nodes (Ranke complex).
    • 5% of the cases are progressive (Progressive primary TB).
      • Resembles acute bacterial pneumonia.
      • Lymphohematogenous dissemination may cause tuberculous meningitis and/or miliary TB.

2. Secondary tuberculosis

  • It arises in a previously sensitised host.
  • It may follow shortly after primary tuberculosis, but more commonly, it appears months to years after the initial infection, usually when the host resistance is weakened.
  • The apical and posterior lobe segments are involved due to high O2 concentration (Puhl’s focus).
  • The infraclavicular lesion is called Assman’s focus.
  • Regional lymph node involvement is late.
  • Cavitation occurs readily with the erosion of the cavities into an airway.
  • Histology: Active lesions show coalescent tubercles with central caseation (Caseous necrosis).

3. Disseminated TB: Spread to other organs.

  • The images below show the caseous necrosis seen in TB.

 

Enzyme degradation (Option A) may be involved in the breakdown of tissue during infection. The primary mechanism of tissue damage in tuberculosis is the type-4 hypersensitivity reaction.

Fibrinoid deposition (Option C) refers to the accumulation of fibrin-like material in the walls of blood vessels. It is typically associated with conditions such as vasculitis.

Sudden cutoff of blood supply (Option D) occurs when the blood supply to a tissue is abruptly interrupted, leading to ischemia and subsequent tissue death. In the case of tuberculosis, the tissue damage is primarily caused by the immune response and the formation of granulomas.

questions.text: A 3-week-old neonate presents with ambiguous genitalia with Na+ - 127, K+ - 6 meq/L with a BP of 50/22 mm Hg. Along with IV fluids, what specific management is done?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hydrocortisone


Explanation: The clinical presentation of a neonate with ambiguous genitalia, hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, and hypotension is suggestive of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH). Hydrocortisone is administered to manage the condition and address the cortisol deficiency.

Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH):

  • Cause: Over 90% of CAH cases are caused by 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • Hormone deficiency:
    • Salt-wasting form: Deficiency in both aldosterone and cortisol.
    • Simple virilizing form: Adequate aldosterone with excess adrenal androgens.
    • Nonclassic form: Mildly elevated androgens, may be asymptomatic or show signs of androgen excess.
  • Clinical Manifestations:
  1. Aldosterone and Cortisol Deficiency:
    • Both hormones are deficient in the salt-wasting form (70% of cases).
    • Symptoms: Weight loss, vomiting, dehydration, weakness, hypotension, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.
  2. Prenatal Androgen Excess:
    • Excess androgens during gestation lead to virilization in genetic females (46,XX), resulting in female pseudohermaphroditism.
    • Features in affected females:
  • Clitoromegaly, labial fusion, and formation of a urogenital sinus.
  • The internal genitalia are typically normal, as there is no antimüllerian hormone secretion.
  • Male infants (46,XY) appear normal at birth, delaying diagnosis until adrenal insufficiency develops.
  1. Postnatal Androgen Excess:
  • Males: Enlarged penis with small prepubertal testes; potential for testicular adrenal rest tumors.
  • Females: Progressive clitoromegaly and absence of menstruation or breast development unless treated.
  1. Adrenomedullary Dysfunction: Blunted epinephrine responses, hypoglycemia, and cardiovascular effects may exacerbate symptoms of cortisol deficiency in untreated cases.
  • Laboratory Findings:
  • Salt-Wasting Disease: Hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, metabolic acidosis, and hypoglycemia.
  • Hormonal Findings: Elevated 17-hydroxyprogesterone, androstenedione, and testosterone (in females).
  • ACTH Test: A marked increase in 17-hydroxyprogesterone after cosyntropin stimulation confirms the diagnosis.
  • Treatment:
    • Glucocorticoid Replacement Therapy: Replaces cortisol deficiency and suppresses excessive adrenal androgen production.
    • Mineralocorticoid Replacement Therapy: Treats aldosterone deficiency in salt-wasting CAH.
    • Additional Medical Approaches:
      • Antiandrogens (e.g., flutamide): Block androgen effects.
      • Aromatase inhibitors (e.g., anastrozole): Slow skeletal maturation by inhibiting androgen-to-estrogen conversion.
      • Growth hormone therapy: May enhance adult height.
    • Surgical Management:
  • Clitoral reduction (if severe clitoromegaly).
  • Vaginoplasty and urogenital sinus correction.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of poor feeding and abnormal twitching of his lower limbs. On examination, he has fever with fontanelle bulging, and the child was lethargic. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Meningitis


Explanation: The clinical features of poor feeding, fever, bulging fontanelle, lethargy, and abnormal twitching of his lower limb (seizure) strongly suggest meningitis.

 

Bacterial Meningitis:

  • Etiological agents:
 

In India

Overall

Neonates

Gram-negative organisms

(E.Coli > Acinetobacter > Klebsiella)

Group B streptococci

Infants and older children

Streptococcus Pneumoniae >

Neisseria Meningitidis > Haemophilus influenzae.

Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

  • Risk Factors for Bacterial Meningitis:
  1. Lack of preexisting immunity
  2. Close Contact with infected individuals
  3. Crowding
  4. Low Socioeconomic Factors
  5. Congenital or Acquired CSF Leak
  6. Cochlear Implant

 

Category

Clinical Manifestations

Nonspecific Findings
  • Fever, anorexia, poor feeding
  • Headache, upper respiratory symptoms
  • Myalgias, arthralgias
  • Tachycardia, hypotension
  • Cutaneous signs: Petechiae, purpura, or erythematous macular rash

Meningeal Irritation
  • Nuchal rigidity
  • Back pain
  • Kernig sign: Pain with extension of the leg after hip flexion
  • Brudzinski sign: Involuntary flexion of the knees and hips upon neck flexion

Increased Intracranial Pressure (ICP) Signs
  • Headache, emesis
  • Bulging fontanel or diastasis of sutures
  • Cranial nerve involvement: anisocoria, ptosis, abducens nerve paralysis
  • Hypertension with bradycardia, apnea, or hyperventilation
  • Decorticate or decerebrate posturing, stupor, coma, or herniation signs
  • Papilledema

Focal Neurologic Signs
  • Seizures
  • Altered mental status
  • Photophobia
  • Tâche cérébrale: Raised red streak appearing 30-60 seconds after stroking the skin with a blunt object

 

  • Diagnosis:
    • Lumbar puncture and CSF analysis: Gold standard.
    • CSF shows Neutrophilic pleocytosis, increased proteins and decreased glucose.
  • Treatment:
    • Antibiotics: Third-generation cephalosporins (Ceftriaxone) x 10 to 14 days
    • Steroids: Inj. Dexamethasone started 1-2 hr before antibiotics and continued for 48 hrs - Prevents cytokine-mediated CNS injury.

 

Febrile seizures (Option A) typically occur in response to fever, but in the absence of other features of central nervous system infection like bulging fontanelle, poor feeding, and lethargy, they are less likely to be the cause. These symptoms suggest a more severe condition like meningitis.

 

Pseudotumor cerebri (Option C) is a rare condition in children under 10 years old and is often associated with obesity, female gender, and certain medications (like lithium, tetracyclines, steroid withdrawal and hypervitaminosis A). It presents with increased intracranial pressure but does not typically cause fever, bulging fontanelle, or abnormal twitching. It usually has a chronic course and presents with papilledema in most cases.

 

Intracranial hemorrhage (Option D) can lead to seizures or abnormal movements, it generally presents with more pronounced neurological deficits such as altered consciousness, focal neurological findings, or altered tone, and is less likely to cause fever and bulging fontanelle, which are more indicative of meningitis.
